story:
Little Fly Studios is proud to announce the opening of its new Home Studio.  Our new space will host workshops featuring a wide variety of Art and Fine Craft experiences taught by instructors of local and national renown for both youth and adults. In an effort to give back to our community, we will also be offering reduced rate workshops for special needs populations.

The Grand Opening event on June 1, 2013, is designed to provide a free educational experience, celebrating the arts through demonstrations and participatory events. Artwork exhibited will showcase 20+ national and local, professional and emerging artists, including former students from the New Hope-Solebury School District and several Workshop Presenters.  Demonstrations from the artists will include fine art and craft techniques and a participatory community art project for public installation. Music and performances by local artists, and light fare and beverages will also be included in this event.   The Opening is an opportunity for the community to tour our new space and discover the workshops and programs Little Fly Studios has to offer, while celebrating a day of the arts.  This is an all age event and is free to the public.

Here is a start to our growing artists list!

Emerging Local Artists: Dylan Hurwitz (painting) www.dylanhurwitz.com, Kyle Schwander (painting) https://sites.google.com/site/kyledschwander/, Victoria Berends (photography), Rachel Sooy (sculpture and ceramics) www.rachelsooy.com, Kyle Krout (paintings on wood) Spencer Blevins (musician) and Rae Mae (Hoopdancing) http://raemae.moonfruit.com

Professional National and Local: Nancy Weisser of Maryland (glass) www.nancyweisser.com Ginger Hanrahan of Connecticut (painting/collage) http://gingerhanrahan.com/, Jeanne Bessette of N.C. (paintings) http://bessetteart.com/  Charlotte Brem NYC (sculpture),  Liza Lucy of New Hope, PA (quilts) http://www.gloriouscolor.com/index.php Bob Krist of New Hope, PA (photography books) Alex Wender of Hawthorne, NJ (photography) www.knowingthefuture.com, Terry Meehan (painting), Lauren Kindle (collage and watercolor), Wendy Blevins (glass, mosaics, paintings), Donna Muchnicki (paintiing) Christine Ramirez (jewelry)

Demonstrations/Performances:

1:00pm Hot Glass Demonstration with Wendy Blevins

3:00-3:30pm Free Hoop Dancing lesson with Rachel Lancaster

3:45pm Hoop Dance performance by Rachel Lancaster

4:00pm Drum Circle with Jim Davidson: Come at 4pm and Jim will provide some hand drumming instruction, followed by holding a drum circle. Jim Davidson is a world percussionist and plays drums of many cultures, usually African style dununba (jun-jun), the big barrel bass drums in a djembe ensemble. He is a student of West African and Middle Eastern percussion and has studied with many masters including Mamady Keita, Famoudou Konate, Menes Yahuda, Quint Lange and Glen Velez. He holds many drum circles locally. www.jembe.com

5:15pm Spencer Blevins (musician): Spencer will be performing with his new project Natraj. Inspired by the legendary Indian-Fusion music of John Mclaughlin and Shakti as well as Jonas Hellborg, Shawn Lane and the Vinayakram brothers, Natraj is a fresh, modernized expansion of the melodic, improvisational, rhytmically driving music of their predecessors. Expect the unexpected and prepare yourself for something you’ve never experienced before.

More to come!

Dedicated to the concept of enlightenment through creative expression, Little Fly Studio is owned and operated by long-time New Hope resident, Wendy Blevins.   Wendy holds degrees in Theater Arts, Radio, Television and Film, with minors in Visual Arts and English.  She has worked extensively with the New Hope-Solebury School District in directing productions for Center Stage Theater Club as well as numerous community events such as Bridge Theater Company’s The Odd Couple over the past 15 years.

The mission of Little Fly Studios Workshops is to provide unique, educational, hands-on art and craft experiences that will expand participants’ knowledge and skills. Workshops are administered by All Arts Connection. Check their website for more details at www.AllArtsConnection.com  Nestled in the artistic community of New Hope, it is another great reason to visit the Bucks County area and take part in the arts! 

Funds raised will support: promotion of this event, Artist stipends and expenses, materials and supplies for the community art project, food, beverages and event execution expenses. 

A full list of artists and event schedule will be available on our websites soon. Check back!

SAVE THE DATE and come on out, June 1 12-8PM 6625 School Rd. New Hope, PA

 

Effecting Positive Change through the Arts

Through this event and our workshops we will strive to effect positive change for individuals and the community by offering alternative and diverse art experiences not currently available in our area.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Please spread the word about our Grand Opening and our Workshops! Visit our websites: www.littleflystudios.com and www.allartsconnection.com . 

Donate food or beverages for the party.  Sweat equity is always appreciated, contact us to see how you can help us get ready!

story:
Introduction

Hello everyone! My name is Zack. I'm 21 years old and a cartoonist at Millersville University in Pensylvannia. The reason I've started this campain is because I am also a transguy, meaning that I feel a physical disconnect between my biological sex and my mental gender. How can you help? It's quite simple! I need whatever funding I can get to allow me to get surgery to remove my female breasts in exchange for a more masculine sculpt. It's a huge endevour, so I can't do it alone!

What We Need & What You Get

Here's how it works:

The series of perks on the side will determine the type of art I can produce for you! I'll list examples of the art you can recieve below. Keep in mind that the content can be of whatever you like, whether that be a character you've created or one that you enjoy. Maybe even a drawing of a family member or pet! It's completely up to you!


IMPORTANT NOTE: All art will be done digitally and sent digitally unless otherwise stated. For contact, please sent your art requests to Zackbvogt@gmail.com

 

Examples:

 

  • Sketches: Loose, quick designs that take approximately 5-10 minutes depending on complexity of the character

 

 

 

  • Line Art Illustration: A more detailed drawing of the character(s) drawn on a white or transparent background

  • "Chibi" Illustration: A small, colored image where the anatomy and proportions are shrunk. They tend to be cuter than usual

 

  • Full Body: A proportional, fully colored/shaded illustration with a splash of color for the background.
  • Full Body + Full Background: A complete illustration with both characters and background interacting with one another.

 

  • What I WILL NOT draw

    - Excessive violence/gore

    - Sexual themes

    Keep in Mind

    - Inorganic/man-made substances are not my strong suit

    - I will need a written description/photo/drawing for reference

 

 

 

Thank you for Reading!

Any little bit counts! I need as much help as I can possibly get, so even just spreading this around is greatly appericiated. If you would like to donate and not recieve a drawing in exchange, please send me an email at Zackbvogt@gmail.com letting me know or leave a comment here.

 

Thank you so much!

story:
HOLES OF A PIECE OF ME: AN INTRODUCTION TO LADY ROSE

          MULTIMEDIA EXPERIENCE FEATURING:

  • SPOKEN WORD
  • DANCE
  • VIDEO
  • BOOK/CD DEBUT AND SIGNING

           SUNDAY, JULY 14TH, 2013

Do you know La Toya A. Hampton, MSW, committed advocate for youth and families, entrepreneur, mild-mannered native Portlander and Oregonian? Or maybe you know Lady Rose, spoken word artist, whose quiet, yet poignant words, share experiences of longing, disappointment, struggle and triumph? Perhap you know one of them, but few know both personalities that embody the soul of this unique being that has chosen be a vessel for change not only through her community work, but also her art.

Up until 2008, La Toya had kept her writings mostly secret with the exception of periodically gifting her pieces to special people whom she felt a special connection. Mostly her written work was kept private or revealed to only a select few, until life-changes prompted her to take a chance and share her personal thoughts and feelings. Her first spoken word performance took place that same year, as well as her, her essay “Sometimes You Are Not Supposed to Pick Up the Pieces” was featured in Concordia University's literary anthology The Promethean. Not long after, La Toya adopted the stage name of Lady Rose as a tribute to her late father Roosevelt.

Since that time, Lady Rose, whose work has been compared to that of Maya Angelou, has made numerous open mics and events as a featured artist in Portland and Los Angeles. She has also expanded upon her artistic experiences, being credited as a contributor to songwriting on published music, as well as contributing her piece, "Brown Knows," to serve as narration for the trailer of the upcoming documentary, Black Girl in Surburbia (www.blackgirlinsuburbia.com).

La Toya also conducts classes and presentations for elementary, middle and high school students, helping them to explore poetry and use writing as a form of expression and self-care, as well as a tool to uncover and share in common interests and struggle.

Lady Rose is now ready for the next challenge in her artistic career, which is bringing her chapbook, Holes of a Piece of Me: An Introduction to Lady Rose, to life on stage in the form of a one-woman multimedia show.

Our goal in order to bring this wonderful show to you is $5,000.

This amount will go toward:

  • Event/Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Show Production
  • Book Publishing
  • CD Production and Recording
  • Marketing, Advertising, Program Printing

The Experience

Those who have had the chance to see Lady Rose frequently have glowing reviews and often ask when her next appearance will be and if she has a book available for purchase.


The $5000 being requested will not only help to produce a one-hour multimedia live experience that includes video, dance, music/singing and of course, Lady Rose's spoken word, but it will also make possible the long-awaited first formally published book and spoken word CD.

Your contribution will no doubt add to what Lady Rose fans already love by amplifying it and taking it another level.

Please see what fellow artists are saying about Lady Rose here: www.ladyrosepdx.net.


Our Gift to You

Expressions and shows of appreciation for your contribution in support of the show range from a mention in our printed program to tickets to the show, Lady Rose materials (post cards, book, CDs) to Producer credits that come with the additional perk of an exclusive invite to the dress rehearsal and talk-back with Lady Rose. There is something for everyone at every level of donation.
 
** Alternative arrangements/incentives can be made for donors who live out of state who give at levels that entitle them to show tickets. **

                       THANKS AND SEE YOU AT THE SHOW!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Holly Ellingwood, 22 years old, female, I'm a freelance artist/illustrator and live in Nova Scotia, Canada. I've been drawing for about 14 years now and my passion is illustration and graphic novels. 
The campaign is about my possibilities of networking with other artists, both freelance and in the professional work field. Meeting new people can help get a small town artist like myself become more recognized and possibly gain more work opportunities.

What I Need & What You Get

Where is the money going? I'll break it down.
$200 is going towards the hotel I would be staying at.
$200 is going towards the gas money to get me to Fredericton.
$55 will be for food, so I can eat while at the convention. It will be for groceries. Don't need any confusion.
$65 for emergency money. In case of a flat tire, car troubles or medical emergency, etc.
$30 will be for the convention badge itself.

If all the funds are not raised, the money will going towards the hotel and gas first.
(Important!! I will not add anything else to the perks. No picture frames or anything else. What you see written, is what you get.)

The perks! You want to know the perks of donating to me!
If you donate $5, your name and facebook page or tumblr blog will get a big shout-out on my facebook page and tumblr blog!
If you donate $15, you get a free print of any size from my print store. (http://hollyeart.storenvy.com/)
If you donate $50, you get an 11"x17" limited edition, Indiegogo campaign only, Fairy-Kei inspired Raver Girl print.
(http://wip-illustrator.tumblr.com/image/8050365...)
If you donate $100, you get a 11"x14" commission! 1 character only with a simple background. Nothing pornographic but willing to draw nudity if requested.

The Impact

The project is important to me in the way that, I want to be able to share amazing and breathtaking artwork with you and the world. Helping me raise money to this convention will help me meet people who can help me better myself as an artist and help create wonderful things that I can share with you.

An important fact about myself is that I have severe anxiety. I have had many problems working jobs at places like department stores and grocery stores. With that said, I'm unable to work in such places without it taking serious affect on my mental health. Currently, I am on medication and seeking help but being a freelance artist means more to me then just creating beautiful pictures. It's a job that I can confidently do, without it having any extreme affects on my health.

With this trip, it will open many doors for me to have a more stable and happy future and create great things for people see.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, since we are all in tough times right now, you can still help!!

You can commission me for art of your own! Take a look at the information right here!
http://wip-illustrator.tumblr.com/post/72090419...

Share this campaign with your friends and family, on your facebook pages and blogs. Any contribution is helping! Even sharing it on your social media websites!

story:
OTHERWISE OCCUPIED | Biennale Arte 2013
Support the only Palestinian Exhibition at the upcoming

Venice Biennale. June 2013.

 


Dear Friends,

            I’m really excited to be presenting a new art piece as part of Otherwise Occupied, the only exhibition dedicated exclusively to Palestinian art at the upcoming 55th Venice Biennale, opening May 29th, 2013. As an “unofficial” exhibition in an event otherwise organized along national pavilions, I am thrilled about this opportunity to showcase Palestinian art at this prestigious and highly visible venue for global art attended by an anticipated number of over 370,000 visitors. I am seeking to raise remaining funds necessary to complete the production of my piece, The Trial, totaling $15,000.

            All funds raised will go directly to cover expenses such as the camera crew, sound man, video editor, etc. I could not do this project without your support. Your donation -- large or small -- will help me bring this project to life.

I hope to see you at the exhibition at the 55 Venice biennale!
http://www.palestineatvenice.com/


Best,
Aissa Deebi

The art project: The Trial
A two-channel installation, HD/DVD 15-minute loop, accompanied by 24 drawings.

This two-channel installation consists of a re-enactment in English of a speech by Daoud Turki, at the Haifa court house in 1973. Where he was a defendant in a military trial. Turki, a Palestinian-Arab citizen of Israel, had been arrested by the Israeli military with four other members of the "Red Front" and charged with espionage and collaboration with the enemy. In his speech, Turki tried to advance an idea against the paranoid Zionist fantasy of conflict toward the larger idea of a socialist class struggle, proclaiming solidarity with "…all workers, peasants and those persecuted in Israeli society." The brilliance of his rhetoric and the fullness of his reasoned arguments, in which he criticizes Zionism for pitting Jews against Arabs, is caught as an address almost from Franz Kafka's The Trial, echo throughout as the tone of an idealist caught in the jaws of the heinous militaristic state.


http://www.indiegogo.com will go live in few days if you are willing to donate please email me regarding your pledge and will get back to you ASAP.

story:
Summary

This project is an art instructor's vision to raise awareness for special needs artists in Southern California and share their incredible work with the world by producing 1000 museum-quality art books to promote them and the programs that support them. Their creative ability is truly something you have to see to believe!

What We Need & What You Get

The goal is to produce 1000 copies of a 400-page museum-quality art book to promote these incredible artists and their work. Due to their marginalized status, intellectually disabled artists are often overlooked despite their talents. A thousand copies of this book will go a long way to help put these artists on the map and get them the recognition they deserve.

The cost of publishing 1000 high-quality books is $30,000 USD. These will be distributed to galleries, museum directors and art industry professionals so the world can see the talents of these marginalized artists.

If we don’t reach our fundraising goal this time around, the funds will be held in an account while we launch a secondary campaign to reach our goal. We are determined to print this book as we are confident in the astounding quality of our artists’ work. We know it will have a huge impact on their visibility.   

We offer great perks for three different levels of contributions!

  • $25 gets you an original 8x10 print of your choice.
  • $100 gets you a copy of the book when it is produced.
  • $1000 gets you a copy of the book when it is produced, as well as one (or more) original pieces of art of your choice, up to a $300 total retail value.

The Impact

For artists living with cerebral palsy, seizure disorder and a range of intellectual disabilities such as autism and down syndrome, increased exposure within the community and the art world means a larger audience to view and purchase their art and help them achieve independence, as well as increased fundraising opportunities for the programs that support them. As artist/mentors working these unique individuals, my colleagues and I need all the help we can get. This book has the potential to bring a huge influx of supporters our way.

Founded in 1968 as a branch of the Exceptional Children’s Foundations (ECF), the Art Centers have mentored hundreds of adult artists living with intellectual disabilities. The mission of the program is to give these gifted individuals a vehicle for personal expression and self-sufficiency by encouraging them to pursue careers in fine art. Throughout the years, the Art Centers have been nationally recognized for the personal and professional progress artists within the program have made.

“My favorite kind of art is fantasy, because you create what you like. I come [to the Art Center] to do a lot of art. The more you develop your drawings it can help you wage down your anger. I don’t really feel anger here [at the Art Center] because I like to get up in the morning and illustrate. This is really good for me.”

- Ray Taix
Downtown Art Center

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute here, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Help us get the word out! Please use the Indiegogo share tools and Tweet about this campaign, share on Facebook, purchase art at www.artecf.org or come to one of our many events in the Los Angeles area.

Please follow @artcentersecf on Twitter, or like us on FB at www.facebook.com/artcentersecf

Thanks for your time! :D

story:
Online Art Space / Amazing Artists / Please Help Us With Our First Exhibition!

Hello, we are Vanja Contemporary, a carefully curated online art space, representing emerging and promising artists from Europe.

Our mission is to expose the artists' works to a wider audience, to help with the development of their portfolios and to support them to get access to curatorial programmes and the art market. We recently launched our website and enjoy already a fast growing following in the arts online communities.

This campaign with your contribution will enable us to go beyond the online space and to exhibit our works in a real gallery space in East London, in the first week of October. This we hope will be a launch pad for both the artists' careers and Vanja Contemporary as an arts platform.

An exhibition in an art capital like London is an important step for artists and galleries who want to break through and get there name out in the art world. Your contribution will help us to do this next step! In return we have amazing prints for you as a Thank You and will also invite you to join us at the private view of our show.

[Image: 'Solitude' by John Pakapoukas]

The Artists

Edurne Aginaga: With her conceptual series Lie Down, Edurne Aginaga has been selected as one of the Top 3 Finalists of the Conceptual Photography category of the prestigious 2013 Sony World Photography Awards. Edurne, originally from Basque Country, lives and works in London.

Philipp Haffner: Philipp is a Berlin-based artist who uses drawing as his main medium to compose mind maps of visual signs, associations and meanings, usually retracing them from his memory.

Stefan Mildenberger: Stefan, based in Hamburg, Germany, captures our media saturated world by scanning audio-visual information from TV and other sources and transforming them into abstract prints.

John Pakapoukas: John is an artist, based in Brighton, UK, whose main tools and materials for his creative process are photography and digital media.

[Image: 'Fence 01' by Stefan Mildenberger]

What We Need & What You Get

Exhibition space in London, framing, insurance and promotion among other exhibition related costs are extremely expensive, and we struggle to pay all costs out of our own pockets. However, being artists, we have an amazing range of small prints to offer as a thank you for your contribution. Images of the different works can be found here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/vanja-contemporary/sets/72157634387533599/

See our list of perks for more details.

 

 [Images: 'Vertigo' 1 and 2 by Phillip Haffner]

The Impact

There are many talented artists who need representation by a gallery in order to be able to show their work to a wider audience. We at Vanja Contemporary are very passionate about the art we are presenting and have great confidence in the success of our artists.

We are looking for donors who share our passion in discovering the new generation of artists and help us in showing their work. This will, in the long term, help artists to produce further new art works and to be included in major international art shows. And who knows, it might even be the starting point for you as an art collector!

Other Ways You Can Help

We can understand that not everyone is able to make a financial contribution. However if you like our project we would be very grateful if you shared the link of this campaign with friends .

Also sharing the link to our website www.vanjacontemporary.com with all your art interested friends would be amazing. We also have a facebook page with regular updates about our artists and activities: www.facebook.com/vanjacontemporary. Twitter: https://twitter.com/Vanja_Contempo

Thank you so much for your support!

[Image: 'Fire' by Edurne Aginaga]

This campaign with your contribution will enable us to go beyond the online space and to exhibit our works in a real gallery space in East London, in the first week of October. This we hope will be a launch pad for both the artists' careers and Vanja Contemporary as an arts platform.
An exhibition in an art capital like London is an important step for artists and galleries who want to break through and get there name out in the art world. Your contribution will help us to do this next step! In return we have amazing prints for you as a Thank You and will also invite you to join us at the private view of our show.
[Image: 'Solitude' by John Pakapoukas]
The Artists
Edurne Aginaga: With her conceptual series Lie Down, Edurne Aginaga has been selected as one of the Top 3 Finalists of the Conceptual Photography category of the prestigious 2013 Sony World Photography Awards. Edurne, originally from Basque Country, lives and works in London.
Philipp Haffner: Philipp is a Berlin-based artist who uses drawing as his main medium to compose mind maps of visual signs, associations and meanings, usually retracing them from his memory.
Stefan Mildenberger: Stefan, based in Hamburg, Germany, captures our media saturated world by scanning audio-visual information from TV and other sources and transforming them into abstract prints.
John Pakapoukas: John is an artist, based in Brighton, UK, whose main tools and materials for his creative process are photography and digital media.

[Image: 'Fence 01' by Stefan Mildenberger]


What We Need & What You Get
Exhibition space in London, framing, insurance and promotion among other exhibition related costs are extremely expensive, and we struggle to pay all costs out of our own pockets. However, being artists, we have an amazing range of small prints to offer as a thank you for your contribution. Images of the different works can be found here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/vanja-contemporary/sets/72157634387533599/
See our list of perks for more details.
 
 [Images: 'Vertigo' 1 and 2 by Phillip Haffner]


The Impact
There are many talented artists who need representation by a gallery in order to be able to show their work to a wider audience. We at Vanja Contemporary are very passionate about the art we are presenting and have great confidence in the success of our artists.
We are looking for donors who share our passion in discovering the new generation of artists and help us in showing their work. This will, in the long term, help artists to produce further new art works and to be included in major international art shows. And who knows, it might even be the starting point for you as an art collector!


Other Ways You Can Help
We can understand that not everyone is able to make a financial contribution. However if you like our project we would be very grateful if you shared the link of this campaign with friends .
Also sharing the link to our website www.vanjacontemporary.com with all your art interested friends would be amazing. We also have a facebook page with regular updates about our artists and activities: www.facebook.com/vanjacontemporary. Twitter: https://twitter.com/Vanja_Contempo
Thank you so much for your support!

[Image: 'Fire' by Edurne Aginaga]

story:
Short Summary

I have been given the opportunity for a residency in Truth or Consequences in New Mexico to make a site Specific animation. I will drive to Truth or Consequences leaving from Philadelphia beginning January 1st and returning on January 14th.

The project I will work on in New Mexico is part of a larger body of work, spanning from Philadelphia, to Richmond Va. The project, as yet unnamed, is part street art, and part meditative animation. In a nut shell, I will take the local landscape an re-interpret it through an animation. This animation will be accesible for all throug Qr codes and the web.

You can see some of my previous work here

belindahaikes.com

This is an opportunity to finally do a project that has lived far too long in my head.

But Gas is expensive. Which is why I need your support. 

What We Need & What You Get

All monies donates will go to the travel costs to New Mexico. Additional funding will be used for art materials.

Plus you get some sweet art! A postcard, a photo or even a personal drawing! 

Impact

Opportunites to make things undisturbed by the demands of everyday life are a rare and beautiful thing. I am lucky to be given this time at Starry Night, but I need help getting there. 

This time will enable me to push my work in a direction it has been wanting to go, but I have not had the unfettered time to bring it fruition. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word. If you want to help in other ways, contact me belhaikes at yahoo dot com.

story:
Short Summary

The Mechanical Nun is a robot dressed as a Nun that listens to confessions of sins and creates an interactive graphical representation, the Sin City map of San Francisco. She offers relief from isolating guilt by demonstrating resoundingly that no sinner is alone. To complement the Nun, a Confession Booth provides a private and immersive sensory experience that reacts to the sinner's confession. 

The Nun and Booth will start their missionary work at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts on November 2nd as part of Project Nunway, a charity fundraiser. The Nun and Booth will also make it to Burning Man, but we don't want to stop there, we want to reach sinners worldwide.  Hence, we're designing an open-source application for broad distribution, to create a searchable library of sins.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $6000 to bring the Mechanical Nun and Confession Booth to Project Nunway at the YBCA, they will stay there during the Distopian Futures exhibition, and make it out to Burning Man. The cost is for the materials of the robot the costume, the Confession Booth and its immersive sensory environment. Everything else is being done by volunteers. 

The Impact

Isolation and loneliness have become epidemics. Once, traditional support systems such as the church provided avenues for relief. As these support systems crumble within modern society, millions of people suffer from self-imposed guilt without community support. The Mechanical Nun is an art project by-the-people, for-the-people, which strives to ease guilt through transparency. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially but still want to help, here are several ways: 

  1. Spread the word - tell your friends about the campaign.
  2. Help us visualize sins anonymously - Fork our repo on GitHub (coming soon).
  3. Help us dress the Mechanical Nun. We need designers to make the Mechanical Nun feel reassuring and 'Nunly.'
  4. Come by to one of our meetups and help us build the booth or design the application.

FAQs

  • What happens if we don't raise the funds? 

The Nun will still be at Project Nunway V but the Confessional Booth will not. Come to the fundraiser to confess your sins and see where your fellow sinners are in San Francisco!

  •  What happens to the Nun after Project Nunway V: 

The Nun and Booth will be at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco until we coordinate future missionary work. Come talk to her at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. 

  • Who decides how our confessions are shared? 

All confessions are anonymous and everyone has access to the text of the confession. You can look at the library of confessions and think of different ways that you would like to look and visualize sins, indulgences and confessions. This is a for-the-people, by-the-people art project

  • What will the Mechanical Nun do?

The Nun surveys sinners for their sins and indulgences, and maps sins geographically by type, creating an aesthetic visual representation of the sins that characterize all of our lives.

  • What will the Confessional Booth do?

The Confessional Booth provides a private and introspective experience with sensory feedback individualized to the confessor's sin.

  • How will data be used?

In addition to mapping sin type and geography, we will be able to catalog and analyze anonymised demographics and characteristics of sinners and their sins, to reveal to the public facts about the behaviors we may find shameful. The application will catalog a library of sins - a searchable stream of people's confessions - to create a living record of our humanity

  • How will anonymity be guaranteed?

No images or personal facts (names, addresses) are collected. We want only the content of your sin.

  • Who are the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence and what is their connection to the project?

The Sisters is a group who's been devoted, through art and performance, to supporting queer causes and marginalized individuals since 1979. Please check out their website at: http://www.thesisters.org/. They were a natural inspiration for our project, and with their blessing, we aim to take it further. We want to take their message of acceptance and bring it forth to everybody.

story:
The First United Methodist Church was chartered in 1906 shortly after the City of Bend was incorporated, however early day Methodist activity is recorded in the area in the late 1800’s. The current church building was constructed in 1920 and sits in what is now the downtown Bend Historic District.  The building is highly visible in the downtown area and serves not only the needs of the congregation but a community in need.   Programs  providing services to anyone on a non-religious basis include regular meals, utility assistance, financial assistance, laundry assistance and sponsors programs for NA, AA, Alanon, SA, OA, boy scouts and girl scouts. The church also hosts the local Jewish congregation.

 

Financial needs were very limited in 1920 and the Bend community, in many cases non Methodists, came together to raise funds for the building. During construction church members selected Povey Brothers Studios located in Portland, Oregon to provide stained glass windows. Povey Brothers, in business from 1888 to 1928, were known for high quality stained glass windows that were called the Tiffany’s of the Northwest.

 

Today, Povey stained glass windows are still considered some of the finest in the country and are known as fantastic works of art. The windows were considered to have extraordinary quality and beauty and are a mark of pride in the Portland area in several historic buildings.

 

Currently the stained glass windows are protected on the exterior by an over forty year old material that is seriously cracked and yellowed. The degraded condition of the protective material is allowing weather elements to endanger the stained glass windows.

 

The preservation project will repair exterior window casework and replace the failing protective material with a new clear high tech material. The clear material will not only protect the windows from the elements but will enhance the outside appearance to the public and preserve these precious pieces of art history.

All dontations to the preservation project are tax deductible.

story:
Foundation Cine A La Calle

(www.cinealacalle.org)


The Foundation Cine A La Calle promotes Films as a tool for social empowerment and public space recovery. We do it through 3 core programmes happening during the whole year:

1. INTERNATIONAL SHORT-FILMS FESTIVAL:

Happening every May every year, the festival is open for short-films from all over the world with an open scope and awarding on different categories: Local Production, National Production, International Production, Best Content for Children, Best Peace-Building Content. 

2. INCLUSIVE FILMS

With technology developed for deaf and blind people, the foundation organizes sessions of appreciation and production of films for these audiences. Our aim is to develop the artistic talent of the participants as well as creating new spaces of expression and bring alternative tools of communication bridging the gap on the social inclusion.

3. COMMUNITARIAL WORKSHOPS

Through film-making workshops, the Foundation foster the potential audiovisual artistic talent of members of low-income communities providing them with audiovisual experts and through which the participants get to gain and strenghthen production tools. The expected outcome is to 


What do we need support with?

Our International Short-Films Festival serves as the frame for launching all our programmes being at the same time the most impacting of our core activities. This year, the festival will take place May 9-17 in several main plazas, parks, cultural centres and schools of Barranquilla, city where we are located at.

Although we have already received financial support from the national and local cultural bodies of the Government, we still need funds for investing in our equipment, human resources, communication materials and means, hosting for our special guests, materials for our workshops, transport, food and general logistic.

Summary of expenditures to be covered:

General Logistic Expenditures: 12349

Travel Costs: 8715 

Food: 2987

Accomodation: 9425

Administrative Expenditures + Taxes: 430

Human Resources: 13500

New equipment (screen, projectors, mobile transporters, etc.): 13687

story:
My name is Veronica Cordova de la Rosa. I have been living in the UK for the last six years and I would like to extend my visa in order to live as a professional artist and cultural entrepreneur. I love the cultural and artistic life in the United Kingdom. Thus, I would  like to design projects where people is involved in the making and delivery of performance art or DIY printing. I would also continue enhancing my experience of living among some of the most appealing and inspiring artist in the world. I would like to continue mapping new possibilities of being among a wonderful multicultural and rich country.

 

This project requires of people supporting artists that contribute to the cultural life of the United Kingdom. Are you one of those?

Are you looking for people passionate about DIY culture?

Are you supportive of social mobility for artists?

Are you interested in supporting artist from other countries?

If so... Please get in touch!

There are some risks and challenges that come with completing my project such as:  

  • getting funding to continue working with art community projects 

  • investing in the local and global art market

  • finding strategies for social mobility for artists despite their background or country of origin.

I would tack this challenges by spending time looking for funding that could give me a space and the sharing of facilities to other artists to present my work and others work. 

I would like to move to different cities within the United Kingdom in order  to get to know other communities and ways of living in the country. 


By not living in the UK as an art student but as a professional artist, I am willing to spend more time in the art of creating, organising and marketing art events.

 

I am currently completing my PhD and I am working with live art and performance artists in Oxford and other parts of Europe.

I have three projects that I organise and promote:

The Live Art and Performance Art Group, Vibrations art journal for Creative Writing and the Museum of Flowers.

story:
My name is John Wilson and I'm an artist. I live in Portland Maine and it's here that my life began to percolate. I imagine like many people struggling to find their place in the world I spent years bouncing from one job to the next. I felt disconnected and mostly unhappy in my work and had the nagging suspicion that my life was slipping away without ever finding something that brought me joy and satisfaction. My life turned a corner when I moved to Maine and plugged into Portland's creative economy. I met professional artists who showed me their work and convinced me that this was a viable path. I began to draw again copying animals out of National Geographic Magazines. And I began to move forward. When a friend suggested I apply to art school I thought "is that allowed?" But, I went ahead and did it and now at 47 I can't imagine doing anything else.  

After getting my BFA I decided to pursue an MFA with the idea that I would one day teach at the high school or college level. On a recent trip to New York I had my portfolio reviewed by an art professor who suggested before I apply to MFA programs that I work more on my figure drawing and painting skills. So after some research I found this summer program in New York that focuses specifically on interpreting the human figure through drawing, painting and clay modeling. I see this as an opportunity to not only sharpen my technical skills but also get the chance to expand my circle of art contacts who may be able to help me gain a better understanding of how the art world works. I'd be so grateful if you felt moved to contribute something. It'd be a contribution to my life as an artist.

The cost of the program is $3,870. This includes tuition and a student dorm room for one month in July. I'm responsible for food, travel and art supplies which my savings will cover. I've already been offered a $500 scholarship and a very generous contribution from a family member. My goal with IndieGoGo is to raise $2,000 by May 15th which is the residency's deadline for payment.

Shortly following the residency I will have a private opening reception at Still Life Studio in Portland, ME where I will show the work I've made and celebrate with all those in the area that have made this possible!

story:
Short Summary

Monster Arts Project is now working on it's fourth year of fantasy and fun! We have over 20 artists on board again this year working in a wide variety of mediums producing amazing artwork around the theme of imaginary creatures/monsters.

As every year we try and produce a multi-sensory experience to blow away our visitors. This year we transport you back in time to another world in which our amazing artist's work resides. Our plan this year may be the most ambitious yet! The gallery will be transformed like never before! With a little help we'll guarantee our vision comes to perfect light! 

Here's a quick example of what our show looked like for Monster Arts Project 3

 

And here is a sneak peek of some of the amazing talent we have on board this year, 23 people bring their interpretation of Monster Arts Project to life!

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds to buy materials to build a specific structure for the gallery. Without giving away too much (we want the opening to be a huge surprise!) we need numerous 2x4s, 4'x8' panels, speciality adhesive papers, various lighting and props to add to the scene, and more. 
All of this comes to about $900-1000

We have plans to make opening night as exciting as years past and some of our funding is needed to help insure our plans go as planned! Within this we also have other plans up our sleeves. This all comes to around $500-600

For your contribution this year we offer wonderful fun monster figurines, greeting cards, stickers, buttons, and more! All perks will be mailed to contributors by the end of November. 

All non-anonymous donors will have their names on a plaque in the gallery!

The Impact

Monster Arts Project has become a beloved part of October in Easthampton and with your help we can insure that our artists continue to be able to be a part of your Easthampton experience! All donations are helpful! Don't worry about how little or how much to donate, Monster Arts Project is an act of love and one that we want to continue for many years to come. By donating to our project you are helping insure an awesome experience for all the visitors to enjoy and an amazing space for all the artists to exhibit. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

If you can't donate please share our campaign far and wide. Our opening night is October 12th from 5-8pm during Easthampton ArtWalk and we hope to see you all there!

And here is a sneak peek of some of the amazing talent we have on board this year, 23 people bring their interpretation of Monster Arts Project to life!


What We Need & What You Get
We need funds to buy materials to build a specific structure for the gallery. Without giving away too much (we want the opening to be a huge surprise!) we need numerous 2x4s, 4'x8' panels, speciality adhesive papers, various lighting and props to add to the scene, and more. All of this comes to about $900-1000We have plans to make opening night as exciting as years past and some of our funding is needed to help insure our plans go as planned! Within this we also have other plans up our sleeves. This all comes to around $500-600For your contribution this year we offer wonderful fun monster figurines, greeting cards, stickers, buttons, and more! All perks will be mailed to contributors by the end of November. All non-anonymous donors will have their names on a plaque in the gallery!


The Impact
Monster Arts Project has become a beloved part of October in Easthampton and with your help we can insure that our artists continue to be able to be a part of your Easthampton experience! All donations are helpful! Don't worry about how little or how much to donate, Monster Arts Project is an act of love and one that we want to continue for many years to come. By donating to our project you are helping insure an awesome experience for all the visitors to enjoy and an amazing space for all the artists to exhibit. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
If you can't donate please share our campaign far and wide. Our opening night is October 12th from 5-8pm during Easthampton ArtWalk and we hope to see you all there!

story:
About the Book

The book is divided into three sections. The first, Political Activist (and Rebel Artist) contains all of my political public art projects from the first half of the 1990s, under the umbrella name THE X-GIRLFRIENDS. It showcases most of my political campaigns, visual commentaries, mail-art projects and outdoor billboards covering various social and political topics at the time, such as freedom of expression, the Gulf War, the Bush administration’s unsuccessful drug policies, separation of church and state, and the Catholic Church’s attitude towards AIDS education, among others. As I was going through the work from this time period, I realized that a lot of the issues featured in this section are unfortunately still topical today, under the current U.S. political climate (and White House administration). It seemed as though we haven’t really moved further at all as a country in the past twenty-five years — the topics are the same and just the name of the players (or politicians) have changed. And if the book has any context today, it is is simply to expose that very dynamic.

This section also includes some of my exhibition work, especially an important “retrospective” installation Linda (out of context) at the University of Illinois at Chicago. In it, along with my collaborator at the time Joanne Pandis, I disrupt, and as a result decontextualize, all of my political public art under THE X-GIRLFRIENDS in order to showcase that it belongs in the public sphere rather than on the walls (or pedestals) of an art gallery. I do this in part by casting the political T-shirts and visual commentaries in synthetic resin and thus making them unwearable (and unreadable). In addition, by creating a maze of crowd control stanchions throughout the entire floor of the gallery, I "manipulate" viewers and take away their choice of the order in which to experience the exhibition. Yes, I was young and rebellious at the time, and very much against any type of institution, including art ones.

The second section, Gender Warrior (and Radical Faerie) contains transitional work, where I turn away from visual public art to writing and performance. Here, I experiment with "gender-fuck" drag and tackle queer-specific issues such as sexism within the gay community, as well as the "Don’t ask, don’t tell" U.S. military policy. My involvement with the Radical Faerie movement, particularly the EuroFaeries, permeates throughout this work and also includes some large-scale ritualistic performances for... yes — non other than art institutions, such as the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago.

The last section is dedicated to my performance art character Malgorzata Romanska, which I developed in Los Angeles in the mid-2000s. The main concept behind this self-made, wealthy art collector and philanthropist is to give financial power to a character who is normally considered an outcast and on the fringes of society. Then through interactive performances track how the public, and more specifically players in the art world, would respond to her. Until 2012, I embodied and lived as Malgorzata Romanska for days at a time, and attended numerous fundraising auctions and art fairs throughout the U.S. and Europe. As her, I bid at those auctions and bought contemporary art at art galleries at the fairs. And hopefully in the process, I was also able to change, even in a small way, people’s perception of what a person with financial power and social clout should be and should look like.

The book contains over 300 images, plus press and archival texts. In it, I tell the stories not only through the main text, but also through various side facts about the projects, thus giving them a more complete context within the political and social milieu of the time. For me, public art and performance can be a dramatic medium that can be employed as a lightning rod for social discourse. And I hope that this personal creative journey informs, intrigues, stirs up thoughts (even if uncomfortable ones), and inspires you, in your own way, to be an active participant in our democracies, both in the United States, as well as worldwide. But most importantly, it encourages you to get out and VOTE!

The official book release date is November 6, 2018 — the day of the crucial mid-term elections in the United States.

BOOK SPECS:

Kulov 90–15: Twenty-Five Years of Political Public Art and Performances will be available in three different versions:
Digital > Each digital version of the book will come in two types of PDFs. One consists of spreads, so it's just like a printed book. And the other is of single pages, which is better to view/read on iPads or other such tablet/mobile devices. $35
Hard Cover > 8 x 10 inches (20 x 25 cm), 100-pound premium matte paper, 122 pages; imagewrap, soft-touch, matte-coated cover. It includes the digital version of the book. $95
Limited Edition > 8 x 10 inches (20 x 25 cm), 100-pound eggshell texture uncoated paper, 122 pages; dark gray linen hard cover with hand-glued image, plus partial dust jacket; signed and numbered in an edition of 12 (plus 3 artist's proofs). It also includes the digital version. $150

 

Why Do I Need Funding?

The printed book is going to be available through on-demand printing, which allows me not to have to front the funds for the printing part of it. But at the same time, this raises up the cost per book tremendously. It also doesn't allow for having a wholesale price, which means that bookstores would not be able to carry it. Therefore, I would have to sell the book on my own and at cost in order to make it affordable for everyone — hence, there will be no profits from the sales. However, a book has many other expenses besides printing, such as editorial and design/production fees, photo retouching, print tests, PR, marketing, and many more. So this crowdfunding campaign would hopefully cover some of those costs. And if I'm able to raise even more than my campaign goal, the funds would be allocated towards a book launch event and even a retrospective exhibition down the line.

RISK AND CHALLENGES
As some of your already know, I've been in a retrospective mood for some time — this is my third such book in just the past four years. So I've done this before, and it would be absolutely no problem for me to complete this book project as well.

 

About the Perks/Rewards

THE BOOKMARK
The Kulov 90–15 Bookmark is under the ART PACIFIST perk, but also under a lot of the other perks in this campaign. Whenever I have full control over the shipping of a perk, I'd be able to send it to you. You can also request to add it to a perk, for which it's not currently listed.

THE BUTTON/BADGE
The Separation of Church & State Button/Badge (1.5 x 1.5 inches > 4 x 4 cm) is under the ART HUMANIST perk. It is not a reprint, but the original from the 1994 campaign — I had saved quite a few for the archive, and there are currently only ten available. This is my last such political public art campaign, which currently appears on pages 38–39 of the Kulov 90–15 book.

THE BOOK
The Kulov 90–15 Book is of course the main perk/reward of this crowdfunding campaign. The digital version of it is under the ART ACTIVIST perk, but also under a lot of the other perks in the campaign. And as I mentioned above, it also comes with the printed versions of the book — the hard cover which is under the ART RADICAL perk, and the limited edition which is under ART ANARCHIST. Check for book specs above.

THE PRINT
The Limited Edition Print (6 x 9 inches > 15 x 23 cm) of the Knowledge Is Power performance art project, 2008–2011, is under the ART WARRIOR perk. It is printed on a 32-point card stock with orange color edges, signed and numbered on the back in an edition of ten. This is actually the same print which is hand-glued to the linen cover of the limited-edition version of the Kulov 90–15 book.

THE BILLBOARD
This mini-reproduction of the One of These Things Is Just Like the Others... Outdoor Billboard (72 x 18 inches  > 178 x 46 cm) is under the ART REVOLUTIONARY perk. It is printed on vinyl with optional grommets, and is signed and numbered on the back in an edition of ten. The original project was produced in 1992 with funding from the National Endowment for the Arts. The actual billboard is 48 x 14 feet (15 x 4 m) and was vandalized ten days into its display at a strategic location in Chicago. The full story is on pages 24–27 of the Kulov 90–15 book.

THE OTHER BOOK
The Kulov 90–00: A Decade of Transformation (6.75 x 8.5 inches > 17 x 22 cm), limited-edition, hand-made artist's book is under the last perk/reward ART SUPERHERO. It was released in 2001 and covers my projects during the 1990s (basically the first two sections of Kulov 90–15). The cover of each book is different and it is numbered and signed in an edition of 12 (plus 3 artist's proofs). It includes vellum, film and other various papers, foldouts, 3-D inserts, a black and white reading version, and white gloves. The edition is sold out, but I have one of the artist's proofs left. This book is part of the artist's book collections of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam.

 

Thank You!

If you've read this far, thank you for your interest and commitment. I would also like to thank you in advance for contributing to this crowdfunding campaign. If you've decided to select a perk/reward, I hope that you've been inspired to embody the name of the perk to which you've contributed. You can also contribute to my efforts without selecting any perks/rewards — just click on the BACK IT magenta button at the very top right, and fill in the amount you'd like to contribute at the top of the pop-up window (above the perks). Either way, don't forget to always misbehave creatively.

story:
Short Summary

Hello, I'm Anthony.  I make art.

It has been my dream to tattoo for my entire adult life.  I don't want this because I want to be the cool guy, or because I want to get rich - It's because I love making people happy with art.

I'm an FTM (Female to Male) transgender person.  One of my goals in tattooing is to be a safe and understanding artist for people in the LGBT spectrum, as well as people with disabilities.

I have an opportunity to learn the craft in a clean, friendly environment with people who are respectful and polite.  I've been asked to raise $1,000 as a down payment on my apprenticeship, and I will pay the rest myself over the next two years as I work and learn in the shop.

What We Need & What You Get

$1,000 will get me started in my training and prove to my teachers that I am dedicated to my studies.  After that, I will arrange a payment plan for the rest which I will pay myself.

Contributors will receive the following:

Donate $10 and receive an 8"x10" print of a piece of my artwork of your choosing.

$25 will get you an 11"x14" of the same.

$50 and I will draw you custom lineart for a tattoo of your own.

$100 and I will design you a tattoo and provide you with line art AND colors to take to a shop of your choosing.

The Impact

There aren't enough openly transgendered tattoo artists and piercists.  There certainly aren't any that I know of in my area - a lot of people could benefit from the comfort and safety of getting inked by a kindred spirit.

I am sensitive to issues endemic to the LGBT and disabled communities such as body dysmorphia, phobia of being touched, and the need to discuss language issues such as pronouns and the names of body parts.

I also want to provide a safe space for anyone who needs a tattoo for spiritual or memorial reasons.  I feel that the experience of getting a tattoo is just as important as the tattoo itself.

Please help me provide this service to those who need it!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this project with your friends!  The wider spread this campaign is, the better chance I have of succeeding!

If you know any other tattoo artists especially, tell them about what my plan is.  See who's sensitive to it and might be interested in helping out.

Pray for me, too, if you do that!  Send me good vibes, keep me in your thoughts!  Thanks!

story:
About me and the exhibit

My name is Margalit Slovin and I have been selected to have a solo exhibition of my photographs at the IMA Gallery in Toronto, Canada.

I recently graduated in May 2013 from Ryerson University with a BFA in Photography. 

The exhibit will be showing my final Thesis project. It includes portraits, still lifes, and architectural interiors that depict the Jewish tradition of ritual purification. You can see more of the project on my website: http://www.margalitslovin.com/mikvah.

Since graduation, I have been working as a photographer at the Israel Museum in Jerusalem. While I love what I do, I barely make enough money to pay my rent... let alone fund an exhibit of 28 photographs. 

I would appreciate your assistance in any funding and publicity of this campaign and exhibit. 

Artist Statement

“A miraculous compound, it is the primary source and vivifying factor of all sustenance and, by extension, all life as we know it...Water has the power to purify: to restore and replenish life to our essential, spiritual selves.” (Slonim)

For centuries, water has been used as an integral part of religious rituals for different faiths throughout the world. These rituals are often performed in the public eye so that many can witness them. However, in the Jewish faith, there is one private ritual for a woman that involves immersion in a special pool of water, called a mikvah. Mikvah literally means ‘a collection’; in this case, a place which has collected a specially prescribed type of water. This water is intended to purify the body before marriage and on a monthly basis for married women. Due to its private nature, ritual immersion is rarely discussed and the physical spaces of these baths have not been exposed to the public.

The mikvah has many layers of significance, connecting generations of Jewish women. I have created a body of work that sheds light on both the traditional and modern beauty of the mikvah. While modern-day mikvahs resemble a miniature swimming pool or hot tub, some of them appear more humble, while others are more opulent. I have photographed eight different mikvahs in the Greater Toronto Area in Canada, underlining the similarities and differences of the spaces.

This photographic project is meant to respectfully offer insight into this private ritual.  The prints are divided into three categories: Tradition, Preparation, and Purification. The first part, Tradition, contains portraits of individual, observant Jewish women. While showing modesty with respect to the subject matter, each woman’s identity is hidden and each covers her hair in some way, according to religious tradition. These portraits have a slight blue cast, signifying the water in the mikvah. In the second portion, Preparation, one can find objects used to prepare for the ritual immersion. The tools rest on silk and are elevated in significance from their typical banality. These photographs are faintly toned red, signifying the impurity before entering the mikvah. Within the last section, Purification, there are various images of the interior spaces of the mikvah. In this part, the photographs depict the mikvah itself as well as, surrounding rooms and details. These images have a minor yellow hue, reminiscent of sepia-toned historic images, emphasizing the continuity of this tradition through the generations.


Funding

All donations received will go directly to cover the costs of printing and framing the images for the exhibit. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please forward this campaign request to anyone that may be interested! And remember to come out to the opening reception on April 3, 2014! The show runs from April 2-26, 2014.

story:
Hello everybody,

My name is Sara, and I am a letterpress printer and Book Arts MFA candidate at The University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa.  I moved here last summer from New Orleans, and I just completed my first year as a graduate student, hooray!

To get a glimpse at my work, please check out my tumblr site: http://southernpestprints.tumblr.com/

This coming summer, I've been accepted along with two classmates to attend the Wells Summer Book Arts Institute as a Teaching Assistant/Intern as well as a workshop student.  This is a huge honor, and I am really looking forward to expanding my book arts community and learning new techniques.  You can see the Wells Program offerings here: http://www.wells.edu/pdfs/book-arts/summer-institute-2014.pdf

As an Intern at Wells, I am not required to pay tuition or lodging fees, which allows me to afford this amazing opportunity.  However, I must take care of my own travel costs and this is where I could use your help.

from Alabama to Aurora

The Institute is held in Aurora, Ny, and flying to Syracuse seems to be the most practical option since I currently do not own a vehicle.

The lowest cost for a round-trip plane ticket to Syracuse is currently $557.  The cost of Amtrak is even higher. 

As a full-time graduate student, this amount is not within my summer budget.

Getting There

Sometimes the most difficult part of a journey is making the first step. 

Living and working at Wells will allow me to gain valuable teaching experience and meet other working book artists, which will strengthen my own abilities and confidence in this field.  I know this will be a fantastic opportunity once I get beyond the financial hurdle of getting there.

Last summer, I was able to attend the Paper and Book Intensive on scholarship, and this event truly changed my life and pushed me to apply for my current graduate program.  I believe that Wells will have a similar effect on its attendees, rejuvenating our passion for what some would call an out-dated craft, that of making books by hand.

Thank you

I know that not everyone has the means to contribute to this campaign, but I really appreciate your taking the time to read this.  Please spread the word if you know others who might be interested!

story:
"The best place to view the Los Angeles of the next millennium is from the ruins of its alternative future."   -Mike Davis on Llano del Rio, City of Quartz, 1990.


What is Squaring the Circle: Llano del Rio?

Squaring the Circle is an interdisciplinary arts exhibition planned for Saturday, May 3rd, 2014 that will feature site-specific installations and performances to mark the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Llano del Rio Cooperative Colony, a utopian socialist community established in 1914 by Job Harriman in Southern California’s Antelope Valley. Like the original Llano community, the event participants reflect diversity in their work as historians, visual artists, filmmakers, writers, choreographers, dancers, musicians, activists, and interdisciplinary practitioners.

We are seeking your help to fund this unique desert collaboration that will feature:

Temporary installations by Jessica Cowley & Lyra Kilston, Michelle Rozic, Karyl Newman, Larissa Nickel, Minna Phillips, and Stacey Spiegel

Performances by LA Art Girls, Olivia de Haulleville, Rachel Finkelstein, Kate Hoffman, Jennifer from JC Penney, Elizabeth Leister, Opera del Espacio, Linda Ravenswood, Semi-Tropic Spiritualists, Leora Wien, and SuarezDanceTheater

Film screenings by Judy Branfman and Mady Schutzman

And historical walking tours lead by Dr. Dydia DeLyser and Paul Greenstein co-author of the book Bread and Hyacinths: The Rise and Fall of Utopian Los Angeles.



Proposed project by the Semi-Tropic Spiritualists


Opera del Espacio responding to the Llano site

What is Llano del Rio?

Llano del Rio was a corporate-run socialist utopian society initiated by Job Harriman following his narrow defeat in a runoff election for the mayor of Los Angeles. The Llano Del Rio Colony planned an alternative vision of cooperation and political equality settling just outside of Los Angeles in the Mojave Desert near Palmdale along Pearblossom Highway 138 in 1914.  After three years of building the colony, internal strife, water disputes, and World War I resulted in the relocation of Llano to a new site in Louisiana called New Llano. The ruins of the original Llano colony remain today 100 years later, as a monument to the history and ideology of the Llano collective. 

What is the budget for the event?

We face distinctive challenges working in a remote desert environment and your support is invaluable to the success of the project. The Llano site has no access to water, power or public facilities. We need to raise funds to cover costs that will sustainably address physical constraints such as transportation to the site, power generation, water, and restroom facilities as well as documentation during the event, and production of a commemorative publication. We have assembled a budget for the Squaring the Circle project and funds will be used as follows:

▫ Van/Transportation
▫ Portable Restroom 
▫ Installation and Power Supplies 
▫ Water 
▫ Performance Program & Maps 
▫ Project Documentation 
▫ Commemorative Publication

How can you help?

We want you to become a shareholder in our Squaring the Circle community. Choose your level of support and help us build a collective vision of Llano del Rio.

    Join the Colony!

In return for your generosity, we are offering unique perks such as:

$15 Comrade: Dear Comrade, we'll mail you a postcard from the Llano Post Office commemorating the 100th anniversary of the founding of the Llano del Rio colony.


$20 Brush Gang: In honor of the internal rebel members who believed that not only the political but also the economic layout of Llano was counter to its socialist ideals, we'll send you a handmade rustic boutonniere made of foraged datura pods to identify you as one of the gang.


$25 Feminist Vanguard: You'll receive a handmade zine created by artist Cindy Rehm honoring Llano's feminist architect, Alice Constance Austin including images from her book, The Next Step; How to Plan for Beauty, Comfort, and Peace with Great Savings Effected by the Reduction of Waste.


$40 Souvenir Club: Exit through the gift shop with your choice of a limited edition t-shirt or a one-of-a-kind Llano felt pennant. Team Llano!


$60 Pearblossom Special: Collect a decorative 100th Llano Anniversary commemorative plate your choice of either Job Harriman or the Llano Silo


$100 A Visionary: Seeking a vision of our alternative past? Don't forget about our Llano collaboration with your copy of our Squaring the Circle catalogue that will document and explore the Llano experience in images and text. (sample image)

$125 Meyer Elkin’s Memory: A single limited edition digital print (choose from Silo, Sunset or Curtains)


$200 Harriman’s Hope: Two limited edition digital prints (choose from Silo, Sunset or Curtains)


$400 Towards Utopia: We're clowning around with a very special private screening of Mady Schutzman’s film, Dear Comrade featuring artisanal cocktails and hosted by Craftswoman House and Hinterculture. 

Even if you can't become a shareholder, please help us spread the word by sharing this campaign with your friends via e-mail, Facebook and Twitter. 

We appreciate all of your support!


Who we are...

Craftswoman House Temporary Residence is a project dedicated to fostering a dialogue on feminist issues through projects and exhibitions. Inspired by collective efforts such as Womanhouse, the project pays homage to the rich legacy of feminist art in Southern California. Temporary Residence partners with artists and organizations to present innovative site-specific works in found domestic and public spaces in and around Los Angeles. http://tempresidence.blogspot.com/

Hinterculture is an arts collaboration that explores the intersections of cultural inquiry and creative potentiality by means of experimental exhibitions. Projects reveal the outlying history, art, technology and business of the desert hinterlands by mining sites for their social, cultural and aesthetic meaning. Documenting hidden and overlooked stories, both natural and manufactured, Hinterculture expands the perception and understanding of art and space—sharing these discoveries and revealing a new public image of the Mojave. www.facebook.com/hinterculture

We hope to you'll join us in Llano on May 3rd, 2014 for our Squaring the Circle: Llano del Rio experience!

story:
Short Summary

I've been painting for about 14 years now, but I didn't go to art school and I've haven't received any real training since high school. I know I have the potential to become an artist that my community can be proud of, and to create beautiful paintings that inspire and delight and add some degree of beauty to the world. HOWEVER, I need more training. 

I've been accepted as a student of Michael Divine's Artist Mentorship Program. Michael Divine is a masterful visionary artist working in California, and he's been a huge inspiration of mine for some time. I believe that studying with him, and receiving the individualized attention his program can offer, is the best and most efficient way for me to learn what I want to learn. 

What I Need and What You Get

For three months of individualized attention from a professional that I deeply respect, I'll be paying $2000. Quite a good deal, really. All donations for this campaign will go towards paying my tuition. 

I'm offering some cool perks for those who donate, such as matted prints of my art. If you've ever thought about getting a print from me, this is a great way to do it. If I don't reach my goal, I'll apply whatever I've raised towards my tuition anyway. Every little bit helps!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, that's totally fine. There are other ways you can help me achieve my goal: 

    • Help me spread the word about this campaign. Share it on Facebook, Twitter, whatever you like!
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
    • Keep enjoying my work and tell your friends about it!

story:
The Project

This is a coloring book. One hundred pages of fairies, in random moments of their lives, all with their wings blank so that you can design their wings the way you think they ought to be designed.

Hi, my name is Eleanor Begley, and I am the illustrator of this project. (I’m also the illustrator of this comic and the owner of this deviantART page, for background’s sake.) The idea of making a coloring book has been bouncing around in my head for ages, ever since I outgrew the simple Garfield coloring books and started to really admire how colors went into other, more intense comic strips. How did the colorists know what to do? Did they all start out with Garfield kicking Odie? Did they shade those? Or were those too simplistic?

In that case, what could I do better? Could I do it at all? And, why fairies?

Seriously, why so many fairies? They’re not even really doing typical fairy stuff, like frolicking with flowers or pestering people. Why fairies? Well, why not? My personal goal for this was to have fun, and drawing one hundred fairies is fun for maybe the first sixty, then you gotta go with some strange pictures.

Yeah, see, this is why this coloring book is for kids AND adults. Super-buff-vain-macho fairy isn’t going to be funny to little kids. This one might:

All of their wings have been left blank. Why? It wasn’t me being lazy. It was me wondering what people would do if given permission to be as creative as they want in a silly setting. It was me thinking that would be fun. That’s all.

What Is Needed

The goal for this project is $600, and that is because printing books is not cheap, nor is shipping them. A small book print run of this coloring book would cost around $450, and the cheapest shipping costs $2.50 for each individual book.

The main goal of this, however, is not just the printing of books: it’s the spreading of fairies. Every reward tier $8 and above gets the PDF, whether or not the goal is reached. With the PDF, you can print off pages of fairies as often as you’d like.

Woo-hoo! Some of the rewards include multiple books, and some of them include artwork by me, like 2.5”x3.5” ACEOs. Here’s an example of one:

Whoa, color! Here’s another one, just for kicks:

By choosing to buy an ACEO, you’ve chosen to get a random and probably very silly card through the mail. For something specific (not to mention bigger), commission options are sprinkled through the reward tiers. Contact me through IndieGoGo or at write2me@gamergnome.com (I know, a very silly address) if you choose this reward tier, although I will probably contact you first. Various size options of original art are on the reward tier descriptions.

Now, what will happen if the goal is not reached? Everybody will get a PDF and any art they bought, of course. The closer we get to the goal, the more likely we can get the book printed. I will keep everybody apprised of the situation. If a tiny print run, just enough to get everybody the book, can be done, then that is what will be done.

Naturally, if the goal is reached, everybody will get what they bought. Woo-hoo!

If the goal is exceeded, stretch goals are in order! Woo-hoo! This is the only stretch goal I can think of for this project:

$1100: One hundred more fairies added, making it a two hundred page coloring book!

Any suggestions made for further stretch goals should that one be exceeded will be deeply appreciated.

What Else You Can Do To Help

Another thing that would be deeply appreciated is networking. Tell your friends! Tell the nursery school! Tell that one person you know who adores fairies (everybody has such a person in their lives)! There are buttons atop this page that allow you to share this campaign via Facebook and such with just a click! Doing that would be a boon.

Thank you for dropping by, and have a wonderful day!
