story:
THE SHOW

"You will be Scarlett O 'Hara". How many people in the world have been told this phrase? Only one: Vivien Leigh. And then? What happened next? You may say: she shot the film, of course. But let’s step back in the middle of time: what happened an hour after the proposal? Two hours after? How did she and how did Larry react to the news? What happens to a couple when one of the two is going to have his big chance? And what kind of “plans” a woman in her private life is forced to abandon to fill a career in the movies?

To be or not to be Scarlett O 'Hara tackles, with imagination, the moment immediately following the Christmas dinner of 1938 at first director-in-charge of Gone With The Wind George Cukor’s house. In the biography by Donald Spoto about Laurence Olivier it’s told that, while dining, Cukor took Vivien apart and announced she had been chosen for the role and then everyone was happy for her "except, maybe, Larry". In this single act we meet the two famous actors after dinner in their hotel room dealing with the crisis that a precious chance such as interpreting the eternal role of Scarlett produces on a pair. Just when the couple seems to find a balance, an unforeseen trouble comes out.

Man, as male individual, still struggles to accept women’s success. It is not a problem of times but rather cultural. As the Hollywood industry passed on feelings like a steamroller, so today the craving for self-affirmation, economic stability and success is threatening lovers’ peace. And actually, as in this comedy, it is the job’s world, with its strict and cold rules, to make decisions for us. "To be or not to be" was Hamlet's torment. Vivien’s. Or anybody’s.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

This is a self funded production and we have been able to cover the initial costs thus far but we need your help! 

As you can imagine the costs of putting on a theatre production are high, and your generous contribution to this play will help directly towards paying our ACTORS, the THEATRE HIRE, REHEARSAL SPACE, SET, BUILD and PROPS.

The amount we are looking to raise is the minimum required to put this play on the stage in front of an audience. However, with greater contributions we will hope to take this play further a field. 

This is not a vanity project for us, we are passionate about the subject matter and want to take this play as far as we can to encourage discussion around the love, and passion. The more funds we raise, the further we can take and spread our message. Whether you want to donate a 'High Five', or pledge to have the production come to you, we hope you'll find a donation level that will suit your pocket. Check out the pledges on offer, and feel free to get in touch if you have any questions. 

THANK YOU!

The Night Express Live Team :)

 

Supporting the show

Collaboration and friendship are brilliant engines. So far, they’ve powered over eleven years of musical making. And now that we have our show ready for next APRIL 2017, with our budget and investments in place, we’re hoping for a little more horsepower. That’s why we’re here. .

So, please, if you can, help us raise our final £5000. Of course, you can also support our show with a ticket or two for the show when it premieres in APRIL. You can pop along to see our rehearsals.

However you choose to support us, we thank you. For helping new theatre Company find a space in the UK. But also for helping to water our acorn.

 

Risks & Challenges

Even small shows are expensive. There’s the hiring of spaces. The designing. The bringing to life of said designs. The printing. The PR. And then there’s the people … the amazing talent helping us to realise the dream …

The great news is we have an amazing team to support us. From our director Raffaele Cericola to the team . The Company is leading the way in fair pay on the fringe. It’s a cause we completely support. Any money you can give will be helping to pay for the hard work of talented professionals who aren’t always so financially supported by their industry.

What is the money NOT paying for? Well, it’s not paying for the writers. In fact, we’re investing in the show ourselves. We believe in the benefits of our hard work and midnight oil. We want all our own seconds and pennies to keep flooding our future. We have faith in this educational experience called ‘putting on a show’. We don’t think the budget should be funding our university, no matter how wonderful it is. And if we raise more than our minimum? All money raised will go directly into the show. We’ll let you know how through our regular updates.

To be or not to be Scarlett O 'Hara tackles, with imagination, the moment immediately following the Christmas dinner of 1938 at first director-in-charge of Gone With The Wind George Cukor’s house. In the biography by Donald Spoto about Laurence Olivier it’s told that, while dining, Cukor took Vivien apart and announced she had been chosen for the role and then everyone was happy for her "except, maybe, Larry". In this single act we meet the two famous actors after dinner in their hotel room dealing with the crisis that a precious chance such as interpreting the eternal role of Scarlett produces on a pair. Just when the couple seems to find a balance, an unforeseen trouble comes out.
Man, as male individual, still struggles to accept women’s success. It is not a problem of times but rather cultural. As the Hollywood industry passed on feelings like a steamroller, so today the craving for self-affirmation, economic stability and success is threatening lovers’ peace. And actually, as in this comedy, it is the job’s world, with its strict and cold rules, to make decisions for us. "To be or not to be" was Hamlet's torment. Vivien’s. Or anybody’s.
 
HOW YOU CAN HELP
This is a self funded production and we have been able to cover the initial costs thus far but we need your help! 
As you can imagine the costs of putting on a theatre production are high, and your generous contribution to this play will help directly towards paying our ACTORS, the THEATRE HIRE, REHEARSAL SPACE, SET, BUILD and PROPS.
The amount we are looking to raise is the minimum required to put this play on the stage in front of an audience. However, with greater contributions we will hope to take this play further a field. 
This is not a vanity project for us, we are passionate about the subject matter and want to take this play as far as we can to encourage discussion around the love, and passion. The more funds we raise, the further we can take and spread our message. Whether you want to donate a 'High Five', or pledge to have the production come to you, we hope you'll find a donation level that will suit your pocket. Check out the pledges on offer, and feel free to get in touch if you have any questions. 
THANK YOU!
The Night Express Live Team :)
 
Supporting the show
Collaboration and friendship are brilliant engines. So far, they’ve powered over eleven years of musical making. And now that we have our show ready for next APRIL 2017, with our budget and investments in place, we’re hoping for a little more horsepower. That’s why we’re here. .
So, please, if you can, help us raise our final £5000. Of course, you can also support our show with a ticket or two for the show when it premieres in APRIL. You can pop along to see our rehearsals.
However you choose to support us, we thank you. For helping new theatre Company find a space in the UK. But also for helping to water our acorn.
 
Risks & Challenges
Even small shows are expensive. There’s the hiring of spaces. The designing. The bringing to life of said designs. The printing. The PR. And then there’s the people … the amazing talent helping us to realise the dream …
The great news is we have an amazing team to support us. From our director Raffaele Cericola to the team . The Company is leading the way in fair pay on the fringe. It’s a cause we completely support. Any money you can give will be helping to pay for the hard work of talented professionals who aren’t always so financially supported by their industry.
What is the money NOT paying for? Well, it’s not paying for the writers. In fact, we’re investing in the show ourselves. We believe in the benefits of our hard work and midnight oil. We want all our own seconds and pennies to keep flooding our future. We have faith in this educational experience called ‘putting on a show’. We don’t think the budget should be funding our university, no matter how wonderful it is. And if we raise more than our minimum? All money raised will go directly into the show. We’ll let you know how through our regular updates.

story:
About the Brass Ring Project

This lengthy overview of contemporary blockbuster cinema  began during my study at the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design, nearly ten years ago, picked up momentum during my (brief) study at Saint Andrews, and has continued to its present state: some 700 pages (depending on formatting), and over 600 footnotes. Now that it's finished, I'm extending this new call for support to get it published, in both print and e-book formats.

The book explores cinema's recent transition from analog to digital formats – and the resulting changes to film viewing, production, and interactivity – using the modern movie blockbuster (e.g., James Cameron's Titanic, George Lucas's Star Wars), as well as the video "remix" and "fan-edit," as signal illustrations of these changes. A number of significant releases from earlier eras (e.g., Hitchcock's Vertigo, Chaplin's The Gold Rush) are also examined, making the study, in part, an attempt to assess mainstream cinema's trajectory and current state, in terms of form, genre, and presence in the lives of consumers. Another key element of the project is the digital "revision" of Jacques Tourneur's Night of the Demon (1957) and Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings films (2001-2003), using formalist principles of continuity, economy, and balance, á la classical Hollywood. The purpose of these ancillary video projects, done in tandem with the book's writing, has been to better understand and define certain box-office driven, aesthetically blinkered shifts in film narrative and technology of the past several decades; or, more simply, to clarify how contemporary cinema's commercial pressures take cultural form, in feature film product. 

Why Focus on the Blockbuster?

If the study is broad enough to consider "cinema's trajectory," why should it focus on the modern blockbuster, as opposed to major movie hits of the past (e.g., Gone with the Wind)? 

I've chosen this particular variety of Hollywood product because it so effectively represents – as well as precipitating – recent, profound changes in the way films are made and regarded. The blockbuster is also a useful gauge of cultural tastes generally, because it exerts a tremendous pull on the consumer at large, whether offered in music, print, or film formats. The emergence of a hit-defying, abundantly diversified digital marketplace, matching unique, individual taste with unique, small-scale titles, has so far been proven false by the market-share for music downloads and video rentals/purchases (as shown by Anita Elberse).  Despite the Internet’s broadened range of merchants and media, the most active consumers are still guided by a sweet tooth for trend and bestsellers – i.e., what others appear to be buying – gravitating toward stars and major releases to define their cultural diet, and culture itself.  

What I Need to Self-Publish

The process of design, layout, review, printing, and marketing for publication (through Minneapolis' Mill City Press), will cost $7,581

This total reflects basic registration, formatting, and production of the book ($1,200), the enormity of the text (an additional $2500), manuscript evaluation ($600), front and back covers ($750), photography fees ($500), enhanced formatting for tables and illustrations ($200), copyright registration ($50), print-on-demand distribution and returns management ($600), exposure on Amazon.com ($500), a bookstore selling sheet w/meta-data on the publication ($100), and an independent review from Kirkus ($575)

Why is the goal of this campaign only $1,100?

Because of the initial campaign, and support from an outside (as yet anonymous) donor, the amount needed has fallen precipitously! 

 

The Project's Impact

Thus far, no film reception study or work of film criticism has taken the practical, studio-based approach that this project has, in which the filmic material examined is variously dismantled and rebuilt (editorially), revealing latent strengths and significations of form. For its demonstration of a unique mode of film analysis – using exceptionally popular titles as subject matter – the potential influence and appeal of the project is considerable. Moreover, despite growing scholarship on fan culture, and a surge in user-altered commercial content (e.g., songs, films, literature, television programs and characters) concurrent with the proliferation of digital media, there has been no comprehensive study of how such content can be re-worked, by consumers, for mass consumption. The reasons for this concern various restrictions of market and venue. Popular sites like Vimeo and Youtube guard against remixed commercial content that isn't sufficiently "transformed" by the consumer-editor, and for good reason. No major record label or film studio wants their property modified and resold by consumers (particularly if the property is made more appealing than its release version), and even if the altered material is distributed for free, its public consumption naturally cuts into artist royalties and producer revenue.

But what of the remixer/re-editor who distributes material for altruistic – e.g., artistic – reasons? The question of piracy becomes murky when education and aesthetics is brought into play, as a motivating cause and purpose of revised material; as seen, for example, in Mike J. Nichols's The Phantom Edit, and Christian Marclay's The Clock (neither of which have incurred legal penalties for their use of protected source material). If such celebrated works become more common – as seems possible, if not likely – how might they affect concepts of authorship, ownership, criticism, and industry power? Though copyrighted material tends to be remixed or re-edited for individual rather than public use, is it possible to develop a new regard for the moving image, a regard both critical and creative, that favors social and communal reception of cultural products? Might visual culture benefit from a more considered film consumption, by viewers who not only possess the tools to produce and alter content, but who can also employ a relevant, relatable aesthetic – an aesthetic born of their capacity for fragmenting, replaying, and manipulating commercial material?

When people have asked me who this book is written for, I describe a digitally-fluent consumer of popular culture, preferably with a basic knowledge of film terms (e.g., "dissolve," "fade-out," "close-up"), who also moonlights – at least occasionally – as a cultural producer. Few young readers would escape this description, yet when I consider the cultural and technological fluency of my students (most of whom are in their twenties), I'm surprised by how rare the critical eye is. Preferences and aversions are readily expressed, but most are at a loss to explain the mechanics of their visual pleasure, distaste, and so forth. For so many fellow consumers I speak to, in and beyond the classroom, it's as if a dividing blade has been dropped, by the binary "rotten"/"fresh," "like"/"dislike" structuring of digital life. If the ease of image-making, access, and manipulation has produced too many options relative to one's capacity to discern, decipher, or communicate through moving images, then a pause for reflection seems in order. We might then reconsider some of cinema's most effective and problematic output, not through an endlessly discursive analysis of possible significations and personal tastes, but through a more neutral  examination of the basic elements of form and style. At this stage in the evolution of motion picture narrative, a formalist lens may be the most useful to consumers, for their creative as well as critical capacities. My hope for Brass Ring is that it offers not only theoretical grist for students of film, or mere critique of a handful of influential blockbusters, but a practical guide for moviegoers generally – a path forward for feature film making and appreciation in the Digital Age. 

 

Five Excerpts from Brass Ring

Chapter excerpt: The Latest Marvel (on the superhero film)

... "The trend in taste and product ramps ever upward in visuality, aurality, and often tone (e.g., from whimsical to peremptory). At least stylistically, the unfortunate formal consequences of this shift can be seen in Frank Miller’s monstrous noir-fantasy The Spirit (2008), an abysmally dark, perversely over-produced translation of more playful, colorful source material (Will Eisner’s titular newspaper strip [1940-1952]). To be clear, the failing of Miller’s film is not in its pictorial or thematic “darkness” so much as its desperately playful accenting,  when the ludic nature of the original strip – a combination of fluid artwork, pulp surrealism, and parodic undercurrent – could scarcely translate to big budget, live-action form; the cost of such grandly-scaled artifice is simply too great for so light a spirit, and the guiltless delight its expression elicits. Though more palatable, Luc Besson’s equally “playful” live-action fantasy The Adventures of Adèle Blanc-Sec (2010) reflects the same delusion of contemporary digital cinema, spending an estimated twenty-five million euros to reify – without improving on or capturing the sprightly intrigue of – its comic book source. (Note that Jean-Pierre Jeunet’s cartoonish action comedy Micmacs a tire-larigot, released six months earlier and produced for about the same amount, suffers no such withering comparison. The soufflé holds. Despite its obvious nostalgia and epic, action-fantasy form, it appears freshly conceived and executed, in part because its digital identity is restricted to color grading and background work, but also because its somewhat anachronistic, slapstick action is leveraged with immediate, real-world concerns; in particular arms manufacturers and the consequences of their products’ global distribution.) This doesn’t mean form can’t overcome material strictures, but the shadow of economics can lie heavily on the act and object of art. The litheness of a bird in flight may be captured in stone, as Brancusi demonstrated with L’Oiseau dans l’espace, but append a $27 million purchase price and the work is made to bear an almost supernatural weight. The blockbuster production that “puts its money on the screen,” as Miller’s The Spirit does to such clear and distasteful effect, bears an even greater burden in its effort to take flight and justify its evident expense." ...

 

Chapter excerpt: Dreaming of a Creative Spectatorship (on Méliès and Scorsese's Hugo)

... "From the earliest projections of the Lumières and the Lathams, to the most advanced practical effects work of Industrial Light and Magic, cinema has demonstrated a profound and spectacular connection with the world outside that of cinematic illusion, as it appears on screen in purely visual form. In her formal analysis of Hugo’s use of stereoscopic space, Purse reveals the nuanced visual sensibility Scorsese brings to the production, distinguishing it from so many major releases conceived and shot in digital 3D. What this thoughtful reading seems to avoid is the film’s overwhelmingly visual character and excessively tight choreography, suggesting an overwound watch; every element of the narrative is graphically represented, unambiguously, and these elements – including the illusion of spatial depth (an “articulation of cinematic space” only in the crudest sense) – are very often computer-generated. The precisely controlled, virtualized figure and/or setting may function as a neutral tool of art, but where the virtual mise en scène prevails in the live-action context, the non-virtual is slighted. To claim that the city or open ocean as reflected in the eye of the camera is no more valuable to cinema than its digital substitute – and perhaps less so for its restive nature – is another form of slight. The same applies to film fantasy when grounded in the live. Seeing Jean Marais’s beast, cocooned in make-up with only his eyes exposed,  one might argue that the weight of the character/creature’s gaze, playing between the who and the what, is simply an artful trick of the medium; a surreal effect of masking, amplified and forced to evolve by the close-up. But there can be no question a living actor moved beneath each strand of fur and thread of costuming – that their eyes once shone before the lens (and no less the eyes of Marais, who suffered the elaborate prosthetics, embodied beauty and beast, and initially suggested the adaptation to Cocteau). Even in the busier, more extreme féerieabstractions of Méliès, the same grounding is evident, and it wasn’t placed there out of fealty to classical theater or the veristic. Though the popular image of Méliès has gained a certain luster and originary status by his place in film history, his goals were chiefly amusement and fantasy spectacle. Whatever realism exists in Méliès’s work exists as a characteristic of live-action production – of practical and quite mundane means – but also because his scenarios were recorded on 

photochemical emulsion, with occasional in-camera effects – effects that relied on the profilmic. As an illusionist of the stage and screen he had no obligation to or particular interest in film’s full mimetic capacities, outside its improvement of the live magic act and suggestion of fantastic persons, creatures, and locales (e.g., the Sun, Moon, hell, the North Pole) – again, primarily as astonishing sights, not as autonomous subjects that existed outside the picture plane, or grew past this visual stricture through artistic maturation (as in the work of contemporary Louis Feuillade)." ...

 

Chapter excerpt: Bigness as Disaster (on filmic excess and amendment)

..."Critically viewing a disaster-romance on the order of Titanic – in which excess defines the picture – or Michael Cimino’s infamously outsized Heaven’s Gate (1980), or the sometimes meandering Nashville (d. Robert Altman, 1972) – in which the drawling pace is largely the point – there may in certain passages be a desire for trimming, but no clear sense of how much. Taking a hand in a feature by attempting to amend it, by digital means, the critical enterprise can assume a finer, more formal dimension, allowing one to better understand what material disserves the film, and how much of it to excise. One may also find that no cutting, however deep or fine, will improve Cameron’s Titanic or Cimino’s Heaven’s Gate. In other titles considered for revision, technical and/or aesthetic problems encountered in certain key shots, lines of dialogue, effects work and so on must be allowed their unfortunate influence, for removing such blemishes would in some cases seriously injure or kill the organism of the film, calling to mind the figure of Georgiana (in Hawthorne’s “The Birth-Mark”), whose husband chemically dissolves a hand-shaped birthmark on her cheek, only to watch her die as the mark fades. Complicating matters, the aesthetic dilemmas and obstacles that face the consumer-revised film are often exterior to the works themselves (apart from the perennial problem of tunnel vision in revisions conducted by a single 

editor).Thinning a largely unnecessary forty-minute lead-up to Skull Island in Peter Jackson’s King Kong (2005) seems a sensible choice, and would resolve at least some of the project’s indulgent character – assuming this is desirable, and the film’s role as document of mounting hubris is set aside – but the victory of improvement by streamlining would still be diminished by the presence of a more economical, agile treatment of the same material in the 1933 version. The original, potentially originary nature of other, less celebrated titles suggests a stronger cause for reform. For example, elimination of the monster visuals in Night of the Demon (d. Jacques Tourneur, 1957) not only produces a deeper, more disturbing impression of the supernatural, the absence of the controversial shots – which are fairly easily excised without affect to flow – brings the viewer closer to the cast and crew’s best artistic intentions." ... 

 

Chapter excerpt: The Source's Apprentice (on Marclay's The Clock)

... "The Clock’s often marvelous, unexpected flow is due to careful use of split edits at almost every turn, while visual and conceptual motifs also serve to unify the disparate source material. Clip length varies greatly, but tends toward staccato cutting at the top of each hour – noon and midnight being among the most spectacular (and best attended). I expected the piece to require an elaborate playback system with multiple synched hard drives, but as Marclay explained to me on the closing night of one museum engagement, “I actually managed to fit the whole thing on a Mac mini, but the new one, the one without any moving parts.”  The solid state drive and player suggests one of The Clock’s most alluring aspects: the miraculous capacity to contain what appears to be – at least at first glance – a clock-themed survey of the whole of cinema, using current PC technology and an elegantly simple, exacting, yet profoundly inclusive editing formula. It should be noted, however, that few museum-goers are likely to devote more than a few hours to the piece; fewer still its full cycle. The impression of a “profoundly inclusive,” 

distilling view of film history’s most literal treatments of time seems inevitable, but the less time one actually spends with The Clock, the better one’s chances of maintaining this impression; there’s always room for the missing element when only a portion of an artwork is seen." ... 

 

Chapter excerpt: The Crowded Exit (on the conclusion of Jackson's 'Rings trilogy)

... "The concluding scenes of The Return of the King are the most crucial in the saga, as they bear the greatest burden of justification for the viewer devoting over seven hours to it. Minutes have been spent well and frivolously until now, with less successful material passing largely without penalty – in the form of impatience – due to the overall quality of the production. This stage of the film is different. Its various settings and exchanges signify not only completion but summation, so anymisstep falls with greater weight, leaving a deeper, fresher imprint before the threshold of memory, the principal residence of every adult viewer. The error of ending at Sam’s home, with its presumptive curtain call and homiletic postlude, is that it is treated merely as a colorful, true-to-Tolkien exit, sealed with an antique end title, when it is in truth an entrance and lens through which we access the preceding film. A sense of obligation to the letter of the source should not now – if ever – force the hand of the filmmaker. Yet this is precisely what has happened, and unless its view is likewise obscured by a dominating image of the text, the general audience must pay the price for the adherent’s pleasure of recognition. " ...

Even in the busier, more extreme féerieabstractions of Méliès, the same grounding is evident, and it wasn’t placed there out of fealty to classical theater or the veristic. Though the popular image of Méliès has gained a certain luster and originary status by his place in film history, his goals were chiefly amusement and fantasy spectacle. Whatever realism exists in Méliès’s work exists as a characteristic of live-action production – of practical and quite mundane means – but also because his scenarios were recorded on 
photochemical emulsion, with occasional in-camera effects – effects that relied on the profilmic. As an illusionist of the stage and screen he had no obligation to or particular interest in film’s full mimetic capacities, outside its improvement of the live magic act and suggestion of fantastic persons, creatures, and locales (e.g., the Sun, Moon, hell, the North Pole) – again, primarily as astonishing sights, not as autonomous subjects that existed outside the picture plane, or grew past this visual stricture through artistic maturation (as in the work of contemporary Louis Feuillade)." ...
 
Chapter excerpt: Bigness as Disaster (on filmic excess and amendment)
..."Critically viewing a disaster-romance on the order of Titanic – in which excess defines the picture – or Michael Cimino’s infamously outsized Heaven’s Gate (1980), or the sometimes meandering Nashville (d. Robert Altman, 1972) – in which the drawling pace is largely the point – there may in certain passages be a desire for trimming, but no clear sense of how much. Taking a hand in a feature by attempting to amend it, by digital means, the critical enterprise can assume a finer, more formal dimension, allowing one to better understand what material disserves the film, and how much of it to excise. One may also find that no cutting, however deep or fine, will improve Cameron’s Titanic or Cimino’s Heaven’s Gate. In other titles considered for revision, technical and/or aesthetic problems encountered in certain key shots, lines of dialogue, effects work and so on must be allowed their unfortunate influence, for removing such blemishes would in some cases seriously injure or kill the organism of the film, calling to mind the figure of Georgiana (in Hawthorne’s “The Birth-Mark”), whose husband chemically dissolves a hand-shaped birthmark on her cheek, only to watch her die as the mark fades. Complicating matters, the aesthetic dilemmas and obstacles that face the consumer-revised film are often exterior to the works themselves (apart from the perennial problem of tunnel vision in revisions conducted by a single 
editor).Thinning a largely unnecessary forty-minute lead-up to Skull Island in Peter Jackson’s King Kong (2005) seems a sensible choice, and would resolve at least some of the project’s indulgent character – assuming this is desirable, and the film’s role as document of mounting hubris is set aside – but the victory of improvement by streamlining would still be diminished by the presence of a more economical, agile treatment of the same material in the 1933 version. The original, potentially originary nature of other, less celebrated titles suggests a stronger cause for reform. For example, elimination of the monster visuals in Night of the Demon (d. Jacques Tourneur, 1957) not only produces a deeper, more disturbing impression of the supernatural, the absence of the controversial shots – which are fairly easily excised without affect to flow – brings the viewer closer to the cast and crew’s best artistic intentions." ... 
 
Chapter excerpt: The Source's Apprentice (on Marclay's The Clock)
... "The Clock’s often marvelous, unexpected flow is due to careful use of split edits at almost every turn, while visual and conceptual motifs also serve to unify the disparate source material. Clip length varies greatly, but tends toward staccato cutting at the top of each hour – noon and midnight being among the most spectacular (and best attended). I expected the piece to require an elaborate playback system with multiple synched hard drives, but as Marclay explained to me on the closing night of one museum engagement, “I actually managed to fit the whole thing on a Mac mini, but the new one, the one without any moving parts.”  The solid state drive and player suggests one of The Clock’s most alluring aspects: the miraculous capacity to contain what appears to be – at least at first glance – a clock-themed survey of the whole of cinema, using current PC technology and an elegantly simple, exacting, yet profoundly inclusive editing formula. It should be noted, however, that few museum-goers are likely to devote more than a few hours to the piece; fewer still its full cycle. The impression of a “profoundly inclusive,” 
distilling view of film history’s most literal treatments of time seems inevitable, but the less time one actually spends with The Clock, the better one’s chances of maintaining this impression; there’s always room for the missing element when only a portion of an artwork is seen." ... 
 
Chapter excerpt: The Crowded Exit (on the conclusion of Jackson's 'Rings trilogy)
... "The concluding scenes of The Return of the King are the most crucial in the saga, as they bear the greatest burden of justification for the viewer devoting over seven hours to it. Minutes have been spent well and frivolously until now, with less successful material passing largely without penalty – in the form of impatience – due to the overall quality of the production. This stage of the film is different. Its various settings and exchanges signify not only completion but summation, so anymisstep falls with greater weight, leaving a deeper, fresher imprint before the threshold of memory, the principal residence of every adult viewer. The error of ending at Sam’s home, with its presumptive curtain call and homiletic postlude, is that it is treated merely as a colorful, true-to-Tolkien exit, sealed with an antique end title, when it is in truth an entrance and lens through which we access the preceding film. A sense of obligation to the letter of the source should not now – if ever – force the hand of the filmmaker. Yet this is precisely what has happened, and unless its view is likewise obscured by a dominating image of the text, the general audience must pay the price for the adherent’s pleasure of recognition. " ...

story:
Short Summary
Hello my name is Zac Bender, I am an artist and here is my story:

I was sitting in a clinic with my father as he started his bone marrow transplant. I was there beside him and wondering and worrying about so many things. I felt overwhelmed by it all. Then I looked at him he saw my worry, it made him worry even more. I decided then that I would make sure to try to raise his spirits. I started drawing something that seemed equal parts ridiculous and fun and for the most part it worked he would crack a smile here and there as I showed him progress on the piece. I was ecstatic that in a situation where I felt helpless I could actually have a impact.

I saw in this sketchbook had 50 pages then a light bulb came on. I knew we would be going through the treatments for up to 6 weeks so I figured why not try to keep his spirits up one day at a time. I decided to do one sketch a day. Drawing from my memories of friends, family, and situations, each sketch i tried to leave a piece of me in them. Before I knew it the 50 days were up. I wish I could say that is where the story had a happy ending and everything was rainbows but sadly this is not the case.

Soon after, my mother found out that she in fact needed a kidney and that the medical costs would be astronomical. We were discussing various avenues to raise money for the surgery and that’s when it hit me — I could compile the manimal sketches into an art book and sell them to raise money for the cause. She always supported me and pushed me even when she was working three jobs and going to college. She has always been there for me. I can’t idly sit and watch her suffer. 

I discussed the idea with some colleagues and performed a bit of market research. The results were so promising that I decided to create a crowdfunding campaign for the project, and here we are!


So then I decided to create a Indiegogo $3500 using the art prints, original art, books, and other ideas as the rewards. I want to donate all the money I make from the kick starter and the art show to her kidney fund. I was hoping you would be able to help me by  backing Project Manimals!

  • The funds will be used to print the book and the prints 
  • The profit will be used to fund my mother's kidney fund

If the project gets funded it would mean a ray of hope for my family and especially my mother. If we exceed the goal then we will be closer to completely funding the transplant which will cost $35,000

 Let me level with you guys. This is my mother, the one who raised me while working 2 and sometimes 3 jobs at a time because that is what she needed to do. Now I need your guys help. I am selling my art that she supported in my childhood and now as an adult i hope to support her with it.

  • The materials for her dialysis is very costly
  • The surgery itself is astronomically expensive.
  • The medicine afterward is not cheap.


I don't foresee any challenges or risks due to the fact i have done my research and made sure to cover not only the printing and binding of the books but also the shipping.

  • The art is already complete
  • The book is already designed
  • I am just waiting for your help

I understand that not everyone can help by donating but everyone can:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about Project Manimals!
  • Share, like, post, tweet, tell your dog so he can tell other dogs!

I understand that not everyone can help by donating but everyone can:  Please get the word out and make some noise about Project Manimals! Share, like, post, tweet, tell your dog so he can tell other dogs!

story:
Our Vision - Fresh Art & Mobile Art Gallery

  • The Mobile Art Gallery is a surprising and delightful way to experience art of all kinds in the St. Croix Valley.
  • Connecting art with nature is another focus for ArtReach. We love to create artful ways to interact with the landscapes and waterways of the St. Croix Valley.
  • The Mobile Art Gallery will bring art to state parks, nature areas, rivertowns, community events and other places around Valley. 

  • With your help, we will build the most efficient and effective structure for our exhibiting artists, performers, and volunteers.

Uses of the Mobile Art Gallery

Architect Anna Koosmann of Afton is contributing her expertise to design a Mobile Art Gallery that will fit three uses. We imagine a pull-behind trailer that will:
1) be a roaming art gallery,
2) host a "Fresh Art" roadside stand (not unlike a produce stand), and
3) provide a venue for pop-up performances.
This transformational space makes it possible for ArtReach to serve multiple disciplines and many audiences.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is to raise $5,000 to match the amount we have already secured in grants from the St. Croix Valley Foundation and MidWestOne Bank. 
  • Additionally, a grant from the Metropolitan Regional Arts Council will be used for first pop-up performances in September 2016.
  • ArtReach will be sure to give all donors updates on the progress and plans for the Mobile Art Gallery.
  • The funds that we raise for this project will be used to pay for the materials and building of the Mobile Art Gallery.
  • Supporters of our crowd fundraising will be invited to a special champagne toast to launch the Mobile Art Gallery - we may even sacrifice a bottle of champagne in celebration.

The Impact

ArtReach St. Croix strives for surprise and originality in all facets of our work. The Mobile Art Gallery lines up with ArtReach's values and goals by:
  • providing a fun and unique way to increase the number of people who will be directly served by ArtReach,
  • expanding the awareness of other art resources, events and venues all over the Valley, and
  • sharing our enthusiasm for the visual, performing and literary arts that happen in this special place.

Risks & Challenges

The Mobile Art Gallery does not come without challenges. Because it is a new project, there are obstacles that ArtReach must prepare for and overcome with everyone's help. The Mobile Art Gallery has:

  • an aggressive timeline,
  • a big vision,
  • the need for a project manager and dedicated volunteer builders, and
  • the backing of creative people who can help us overcome these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute but would still like to help, you can:

  • volunteer your time and skills to help us with the construction process,
  • contribute an item from the project wish list (posted on ArtReach's website),
  • spread the word about ArtReach and the Mobile Art Gallery! We love to see new faces at art events happening all around the St. Croix Valley

About Us

ArtReach St. Croix is a non-profit organization whose mission is to connect the St. Croix Valley community and the visual, literary and performing arts.  ArtReach St. Croix is a regional arts service and marketing organization that supports the work of artists and other arts organizations.To learn more about ArtReach St. Croix’s programs and services, visit: www.ArtReachStCroix.org

story:
Local Cloth wants to create a studio where members of the community can dye, teach and learn about fiber arts and work with local materials. Formed in 2011 and incorporated in 2012, we've successfully brought together weavers, spinners, dyers, fiber animal farmers, designers and mill owners from the 100 miles surrounding Asheville, NC,  to discuss the fiber economy and ways to help it grow.

Led by Judi Jetson, then economic development director at HandMade in America, this group identified gaps in the supply chain and discovered the major problem was – we were largely invisible to one another and there was no place to connect.  

Lots of initiatives followed, and as of 2015, more than 100 fiber artists, farmers and designers belonged to Local Cloth; 250 visited our latest exhibit; 350 attended or participated in our last fashion show; and hundreds shopped at our fleece and fiber tailgate market.  This year, we were offered an opportunity to realize a long-held dream -- a community dye studio and classroom space where we could come together any day of the week and work together.  

Now, thanks to an invitation from the Asheville Area Arts Council to be a founding member of its new arts incubator, The Refinery Creator Space, in Asheville’s burgeoning South Slope, we are proud to announce:

Coming Soon (with your help) -- Local Cloth ǀ Studio ● Classes

While we are fortunate to be in the midst of one of the richest concentrations of fiber artists in the U.S., there are few places residents and visitors can take short fiber arts classes – a situation our studio will remedy with a ready supply of highly skilled teachers. Located at 207 Coxe Avenue in Asheville, NC, the studio is about 900 square feet with tile floors, lots of natural light and access to water and ventilation. We share the building with another 12 studios full of photographers, painters, jewelry makers and all sorts of creative types.

Local Cloth members (annual dues are only $30, and $10 for students) will have access to the workspace, including all machines and equipment, for very modest fees. All programs and workshops, taught by skilled and experienced artists, will be open to the public, with members receiving discounted rates. By offering a range of workshops geared toward a variety of learners, Local Cloth will be supporting fiber artists of all ages and backgrounds. We’re also providing training classes to certify safe and productive use of equipment.

Why should you help?

Your contribution is essential for Local Cloth to acquire necessary equipment for the dye studio and a full range of fiber arts classes. Operational funding will come from dye studio rentals, workshop revenues and grants. Your support is an investment in our fiber artists and farmers, in our local craft scene, in our economy and in our community.

We believe in the principles of sustainable community development, and are pioneers in translating the techniques of the local food movement into a local cloth movement.  If you agree that it's important to help create (or bring back) revenue and jobs in the textile industry to the U.S., you should fund our project.  

How will we use your donation?

Your donation is critical for us to get Local Cloth’s Studio up and running. Generous donations of our members’ time and talent have gotten our space painted and cleaned up, and we know some will donate equipment and supplies, but there are major items we need funds to buy:

  • $1,300 – 3 natural gas ranges for dyeing wool, mohair and alpaca

  • $1,500  - Stainless steel sinks for rinsing

  • $1,800 – Induction burners and stainless steel pots, dye mixing hood and scales

  • $1,000 – triple guide motorized skein winder

  • $1,250 – storage, work counters and shelving

  • $1,900 – tables and chairs, stools and risers

  • $450 - tools like blenders, electric skillets, measuring cups, buckets

  • $800 – washer and dryer, drying racks


Our Successful Track Record

Check out what we’ve accomplished over the past five years:

  • Textile Study Group, now in its fifth year, features speakers working in or visiting our local area who present in-depth textile-related topics they’re passionate about.  Our champion:  Catharine Ellis, author and international speaker who taught in the Fiber Program at Haywood Community College for 30 years and originated the woven shibori process.

  • Project Handmade, created in 2012, is a biennial fashion show featuring locally made contemporary garments with traditional handcrafted detail using local materials. Its purpose is to showcase what our region’s most creative and talented fiber artists and garment makers can do when challenged to demonstrate the artistic and economic potential of supply chain collaboration. Our champions: 2012-Barbara Zaretsky, studio artist producing hand-dyed and printed textiles using peace silk, natural materials and plant dyes, and director of Cloth Fiber Workshop;  2014-Karen Donde, handweaver and weaving instructor; 2016-Vicki Bennett, feltmaker,  fiber artist and instructor.

  • Exhibits were initiated in 2011 to educate the public about the richness of fiber production and fiber art in the Blue Ridge region of southern Appalachia.  The first, Farm to Fashion, was at HandMade in America’s office, and subsequent exhibits - EXCITE and Connections -  were at Haywood Community College and the Asheville Area Arts Council. Our champions: 2011- Kari Rinn, Creative Arts Director at Haywood Community College; 2014-Kathie Roig, handweaver, fiber artist and instructor; 2015-Joan Berner, fiber artist and instructor.

  • Fiber Feel Day is an annual opportunity for spinners, knitters and weavers to connect with local farmers, feel the fleece and take home raw materials from the local area.  The one-day event is held at the WNC Farmers Market the first Saturday each June and has been generously co-sponsored by WNC Communities. Our champion: Susie Wheelis, founder of Last Penny Farm Alpacas.

  • Shepherd’s Forum gathered fiber animal farmers and service organizations together in 2012, 2013 and 2014. Collectively, they developed ideas to create new markets for their products while finding ways to make existing wool, mohair, alpaca, llama and rabbit fiber more enticing to fiber artists. Our champion: Starr Cash, owner of Venezia Dream Farm Alpacas.

  • Fiber Trails of the Blue Ridge Region puts details about our regional fiber economy, including a directory and map of supply chain participants, in a handy, fold-out printed brochure for locals and tourists. An online directory is in the works. Our champions: Judi Jetson,  Rik Lain Schell

Please visit our website, www.localcloth.org, to learn more about Local Cloth and the people who are committed to its success.

Thank you for joining us in our mission to support and sustain the regional fiber and textile arts economy and professions in the Blue Ridge Mountains through collaboration, education and innovation.

story:
Des livres et des réfugié-e-s est une maison d'édition qui publie des livres depuis 2016. Grâce à nos publications nous sommes venus en aide à de nombreuses familles. Nous achetons du matériel scolaire pour les enfants dans le besoin, nous cultivons la curiosité d'apprendre le français auprès de jeunes immigrants à travers nos ateliers d'écriture et de poésie et nous contribuons à l'excellence scolaire d'anciennes/anciens réfugié-e-s qui désirent poursuivre des études universitaires à travers notre bourse d'études Des livres et des réfugié-e-s.

Avec notre première campagne « Un livre pour Noël afin d'aider les réfugié-e-s » nous désirons atteindre l'objectif de 300 copies commandées d'ici la fin de la campagne le 12 décembre 2018. Toutes les commandes seront expédiées le lendemain, jeudi le 13 décembre 2018.

Grâce à votre aide, nous pourrons élargir notre soutien à travers le Québec. En plus d'encourager la culture en vous procurant un livre d'auteur-e-s d'ici, vous aidez à l'intégration et à l'apprentissage du français des nouveaux arrivants.

story:
Following "the Stargate", we were looking for a new project that would allow us to continue building large installations and using non-conventional disciplines, as a way to create art.  The deer/stag is an animal that we resonate with and we were inspired to capture the beauty of nature's architecture in a sculpture of a stag's skull.  In Beatrix the White's vision, the stag is a symbol of silent strength and the skull is a reminder of the graceful balance between life and death.  When exploring the design, Ms. Oh came across the story of Actaeon and was inspired to incorporate it into the name of our sculpture.

The Story of Actaeon:
The legendary huntsman of Greek myth, a grandson of Cadmus. During a hunt, he left the party and wandered alone through the forest when he suddenly came upon a clearing. There he saw the goddess Artemis bathing in a large pool, surrounded by her nymphs. When they noticed the hunter they flew themselves before the goddess, but he had already seen her splendid nakedness. Angered, she turned him into a stag for she refused to let any mortal say that he had seen Artemis naked. Actaeon moved away from the clearing feeling different and confused, not yet realizing what had happened to him. The truth hit him when he saw his own reflection in a river and he knew he was no longer human. In the distance he heard the sound of his own hounds. A brief moment of joy quickly turned into fear when he realized they were hunting him now, not recognizing their former master. He fled but was eventually overrun and torn to pieces by them.



Physical Description:

The Skull of Actaeon is shaped like a stag's skull, as you would find it while wandering in the woods. This sculpture will be constructed from plywood and 2 x 4's to create the skull base.  The antlers will be constructed from pvc pipes, and recycled rebar, anchored into the ground by steel wire.  The skull base will stand approx. 4 feet tall, with antlers extending to approx. 13 ft. In each of the eye sockets, an altar space will be created. The outside of the sculpture will be skinned in thin strips of wood, resourced from pallets.  The antlers will be skinned in fabric and internally lit via a programmed LED grid, which is remote controlled, and capable of syncing with audio.  We also hope to create an interactive light experience using an arduino controller, allowing the participant to change and control the lights.  Additionally, the skull will be internally lit, filtering soft light through the slits between the strips of pallet.  The altars will create a shared experience with our community, intended to address a need for a sacred space.

But where is the money going?

We need money...approximately $4500.

This budget is for new materials, but that is really the minimal costs of our budget. Our plan is to locate and source re-used or recycled materials, to save money. However, recycled materials are no guaranteed, so we have planned for all expenses. On top of that gas is really expensive.  We really want to take it places this summer- ESPECIALLY BURNING MAN!  So if you want to see this project there then please donate.  The more money we get the better we can make this project (including possible interactive visuals)!!!

3/4" 4'x8' Plywood @ $33.63 x 4 $134.52
1/2" 4'x8' Plywood @ $21.75 x 6 $130.50
2" x 4" x 8' Lumber @ $2.44 x 20 $48.80
2" x 2" x 8' Lumber @$1.78 x 6 $10.68
8" x 8" x 8" Concrete Block @ $1.16 x 4 $4.64
16" x 8" x 8" Concrete Block @ $1.25 x 4 $5.00
1/2" x 10' Rebar @ $7.47 x 4 $29.88
1/2" x 10' PVC Pipe @$1.81 x 20 $36.20
1 Gallon White Enamel Exterior Paint $39.98
Jersey Knit Stretch Fabric $28/m x 12m $336.00
3/16" Stainless Steel Wire Rope x 125' (roll) $59.77
Wire Rope Thimble & Clamp Set @$2.58 x 16 $42.28
6' Rachet Tie Down (12 Pack) $39.81
Auge Anchors (4 pack) $52.99
20m LED strip Light w/ sound control (incl. Ship) $244.95
#9 3" Wood screw 5 lbs $29.98
TimberLock 4" Hexhead Woodscrews 50 pk $28.31
3/4 " Brad Nails 1000 piece box x 3 $11.94
Arduino Controller $75
InstaPulse Floor Mount Heart Monitor  $438.09
Tax $269.90
Total Building Expenses: $2069.22

Transportation:
Entheos 194 km x $0.54/km = $104.76
Burn In the Forest 194 km x $0.54/km = $104.76
Shambhala 1318 km x $0.54/km = $711.72
Burning Man 2672 km x $0.54/km = $1442.88
Total Transportation Cost: $2364.12
(carrying wood is expensive and eats up gas)

Pre-Fee Total= $4433.34
12% Fees (indie GoGo & paypal) = $532
Additional possible cost for lighting & projector= $500
Total Costs = $5465.34

Our Sponsors

A big thanks to those who have already supported us and have helped us get building.

GVIAS ART GRANT (hooray) = $750

The Impact

We build beautiful art (Ask anyone who's seen The Stargate).  The Skull of Actaeon will be an amazing sight to behold in its own right, both in the daytime & at night.

The Skull of Actaeon is interactive in that it is physically there for people to touch and see, with altars to contribute to. As well, the lighting component is capable of syncing up with the music of the event and can also be controlled by the participants. We are hoping to develop interactive visuals, that the participant can control with their hand movements. Come play with it at one of the many festivals we hope to bring it to.

Your Support Means a Lot!!!!

Your support means a lot to us, so we'd like to show our gratitude for that support  with some amazing rewards (which you can see over to the right side of the page.) Every single penny we raise goes right into The Skull of Actaeon.  Like all of our art projects, this is a labor of love for us.  Not only are we donating our own time and money to this project, but we are donating from our business to help make this project come alive.

At the end of the day though, the reward that WE, the build team, and YOU, our supporter will share in is the amazing sense of community that you are helping to create. 

Here are examples of some of the great swag you will get:

NOTE: These are mock-ups only.  We will post new photos when we have received the real product.  Thanks for your patience!

Can't contribute, but still want to help???

You CAN!

Please help us spread the news of this epic project far and wide by using one of the many Sharing Tools- whether on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, or via email, we need your help in spreading the word to every corner of the world! Or share our link wherever you can!

We also need help with lighting and visuals! If you are an expert in visuals and lighting, we could use your help.  We have a few friends interested in helping us, but the more ideas we have the better this piece will be!


Who are you people???

Oh Bunny Designs has had many years experience building big art, organizing festivals, and if need be can call on the experience and knowledge of the wider Temple of Transition Vancouver Crew, Intention Gathering Community, the Greater Vancouver Burner community and the International Arts Megacrew (a global group of artists, artisans, fabricators, industrial designers and project managers with a vision for producing large-scale art projects. With over 50 core members from 17 countries, IAM members have created installation art for festivals and events worldwide).

Beatrix the White has been pursuing a career as an artist since 2007. He is a multidisciplinary artist, working in illustration, tattooing, sculpture, fashion design, and installation art work. As a an illustrator, he creates highly detailed works of a visionary/surrealist nature. Drawing greatly on mathematics and geometry to create structure within the organic realm of the inner landscape of the mind. Examples of his work can be viewed here. As a Fashion designer, he works with his partner under the name Oh Bunny designs. Creating steampunk/Victorian style fashion accessories including; hats, cuffs, earrings, and hair pieces. Examples of their work can be viewed at Facebook. In 2011, Beatrix had the opportunity to serve the Burning Man community by helping build the Temple of Transition by the IAM. He served as build lead in Vancouver and was key part of the design and construction of the Altar of Union, a kinetic sculpture that was built in Vancouver and shipped to the Playa to be a part of the temple. In 2012, he joined David Best' team on the playa to build the Temple of Juno, working mainly on the outer walls. 

When not working as an elementary teacher at a Fine Arts School, Karen Oh is pursuing her passion in the arts. As a Fashion designer, she too works with her partner under the name Oh Bunny designs(co-inky dink?). Creating steampunk/Victorian style fashion accessories including; hats, cuffs, earrings, and hair pieces. Examples of their work can be viewed  online (see link above) or in person at Entheos and Folk Fest Artisan Market. In the summer of 2011, Karen also had the opportunity to serve the Burning Man community by working with the crew of the Temple of Transition. She served as fundraising lead in Vancouver and was Assistant Lead-Fluffer on Playa, helping to care for and keep the team alive during the building of the temple. In 2012, she once again was asked to join the Temple crew and joined David Best building the Temple of Juno, working on lanterns and in the tool shed.

story:
Hey there!

If you happen to find yourself to be reading this, then I'd like to start by thanking you for taking a few minutes out of your day to get to know me and my pretty ridiculous campaign here on IndieGoGo! I promise it wont be a waste of your time- I think of myself as pretty entertaining...

My name is Matt and I just graduated from Manhattanville College with a double major in Theatre and Education. I have a strong desire for both teaching and performing, and have spent the last four years really devoting my time in the classroom and on the stage. As a pretty awesome award from my parents for my successes, they've planned a family vacation to California to celebrate! This is my first time in the Cali area, and for that purpose, I knew the first place that I would have to stop into was High Voltage Tattoo! This shop is home to some of the worlds best artists and most acclaimed names! Why is any of this information important to you? Well.... you're about to come into my story!

Broke College Graduate...

I submitted an appointment form via the website on their page, and surprisingly received interest from two different tattoo artists in a short amount of time! While this is amazing news for someone who wasn't expecting much more than a hopeful walk in appointment, the estimated price on this piece was a bit out of my price range for the entirety of my trip! That's why I've turned to you, my wonderful readers, in hopes that you can find it in your heart of hearts to donate whatever you can for some permanent ink on my skin!

    The Ink

    In a mixture combination of the things that I love, my desire for the need of self fulfillment is established between my astrological sign and that of theatrical implementation. In this sketch by 17th century artist Johannis Hevelius, the two worlds intertwine to tell the tale of the Sagittarius. Located on my right forearm, this tattoo will forever fly through my life with me; and receiving it at such a high end shop after a big event in my life that I am more than proud of is just the icing on the cake!  

    The Impact

    This trip for my family and I is one that we'll forever remember. Not only is a vacation fulfilling, but this is the last one we will have as a group for quite some time. My younger brother is in the NAVY and has been stationed across the sea and a whole lot of miles away for a few years as of this July. Everyday will be spent in the present, and though it will be hard at the end, having something that is permanently there to remind me of the different roads we lead in life will be a great addition to the word I currently have tattooed on my wrist; "Breathe."  

      My thank you to you

      Seemingly the most pretentious, self oriented and personal IndieGoGo of campaigns that I'm sure you've ever read, I would just like to thank you so much for reading this post! If you could find it in your heart to donate even a penny, you'd be responsible for something so totally awesome! Everyone gets a hug and a cupcake! Love, Matt :)

story:
PHOTOGRAPHY EXHIBITION

The third year students of Camberwell College have their graduation in sight. The students have started planning the degree show and have already produced some great work-we are on target to be able to show some truly original works.

We've extended our deadline as we are not close to the £3000 raised by the fundraisers last year!

Please click on the 'Gallery' tab above to see some examples of the work the students have produced.

The course at Camberwell is unique because it allows students the freedom to explore any interests in research. Through photography based lectures and seminars, students are free to create works that range from photography to sculpture with a mixture of studio and externally based practices.

We need your help to raise money, for things such as the catalogues and the build of our show.

 

Help support emerging artists!

 

We don’t have a target! The more you help us out the more ambitious and innovative the show we can create and the more VIP’s we can reach to give us the best opportunities possible for after graduation.

 

Come and see fresh work and help us reach the biggest audience we can!

We hope many of you will be just as excited to be able to be a part of it as we are.

The show is a fantastic opportunity for you to catch a glimpse of some ground-breaking work.

Join our facebook page to be notified of updates on the projects we are working on.

https://www.facebook.com/groups/629444350437552/

And 

To show our gratitude and a way of remembering the show we have put together gift packages for donations over £5.

 

Please give generously.

Thank you for your support in advance and we look forward to seeing you in June.

story:
Short Summary

The John Biggers Art Bridge and Seed Project (Seed) is a public art and collaborative design effort  engaging renowned African  American artists, local lead artsts Tacoumba Aiken and Seitu Jones in mentoring of 13 emerging artists in placemaking and career development. Seed is inspired by the Celebration of Life Mural project, an acclaimed public artwork led by Dr. John Biggers, a major African American artist of the twentieth century, which began the careers of young artists and organizations (including Obsidian Arts and Juxtaposition Arts), planting artistic “seeds” and reflecting the legacies of north Minneapolis neighborhoods - Harrison, Heritage Park, Near North, and North Loop.

Seed has four goals:

  • Engage artists across generations in a collaborative effort to create a vibrant place that speaks to the culture and legacies of the north Minneapolis areas;
  • Grow, launch and nurture the public art careers of emerging artists;
  • Build an attractive connection between these North neighborhoods (Harrison, Heritage Park, North Loop and Near North) and downtown that improves walk-ability and make the area more attractive to residents and visitors;
  • To create a process that is replicable so that we can continue to increase the diversity and competitiveness of the state’s public artists.

Seed is funded by the City of Minneapolis Art in Public Places Program, the National Endowment for the Arts Our Town Program, the McKnight Foundation Regions and Communities Program, the Pohlad Family Foundation and the North Loop Association.

Meet the artists

Meet Artists Video


Impact

Seed aims to impact the north Minneapolis area in three specific ways. 

First, the project creates an iconic public artwork that shares the story of the north Minneapolis area through an art bridge stretching more than 250 linear feet.  This bridge will be a gateway and source of pride for the residents of the adjacent communities.

Second, the project aims to launch, develop and support the public art careers of the 13 emerging artists,, dramatically increasing the number of African American artists equipped to compete for major public art commissions. An evaluation of the project will focus on understanding how Seed can serve as a model to engage and successfully grow other emerging artists from underrepresented communities in the future.

Third, imagine what artwork could be created if you could paint with glass. The art bridge is being created using an enameling process that is unique and compelling--porcelain enamel--a vibrant and durable glass material fused to steel.  The artists, who come from a variety of artistic backgrounds, will learn this exciting and extremely durable process and create the more than 300 panels that will be installed on the art bridge.  Your contribution will literally change the landscape of the North Minneapolis community and a major public space that will be experienced by people traveling throughout the region.


The project partners and their responsibilities:

  • Urban Research and Outreach Engagement Center (UROC): Coordinate local community engagement activities and host a number of the artist training sessions.
  • Obsidian Arts:  Emerging artist selection, training, and follow-up.
  • Chicago Avenue Fire Arts Center: All activities related to fabricating the enamel panels including kiln construction and maintenance, artist training and artwork development.
  • The City of Minneapolis is responsible for the overall coordination and administration of the project through its Art in Public Places program.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking an additional $7,500 to support artist training and enamel panel creation over the next one and a half years.  The training will includes kiln building, firing and artwork fabrication, collaborative design, art conservation, material selection, concept planning and evaluation, community engagement and more.  These skills are core to the development of successful of public artists.

In appreciation for your support we are offering six levels of participation intended to ensure that everyone in our community can support this project.  These contribution levels range from $10 a to $500.  Perks attached to each contribution level (see below) are our way of sharing the project with you. We ask that you give at an amount that is significant to you..

If we do not reach the $7,500.00 goal we will utilize the funds collected to support the training to the level possible that maximizes the value per dollar in hand.

The project will transform this bridge.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a contribution you can help us by sharing the information about the Seed Project to your friends and relatives.  You can also plan to join us for the community meetings and gatherings that we will host over the course of the project. To join our email list please contact us at elizabeth.turner-opanga@minneapolismn.gov.

story:
My name is Mike Kennelly.  I am the treasurer for StorySwap, one of the local storytelling guilds, and a member to the Three Rivers Storytelling Festival Organizing Committee.  I have been involved with the storytelling community in Pittsburgh since 1990 as a performer and an organizer.  This is the second year that Festival is being operated as an independent event. The committee has spent a ton of time since last year's festival refining our purpose, setting goals, and planning for the next five years.  We have so many things to accomplish! For example, teaching young people how to tell their story or gathering the shared experience of older people to share with others.  Eventually we see the festival as a regional event involving multiple venues where the stories that define us are shared in a variety of forms that makes this performance choice so wonderfully flexible. This campaign is one of the ways that you can help make these big dreams a reality.

Our goal is to raise $1500 from people who support Storytelling as a performance art. All of the money raised at this point in time is used to fund the festival operations. In the future we hope to build out other programs more related to the development of the craft and exploring new creative forms.

Truthfully though just running a festival is an expensive undertaking when it is done in such a way that the performers, guests, staff, and hosts are comfortable and having fun.  This campaign will not fund the whole project. It provides a huge boost. It also give you an opportunity to contribute to this worthy endeavor. Remember our goal is to provide an event that is free to the public.  We want everyone who wishes to gather with a community of like minded souls and enjoy a few hours sharing laughs, loves, tears, and terror in the way only people can.

If you can't donate you can still help. You can help by letting people know about this campaign. You can help by telling people about the Festival. You can help by volunteering at the Festival. You can help by showing up on August 8th, and 9th and joining in on he fun.
