story:
Telling stories in a forgotten way

Anamnesis is a collaboration with five Iranian tribal women, in a show of rugs, using the power of recollection and the art of weaving to tell their personal stories. It explores how the tradition of rug weaving is slowly vanishing in Iran. It aims to restore the weavers as creators as opposed to manual laborers by reinstating the power of symbols and heritage of storytelling, in a practice, that’s an important part of nomadic and tribal culture in Iran.

The show in New York will be accompanied by a short film chronicling the journey of the project and a limited edition book showcasing each weaver, their final piece and the memory that inspired it.

The project will culminate with an exhibition in late fall of 2019 in Tehran, Iran and will travel to New York in the winter of the same year with the possibility of traveling to other cities across the United States in 2020.

https://www.instagram.com/anamnesis_anamnesis/

http://handeyemagazine.com/content/anamnesis

Mythology & lore of creation

Rug weaving is deeply tied to Iranian culture, history and art. Nomadic and tribal weavings have their own unique history and traditions and carry significant information and stories about their makers. They contain meaningful symbols, beliefs taken from myths and folklore that were handed down from one generation to the next. Not only were the motifs regarded as powerful but also the belief in the act of tying knots to manifest desires made hand knotted weavings incredibly strong talismans that served an important purpose in the lives of the nomadic tribes.

Phase 1 : Already completed!!

Over the course of several magical months in 2018, I traveled and researched in major cities throughout Iran where rug production has been a main source of income for majority of nomadic tribes and tribal villagers. I spent time with 18 weavers, women from very humble backgrounds, discussing how and when they began weaving, what impact weaving has had on their lives and how they regard it as artisans. They shared their memories from childhood, as young women and later as wives who would use this craft to support families of rather large sizes. Simultaneously, I would share memories from my own life as an artist, an ex-pat, and what weaving means to me.

To gain deeper knowledge about the history of weaving in Iran, I interviewed professors, young artists and foundations whose sole purpose is to preserve and work in traditional Iranian crafts, most importantly, rug weaving. To my unfortunate surprise, it seemed that due to severe competition on the world stage, the worsening economy and political reasons the art of rug weaving is slowly dying out of newer generations and that as the New York Times stated in 2016, “the Persian rug may not be long for this world” https://nyti.ms/1Wm9MLM.

Phase 2 : Summer 2019, right around the corner!

These talented women will be choosing and weaving a memory or a story that they’ve already shared with me and deem personally significant. An important outcome of this stage is to give them support to work on a personal project that has meaning for them and reinstate them as creators. Currently, they are only recognized as hands producing a product and all are severely underpaid for their time and expertise. Their generational knowledge is regarded as disposable and the importance of giving them agency is not a factor in their treatment.

I will be working with five weavers after discussing the premise of the project with each. We will be drafting a letter of agreement to be signed by each woman. We’ll be calculating their wages by the World Fair Trade Organization standard which states :

“A Local Living Wage is remuneration received for a standard working week (no more than 48 hours) by a Worker in a particular place, sufficient to afford a decent standard of living for the Worker and her or his family.”

This is not a NPO (non-profit organization) endeavor and I am not a member of the WFTO but I am using their guidelines as a global model to pay fair wages and make sure working conditions meet the WFTO standards. Most weavers, if not all, work out of their homes as it allows them to take care of their families and homes.

All materials and custom made looms will be provided by myself and donated to the women. I will be conducting a 2-3 week design workshop where we’ll be helping the weavers refine their ideas and mainly give them support and self confidence to work on a personal project that has meaning for them.

Phase 3 : Winter of 2020 : Funded by your generous DONATIONS!

Your donations will be used to bring the project to its final stages and our show in New York in the winter of 2020. Any funds raised above our goal will be put towards shows in Washington D.C. and Los Angeles with hopes to make it a traveling exhibit across the United States.

Short Film : Our fifteen minute short film will be a visual diary of this project. The film will be in post-production in New York City. A post-production team will be commissioned for the video and sound editing, translations, voice-overs, subtitles, graphics, color correction, music, raw footage archiving as well as other technical needs for the final completion of this short film.  

Limited Edition Book : A 30 page book will be designed and published in New York City in two languages: Persian and English. This collectors item will show the journey and roots of this project not only with visuals but also with profiles of each weaver and their unique stories. Each weaver’s personal anecdote of the significance of the particular memory they decide to manifest on the loom will be chronicled in this special limited edition book. Along with a seasoned graphic designer, we’re hiring a translator, editor and we’ll be printing with an independent publishing house.

Pop-Up Gallery Exhibit New York : The purpose of this project is to share the rarely told stories, incredible talent and unique history of these women with an audience that would otherwise never have access to them. With an exhibit that showcases their pieces, our limited edition book and viewings of our short film, we want to share this special journey with others. With your donations, we’ll be able to host a pop-up gallery for a minimum run of two weeks. This includes space rental and exhibit preparation, installation of pieces, special lighting, labeling, video projection, audio production, and an opening reception.

Post-Anamnesis and why this project is important

Beyond this project and the multiple shows, we aim to preserve and rekindle the long tradition of "zehni-bafi" - weaving from memory - not only to inspire but to teach these women to tell stories the ancient way by use of motifs and emblems. It is our desire to once again give deeper meaning to what these women create and provide a platform where they have a role in the outcome and significance of the product that they painstakingly work on. These traditions are rapidly fading, it is the hope that this endeavor will reignite the artisanal passion for newer generations and continue to preserve this beautiful artistic craft.  

http://handeyemagazine.com/content/anamnesis

Project Creator

I am Nazanin Sadr Azodi, an Iranian-American textile designer.             

My 15 year career in the design industry has afforded me an in depth view of mass market and the damaging effects it can have on local crafts. As a designer as well as a director, my push for high level design, no matter the tier of market, and the demand for better quality was always met with bottom line thinking. The stripping of quality, which inevitably would lead to the dumbing down of the design aesthetic, and disregard for craftspeople and consumers left me disillusioned with the world of design. I, not only as a maker, but also as a consumer, wanted to support products that had soul and a story to tell. Ultimately my distaste for fast design and cheap products along with a need to better align my daily practice as a designer with my ethics led me back to my home country of Iran where I rediscovered my love of textiles and the women who make them. This time of reflecting and connecting with these women through a shared narrative experience and our love of weaving was humbling and beautiful. To learn about the history and mythology of rug weaving in Iran, where its roots lie, was a haunting and an unforgettable experience that I want to share with others.

www.linkedin.com/in/nazazodi

Risks & Challenges

While I am optimistic and hopeful that we will reach our funding goals to bring this project onto the global stage, I am 100% dedicated to bringing Anamnesis to fruition whether or not we reach it. This project is a manifestation of the last ten months working relentlessly non-stop. As a result of following my intuition to bring a vision and a voice to these rarely known artisans, I quit my job and used my life savings to research and travel solo across Iran in search of these gifted weavers. Due diligence was taken at every juncture to ensure that we do not hit any roadblocks or obstacles. I've consulted lawyers, accountants, and have interviewed countless collaborators to make this an outstanding endeavor.

This is an ambitious project and it involves many moving parts. The risks and challenges involved are all in the arena of time. I've accounted for unforeseen delays in our timeline but there can always be more surprises no matter the extent of planning and delicate logistics. Rest assured, I am a 15 year veteran of an industry that operates on very tight deadlines, demands you to work on an array of projects simultaneously and manage internal and external teams. Hence, I'm well equipped to handle large projects whether here in the United States or internationally while meeting deadlines and delivering results.

So stay tuned to our updates on Indiegogo and follow us on our Instagram. I will be documenting every step of the way and updating constantly. Not only do I want to be completely transparent with the process, I want all of you to enjoy and witness this special journey with us!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate at this moment (but maybe a lil later! Think of it as getting me an Indiegogo drink! ;)) I ask that you kindly share our Indiegogo funding page on your social media (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) - put us out there! Indiegogo has really easy-to-use buttons on the top right corner of our page.

We're truly *grateful* for you believing in us, valuing this ancient craft, respecting these women as precious and rare artisans they are and enabling us to make this project an incredible success!

story:
Dear friends and future friends,

We are Vero and Kate, two founding members of The Great Social Evil, a feminist artist collective. Vero is a textile artist. Kate is a choreographer.  We met during grad school as part of the inaugural class of Gregg Bordowitz’s Low Residesidency MFA program in Studio Art at the Art Institute of Chicago. We have been invited by the Skaftfell Center for Visual Art in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland to develop a performance installation during  the month of May. We will be bringing one of our dancer/collaborators, Ann-Marie Gover. We will use this time to rehearse, write, play, and develop a process of working together. We have begun the research as part of Kate’s Artist-In-Residence at Movement Research in New York, and will continue into 2017.

The Great Social Evil is a research-based interdisciplinary and multiform collective, whose members live and work across the American and European continents. The main aim of the collective is to create a balance between ethics and aesthetics that transcend the studio walls and permeate the daily routine. Hidden histories within the official History (the one with capital H), intersectional feminism, radical self-care, and pleasure as origin and motor of the practice of both art and the everyday life.

Over the next two years, we will build a performance practice based in embodied ensemble work focusing on pleasure, failure, and risk. In this research, we will engage with a myriad of sensorial choreographies, in which we aim to shift perception of the performers and audience through heightened experience of each sense. We will construct a large installation of various textiles, objects, and materials, which will double as garment, set and sculpture. We will play with the material as it lives in relation to body, architecture, and space. This research will work towards a durational performance installation that will premiere in 2018.  

Because we believe in fair, kind, and caring practices in art and life, we are committed to pay our collaborators for their work. It is for this reason that we reach out to ask for your support in helping us fund this trip/research. Your donations will help pay for our air fare, groceries, car rental, and artist fees. We are looking to raise $4500, which will help us cover these costs.

It is important to us to be able to contribute to a healthy art employment ecology. With this action we pursue not just fair payment for our collaborators, but join many art practitioners that are fighting against the rampant speculation and abuse of the art world (thus sending good Karma around).

For your kind contribution, we are of course thankful, and will yell your name in the Iceland countryside. But we have moore goodies that range from the chintziest postcards of icelandic landscape we can find, to custom embroidered patches, professional development sessions with Kate (in person for those in NYC, and by Skype for the rest of you) to help strategize how to build a sustainable life as an artist, an invitation to a rehearsal, appliqued textiles with quotes  from our fave feminist authors, and digitally woven artworks made by Vero specially for you.

To learn more about us, scroll down.....

Thank you so much for your help, and if you can't contribute, cause you know, crowd-funding, everyone does it.....then consider spreading the word.

We are grateful.

Kisses,

Vero + Kate

Some more about us:

Veronica Casado Hernandez is a Chicago-based visual artist and cultural historian. A self-confessed “pastist” (in opposition to futurist), she uses queer notions of historiography and chronopolitics to practice trans-temporal drag and explore narratives of power and rebellion related to women’s social identity in her installations, performances, and writings. Both her studio practice and academic research intersect  investigates constructions of female identity in western nineteenth and twentieth century, and their outcomes and parallels in present day.

After working briefly in fashion, and in costume in advertising in Spain and Lebanon, Casado Hernandez moved to the US to complete her undergraduate studies. She earned a BFA in  Fibers and Culture and Politics in the Maryland Institute College of Art. She is a graduate of the inaugural class of the Low Residency MFA in Studio Art at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, and a founding member of The Great Social Evil. She is a 206/17 Hatch Resident at the Chicago Artist Coalition, and at Skaftfell Center for Visual Art in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland.  Her work has been shown in the US, Spain, and the Netherlands; and she has presented her academic  research in the Costume Colloquium IV and V, and MORE Conference in Gender and Architecture  in Florence, Italy. The New Research Conference of the Fashion Historian Association in London, UK Popular Culture Association in Seattle, and College Art Association in New York.

verocasado.virb.com

Kate Watson-Wallace is an interdisciplinary artist based in Brooklyn, NY. Her work is in dialogue with queer theory, pop culture, and feminism. Her research investigates the performer body, the audience body and the space between, while trying to break apart this binary through interactivity.  Her practice as a writer, curator, moderator and artist is concerned with the role of artists as vision-makers, people who imagine the impossible and work with futurity, risk and collective strategies to create change. In her work and teaching, she wants to create spaces for understanding and negotiating difference, spaces for wildness, spaces for new imaginaries.

Her work has been funded by multiple Map Fund grants, Doris Duke Foundation/Creative Capital, Independence Foundation, The Mid Atlantic Arts Foundation, and the Pew Center for Arts & Heritage. She is a Pew Fellow in Choreography. She has toured internationally as a performer, choreographer, and educator. Major works include CAR, a performance inside a moving vehicle, mashupbody, a collaboration with HPrizm/Chris Powell, and alt/mode, an interdisciplinary stage show with electronic composer RYAT, that premiered at Summerstage Central Park. She has choreographed music videos for Animal Collective and Black Dice, with director Danny Perez.  Recent lectures/residencies include: Massachusetts College of Art and Design, University of California Los Angeles, University of Texas Austin, University of the Arts and The Yard. Her current research is supported by a Movement Research AIR in NYC and a residency at Skaftfell Center for Visual Art in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland. She is a graduate of the inaugural class of the Low Residency MFA in Studio Art at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, and a founding member of The Great Social Evil. www.katewawa.org
story_txt: Dear friends and future friends,We are Vero and Kate, two founding members of The Great Social Evil, a feminist artist collective. Vero is a textile artist. Kate is a choreographer.  We met during grad school as part of the inaugural class of Gregg Bordowitz’s Low Residesidency MFA program in Studio Art at the Art Institute of Chicago. We have been invited by the Skaftfell Center for Visual Art in Seyðisfjörður, Iceland to develop a performance installation during  the month of May. We will be bringing one of our dancer/collaborators, Ann-Marie Gover. We will use this time to rehearse, write, play, and develop a process of working together. We have begun the research as part of Kate’s Artist-In-Residence at Movement Research in New York, and will continue into 2017.The Great Social Evil is a research-based interdisciplinary and multiform collective, whose members live and work across the American and European continents. The main aim of the collective is to create a balance between ethics and aesthetics that transcend the studio walls and permeate the daily routine. Hidden histories within the official History (the one with capital H), intersectional feminism, radical self-care, and pleasure as origin and motor of the practice of both art and the everyday life.Over the next two years, we will build a performance practice based in embodied ensemble work focusing on pleasure, failure, and risk. In this research, we will engage with a myriad of sensorial choreographies, in which we aim to shift perception of the performers and audience through heightened experience of each sense. We will construct a large installation of various textiles, objects, and materials, which will double as garment, set and sculpture. We will play with the material as it lives in relation to body, architecture, and space. This research will work towards a durational performance installation that will premiere in 2018.  Because we believe in fair, kind, and caring practices in art and life, we are committed to pay our collaborators for their work. It is for this reason that we reach out to ask for your support in helping us fund this trip/research. Your donations will help pay for our air fare, groceries, car rental, and artist fees. We are looking to raise $4500, which will help us cover these costs.It is important to us to be able to contribute to a healthy art employment ecology. story:
My name is Henry Detweiler and I am an artist, writer, and curator based in Atlanta, GA. I have been accepted to the Vermont Studio Center for residency from November 24-December 20. This will be my first time attending a traditional artist residency and I'm so looking forward the solid month of focused time to work that the residency will provide.

The problem is that although the cost of which has been offset by generous artist and work exchange fellowships from VSC, I still cannot afford the residency fee and the expense of getting there and back at one of the busiest (and most expensive) times of year for travel–not to mention the cost of transporting art supplies and artwork.

I've had a lot of professional success in the last year due in large part to the help and support of others, so I'm asking for your help again to help me participate in what would really be a dream opportunity for me.

Please help in whatever way you can–the perks are gonna be pretty sweet. If you can't help out financially, please share with your friends and help spread the word–the love perks for doing that are also gonna be pretty sweet.

Thank you for your support!

story:
Project Summary

VideoSynth is an interactive audio/video installation that uses you as the instrument of live art. At one end of the installation is an automated touch screen video booth that elicits a series of responses from participants. The video recording appears at the mixing station console where participants can select their videos and play them back on a large screen while manipulating and synthesizing the sound, video, and background art in real time. The dynamic video portrait can be saved and emailed to users. Participants can also generate 4"x6" still photographic prints on the fly by pressing a print button on the controller. The project is part video booth, part photo booth, part dynamic portrait machine, and part musical instrument. Please got to http://videosynth.me to see photos of the installation.

What We Need and What You Get

We are hoping to raise at least $5000 in the immediate future to help defray some of the costs of gear and transportation to upcoming events and festivals. Our next event is BurningMan and we would like to do live printing there. It will cost about $1500 to do this at BurningMan. The printer will be ruined from the dust at this event. 

We are also trying to create a new video booth with an embedded camera system. The current video kiosk does not have an embedded camera so we may run into dust issues with that as well. 

We are really interested in the concept of playing yourself like a live instrument. We created this system for you to dynamically create a live video and play it back with audio like a live moving portrait on a massive screen. You can save the video portrait and also make printed still portraits in the process. We think it's a lot of fun!

We are doing 2 private gallery showings of the project for donors in a gallery setting, one on August 17, and one in October 2013. All donors will be emailed invitations and details to these events.

We've also designed some great personalized art pieces for you to preserve your video and still portraits with. Please check out the perks sections and go to http://videosynth.me/gifts for photos and details.

The Impact

We think we have created a very unique project. Many of my friends and family have seen this project take shape over the last year. Your support for this project would mean the world to our team and help make this project the best that it can be.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds to help support us but still like our project, please share this with your networks and let us know. We'll send you a big thank you and an invite to our donor events. Please contact us at info(at)videosynth.me

Thanks!!

story:
We are a diverse group of about 30 visual artists who have one significant commonality. We all attended New York City’s High School of Music and Art, graduating class of 1969.

After more than 44 years, evolved and encrusted with life, love, children, grandchildren, failures, triumphs and most notably art, we have come together as a collective to present an exhibition of works from paintings to sculpture to movies to books to wall hangings to puzzles to shadow-boxed scenes to gardens and beyond. The event will open on Saturday, November 9th, at Studio 34 in Long Island City in Queens.

Our common ground as young creatives during the tumultuous and politically charged years of the late 60s, when the civil rights and women’s rights movements and the Vietnam conflict, rendered a unique glue that stealthily bonded this quilt of humanity together like no class before or after (to date). The impact of those formative years layered with the breadth of varied and global experiences for the next 44, has culminated into an astounding super-­charged body of work that we believe is not only significant but internationally relatable.

Both as teenagers in the ’60’s and 60-year-­olds today, art has, and continues to be, the bridge that connects the gamut of racial, religious, and socioeconomic strata we comprise. In a time when diversity is constantly being challenged, we believe as a group we are bringing a breath of fresh air as well as important social commentary to the public viewer where the impact and influence is the greatest. 

Monetary contributions will not only help to make this Group Exhibition a reality by allowing us to cover the costs of printed and promotional materials, hanging supplies, transporting of musical instruments, and domestic and international postage, but it will also offer the financial infusion needed to publicize this unprecedented event far and wide in our efforts to achieve the greatest public impact.

And we will be offering some incentives to contribute: for a $25 contribution you can receive a dvd of photos from the event and mention as a supporter in the program. For a $50 contribution we will be offering a dvd of photos as well as interviews with some of the artists, plus mention in the program. And for a $100 contribution we will offer all of the above and an autographed poster of the event.

For those of you who are viewers, creators, collectors, or otherwise appreciators of the arts, this conglomerate of media and styles by names you might recognize as well as those you will not, will certainly energize you. For those of you who simply seek out creative and robust causes worthy of your support, we believe this notable effort more than fits the bill.

Even if you can’t contribute money, your getting the word out is as good as gold. You can help us by using the Indiegogo share tools to let your friends, family and colleagues know what is about to take place.  You deserve to be part of this “Evolution!”

story:
Elephant Room is a Chicago-based arts organization specializing in primarily local, under-represented artists and designers working across all types of media. We operate a retail art gallery in the South Loop neighborhood where we host art openings, creative events, talk and workshops on a regular basis. Our programs allow us to work beyond our storefront space and this campaign will further our reach out into the world!
 
Background
 
Elephant Room Gallery began in 2009 when the opportunity to partner with a local small business owner came along to transform a 320 square foot storefront into a gallery in the South Loop. I, Kimberly Leja-Atwood, attended the University of Illinois at Chicago and earned my BFA in photography. While there, I was a part of the New Works Group, composed of my fellow peers, where we frequently put together our own photography exhibitions. My interest in gallery work grew exponentially here as I enjoyed the collaborative nature of working with other artists and having a hand in curating exhibitions from start to finish. Elephant Room was a perfect fit for my interest and skill set. As Elephant Room took shape that first year, I continued to work full time as a commercial real estate photographer while holding art exhibitions every one to two months with limited viewing hours. The gallery was run entirely by myself and my husband, James, while we both worked full time at our day jobs.

In February of 2011, a couple of weeks after giving birth to my son, Austin, we re- opened Elephant Room as a retail art gallery where we exhibited a multitude of artists and designers, while still holding exhibitions every 1-2 months with a focus on under- represented artists. In addition, we started to branch out and hold many unique events including socials, open mics, live sketch events and launch parties. We also began to host exhibitions in other unique spaces in the city and became more involved with assisting artists in hosting their own open studio events. The Artist Assistance Program began to organically emerge as we hired on more of our own gallery interns and were able to commit to working with more established artists in their studios.

The most rewarding and unexpected element in all of this has been the strengthening of my own family unit as my husband James and I run the business together and our love for art continues to evolve. We both take our roles seriously and have learned to balance work and home life after a few years of trial and error. Our 19 month old, Austin, has been introduced to the art world from birth as he’s frequently with me at the gallery and enjoys his time there and has developed relationships with our artists just as we have. A great example of this is when James commissioned one of our long time artists, Jennifer Cronin, to paint a portrait of the three of us and our two dogs after our son Austin was born. The painting hangs in Austin’s bedroom as a constant reminder of why we’re doing this.

The Campaign

I started Elephant Room Gallery with the intention of providing a unique space that would be both an exhibition space and a resource for the Chicago art community. By working with under-represented artists Elephant Room provided a space for an up and coming artist the ability to build their resume, gain exposure, and make contacts.

Today, Elephant Room Gallery is much more than a retail outlet and gallery space. This transition is very intentional. After a year of exhibiting emerging artists and holding openings, artist talks and workshops, we decided that we needed to do more with the community and involve even more artists and interested community members with our space. With your investment we can move Elephant Room Gallery beyond a store front and out into the community through innovative programs such as the Artist Assistance Program and the Intern Placement Program.

$15,000 will allow us to increase the number of exhibitions we put on per year from November 2012 to November 2013; strengthen our network by hosting events throughout Chicago; and ensure that each artist exhibition has a healthy marketing and promotion budget. Additionally, the funds will allow us to continue our Artist Assistance Program at no cost to the artists involved (currently they pay a nominal fee) and will expand our Intern Placement Program by reaching a larger artist and student audience through advertising.

Perks!

All of our perks showcase our current artists, who have generously donated their time and talents to making this campaign a success.

$500: Zeph Farmby is currently exhibiting “Love, Lust and Desire” in our gallery and has been a strong and positive supporter of our mission. http://i-amaze-eyez.com/about/ Sam Kirk, a long time Elephant Room supporter, is a Chicago artist now moving her message to other cities. www.iamsamkirk.com

$1,000: Connie Noyes is an active participant in our Artist Assistance Program. www.connienoyes.com

$2,500: Jennifer Cronin is a rapidly emerging Chicago artist who’s paintings are now making impacts outside of the U.S. www.jennifercronin.com

If we do not reach our $15,000 goal, the funds donated will still make an impact on our organization as we work to increase our impact beyond our four walls. We will work to make up the remaining funds needed through our gallery sales to ensure that we stay on target with an increase in exhibitions and additional programming.

The Impact

Elephant Room has successfully provided an exhibition space for emerging artists as well as a venue for artists and designers to sell their work and retain a majority of the sale while gaining valuable exposure and experience. Our focus on under-represented local artists has had amazing impact on Chicago’s art scene as we bring more attention to these individuals and thus impact the direction of their careers. Our South Loop storefront has been the hub for gatherings of many kinds that have connected people in an artistic setting and has been a great art resource for the surrounding community of students, residents and visitors. The Artist Assistance Program was developed in our second year and provides artists with that bit of extra help with both office and in-studio work that allows them to focus more on the creative and removes the overwhelming elements of self-promotion and marketing. After a year of running the Artist Assistance Program and meeting more and more artists and students who wanted to become involved, we started to pair interested students with individual artists who were in need of interns. During the summer of 2012, the Intern Placement Program was born. We are able to connect students with artists in order to provide both parties with the experience and time needed in order to further their careers in the art world.

With our limited budget, we have been able to build our exposure over the past few years and are now a recognizable name in many art circles. We receive several artist submissions per week as well as a lot of interest from both artists and students interested in our programs. We continue to operate on a smaller scale with 2-3 interns per semester so that we can focus on providing them with a valuable experience while still providing opportunities for the multitude of other applicants to work one on one with an artist for a semester. I am proud to say that our gallery interns continue to return and offer their assistance and support for our projects. This has been a testament to the value that our program provides. Emily Dahlquist, a Columbia College student, interned for us during the Spring Semester of 2012 and returned to see how she could help out over the summer. “9 months ago, I sat down with Kim, the owner of Elephant Room. I instantly felt that this was a genuine exchange and valuable opportunity for growth. The artist assistance program began the semester I started working there. Artists helping artists made for a perfect collaboration of business and artistic expression. I was placed with a local Chicago artist later on and in the past 3 months I’ve grown professionally more than I ever would have thought. I’ve gained hands on experience in my field and my eyes have been opened to so many amazing opportunities. I feel so much more advanced in my field and I can’t wait to see what’s ahead!” - Dahlquist

We have received increased press for our exhibitions as we continue to push our activities out into the press world.

In May of 2010, Newcity wrote an excellent review on Jennifer Cronin’s “The Peculiar Manifestation of Paint in My Life”. http://art.newcity.com/2010/05/04/review-jennifer-croninelephant-room/

Chicago Artists Resource featured Sam Kirk for the “Common Ground” exhibition in October of 2010. http://www.chicagoartistsresource.org/visual-arts/node/28920

In April of 2012, Donte Mearon and his “Chicago Loves Me” exhibition was a featured exhibition during Explore Chicago, celebrating the city’s 75th anniversary. http://www.explorechicagotourism.com/?p=4257

Most recently, “Love, Lust & Desire”, an exhibition of brand new work by Zeph Farmby, was written about in the Chicago Reader as the Art Critic’s Choice. http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/love-lust-and-desire-elephant-room-inc/Content?oid=7302135

Early and Continued Successes

In the first year, we worked with nine emerging artists who we continue to have relationships with and many that are no longer emerging but established artists (Sam Kirk, Jennifer Cronin, Cydney Lewis and Hebru Brantley) with loyal collectors and an explosive reputation throughout the US.

Sam Kirk was our first exhibiting artist for our grand opening in November 2009 with the exhibition, “I AM”. Over the years we have continued to follow Sam and provide invaluable support as she continues to make a name for herself. Sam recently participated in our Artist Assistance Program and is now currently in our Intern Placement Program where we have provided her with a dedicated intern to assist her with her art career. Sam is currently working on exhibitions in Chicago, Minneapolis and New York. She is certainly becoming recognizable as she continues to spread her PROVOKE CULTURE message through her art. www.iamsamkirk.com

We have continued to grow our local reputation specifically in the South Loop by participating in Chicago Artists Month, Art of Home, Explore Chicago and various South Loop Neighborhood events. We are looking forward to solidifying ourselves as a neighborhood staple by bringing the community together, both organization, individuals, and small businesses, through art.

Make some Noise

Help us get the word out by making some noise about our campaign. Share our campaign and the action you take with your friends on facebook and twitter. Be our partner as we continue to make art a relevant and important part of everyday life.

I, Kimberly Leja-Atwood, attended the University of Illinois at Chicago and earned my BFA in photography. While there, I was a part of the New Works Group, composed of my fellow peers, where we frequently put together our own photography exhibitions. My interest in gallery work grew exponentially here as I enjoyed the collaborative nature of working with other artists and having a hand in curating exhibitions from start to finish. Elephant Room was a perfect fit for my interest and skill set. As Elephant Room took shape that first year, I continued to work full time as a commercial real estate photographer while holding art exhibitions every one to two months with limited viewing hours. The gallery was run entirely by myself and my husband, James, while we both worked full time at our day jobs.


In February of 2011, a couple of weeks after giving birth to my son, Austin, we re- opened Elephant Room as a retail art gallery where we exhibited a multitude of artists and designers, while still holding exhibitions every 1-2 months with a focus on under- represented artists. In addition, we started to branch out and hold many unique events including socials, open mics, live sketch events and launch parties. We also began to host exhibitions in other unique spaces in the city and became more involved with assisting artists in hosting their own open studio events. The Artist Assistance Program began to organically emerge as we hired on more of our own gallery interns and were able to commit to working with more established artists in their studios. 
The most rewarding and unexpected element in all of this has been the strengthening of my own family unit as my husband James and I run the business together and our love for art continues to evolve. We both take our roles seriously and have learned to balance work and home life after a few years of trial and error. Our 19 month old, Austin, has been introduced to the art world from birth as he’s frequently with me at the gallery and enjoys his time there and has developed relationships with our artists just as we have. A great example of this is when James commissioned one of our long time artists, Jennifer Cronin, to paint a portrait of the three of us and our two dogs after our son Austin was born. The painting hangs in Austin’s bedroom as a constant reminder of why we’re doing this. 
The Campaign
I started Elephant Room Gallery with the intention of providing a unique space that would be both an exhibition space and a resource for the Chicago art community. By working with under-represented artists Elephant Room provided a space for an up and coming artist the ability to build their resume, gain exposure, and make contacts.
Today, Elephant Room Gallery is much more than a retail outlet and gallery space. This transition is very intentional. After a year of exhibiting emerging artists and holding openings, artist talks and workshops, we decided that we needed to do more with the community and involve even more artists and interested community members with our space. With your investment we can move Elephant Room Gallery beyond a store front and out into the community through innovative programs such as the Artist Assistance Program and the Intern Placement Program.







$15,000 will allow us to increase the number of exhibitions we put on per year from November 2012 to November 2013; strengthen our network by hosting events throughout Chicago; and ensure that each artist exhibition has a healthy marketing and promotion budget. Additionally, the funds will allow us to continue our Artist Assistance Program at no cost to the artists involved (currently they pay a nominal fee) and will expand our Intern Placement Program by reaching a larger artist and student audience through advertising. 
Perks! 
All of our perks showcase our current artists, who have generously donated their time and talents to making this campaign a success. 
$500: Zeph Farmby is currently exhibiting “Love, Lust and Desire” in our gallery and has been a strong and positive supporter of our mission. http://i-amaze-eyez.com/about/ Sam Kirk, a long time Elephant Room supporter, is a Chicago artist now moving her message to other cities. www.iamsamkirk.com
$1,000: Connie Noyes is an active participant in our Artist Assistance Program. www.connienoyes.com
$2,500: Jennifer Cronin is a rapidly emerging Chicago artist who’s paintings are now making impacts outside of the U.S. www.jennifercronin.com
If we do not reach our $15,000 goal, the funds donated will still make an impact on our organization as we work to increase our impact beyond our four walls. We will work to make up the remaining funds needed through our gallery sales to ensure that we stay on target with an increase in exhibitions and additional programming.
The Impact 
Elephant Room has successfully provided an exhibition space for emerging artists as well as a venue for artists and designers to sell their work and retain a majority of the sale while gaining valuable exposure and experience. Our focus on under-represented local artists has had amazing impact on Chicago’s art scene as we bring more attention to these individuals and thus impact the direction of their careers. Our South Loop storefront has been the hub for gatherings of many kinds that have connected people in an artistic setting and has been a great art resource for the surrounding community of students, residents and visitors. The Artist Assistance Program was developed in our second year and provides artists with that bit of extra help with both office and in-studio work that allows them to focus more on the creative and removes the overwhelming elements of self-promotion and marketing. After a year of running the Artist Assistance Program and meeting more and more artists and students who wanted to become involved, we started to pair interested students with individual artists who were in need of interns. During the summer of 2012, the Intern Placement Program was born. We are able to connect students with artists in order to provide both parties with the experience and time needed in order to further their careers in the art world.






With our limited budget, we have been able to build our exposure over the past few years and are now a recognizable name in many art circles. We receive several artist submissions per week as well as a lot of interest from both artists and students interested in our programs. We continue to operate on a smaller scale with 2-3 interns per semester so that we can focus on providing them with a valuable experience while still providing opportunities for the multitude of other applicants to work one on one with an artist for a semester. I am proud to say that our gallery interns continue to return and offer their assistance and support for our projects. This has been a testament to the value that our program provides. Emily Dahlquist, a Columbia College student, interned for us during the Spring Semester of 2012 and returned to see how she could help out over the summer. “9 months ago, I sat down with Kim, the owner of Elephant Room. I instantly felt that this was a genuine exchange and valuable opportunity for growth. The artist assistance program began the semester I started working there. Artists helping artists made for a perfect collaboration of business and artistic expression. I was placed with a local Chicago artist later on and in the past 3 months I’ve grown professionally more than I ever would have thought. I’ve gained hands on experience in my field and my eyes have been opened to so many amazing opportunities. I feel so much more advanced in my field and I can’t wait to see what’s ahead!” - Dahlquist 
We have received increased press for our exhibitions as we continue to push our activities out into the press world. 
In May of 2010, Newcity wrote an excellent review on Jennifer Cronin’s “The Peculiar Manifestation of Paint in My Life”. http://art.newcity.com/2010/05/04/review-jennifer-croninelephant-room/
Chicago Artists Resource featured Sam Kirk for the “Common Ground” exhibition in October of 2010. http://www.chicagoartistsresource.org/visual-arts/node/28920 
In April of 2012, Donte Mearon and his “Chicago Loves Me” exhibition was a featured exhibition during Explore Chicago, celebrating the city’s 75th anniversary. http://www.explorechicagotourism.com/?p=4257
Most recently, “Love, Lust & Desire”, an exhibition of brand new work by Zeph Farmby, was written about in the Chicago Reader as the Art Critic’s Choice. http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/love-lust-and-desire-elephant-room-inc/Content?oid=7302135






Early and Continued Successes 
In the first year, we worked with nine emerging artists who we continue to have relationships with and many that are no longer emerging but established artists (Sam Kirk, Jennifer Cronin, Cydney Lewis and Hebru Brantley) with loyal collectors and an explosive reputation throughout the US. 
Sam Kirk was our first exhibiting artist for our grand opening in November 2009 with the exhibition, “I AM”. Over the years we have continued to follow Sam and provide invaluable support as she continues to make a name for herself. Sam recently participated in our Artist Assistance Program and is now currently in our Intern Placement Program where we have provided her with a dedicated intern to assist her with her art career. Sam is currently working on exhibitions in Chicago, Minneapolis and New York. She is certainly becoming recognizable as she continues to spread her PROVOKE CULTURE message through her art. www.iamsamkirk.com 
We have continued to grow our local reputation specifically in the South Loop by participating in Chicago Artists Month, Art of Home, Explore Chicago and various South Loop Neighborhood events. We are looking forward to solidifying ourselves as a neighborhood staple by bringing the community together, both organization, individuals, and small businesses, through art. 
Make some Noise 
Help us get the word out by making some noise about our campaign. Share our campaign and the action you take with your friends on facebook and twitter. Be our partner as we continue to make art a relevant and important part of everyday life.

story:
*New News"

CR8 Gallery has received it's first Private Investor!   This moves the Gallery so much closer to a reality!

Seattle's Katwall construction company just signed on as investors and they are incredibly excited to be on board!  They just completed work on the Greenest Commercial Building on earth called Bullitt Center, Seattle Washington


Why A Gallery?

The experiences of food in a restaurant setting are full of rules and expectations.  My dining concepts need a platform of unlimited possiblilties.  The rules will be broken so the ideas have room to grow and give people new emotional experiences.  There is so much creativity in the form of design, art, music, nature, photography, architecture and food.  The line that brings them all together as one, will be drawn in CR8 Gallery.

So what is CR8 Gallery?

It's the first edible interactive gallery in the world. So imagine this...you enter the space and are bewildered by it's unorthodox creative installations.  In the midst of it, someone hands you a container and a utensil.  Then you get to taste the very artwork you are admiring.  This is just the beginning!

Creative and brilliant people need a place to come together to engage in and share new experiences.  Bellingham and the world will be eager to share something new and inspiring.

Who am I?


My name is Roberto Cortez and I was a Private Chef for 15 years.  I had the honor of cooking for Microsoft’s Paul Allen, Antonio Banderas, Melanie Griffith and Eddie Murphy, and some of the worlds most influential musicians.

However the world of design and art had always fascinated me.  My life changed when I saw a photo of cutlery in Elle Decor magazine and I traveled all the way to Europe just to meet the designer.  This experience fueled the creative fire that allowed me to combine my extensive culinary training in Europe with my passion for incorporating art, design and food in way that has never been done before.

What will happen there?

Imagine a scenario of experiencing Alice In Wonderland but tasting what it would be like in the story!

Or imagine different Emotions that we have all had throughout our lives, captured in photos and paintings and translated to flavors and textures for you to experience as  you explore the gallery!


"Alice",  By one of the worlds best photographers, Katarzyna Widmanska, will be part of the Sounds Of Wonderland Exhibition....
 
 These photos will be part of the first exhibition in the CR8 Gallery.  An exploration of emotions and flavors.

Who is involved?

There will be a plethora of designers from around the world showcasing their work here.  From Bellingham we have Greg Klassen designing the spectacular table.  From London, we have Andreas Fabian and his spectacular designs.  From Berlin we will have Hering and their magnificent porcelain.  This is just the beginning!

CR8 Dining Experimental

I began experimenting with those concepts in 2011 by forming in Los Angeles a dining group called "CR8" (pronounced "Create").  Since then I have done 8 conceptual dining installations, each completely unique in the way it shattered all rules!  Quickly CR8 became popular and recognized by people around the world.   

It became clear that CR8 needs a permanent home and CR8 Gallery is intended to be that place.  The dining concepts will change every few months and they will encompass some of the best local and global talent to manifest the vision.

Follow the link to explore the magical world of CR8 Dining Experimental

http://www.robertocortez.com/blog/category/cr8-dining-experimental/

*The dining environment from one of CR8's dinners known as "Dark Illuminated Forest"

The first dining concept in the Gallery space will be called "UnNatural"  Will you experience it?

Super sensory manipulation and expansion in a dining environ. Come feel what is possible through creativity!
 
How much do we need?

We need to reach our goal of $543,000.  We have the perfect space located and all the players are in place.  Local designers, architects, interior designers and innovative business minds are all on board and excited to bring CR8 Gallery to life. The world will be such a more positive, creative and enchanting world with the CR8 Gallery in it! 

What Will Your Money Be Used For?

Here is what it get's us:

$193K Kitchen equipment, plates, cutlery, glasses, table, chairs, lighting, etc

$350K Construction cost, designing, architect fees, etc, hiring start up, etc

How else can you help?
Thanks for passing on the word to your friends and colleagues with Indigogo share tools!

story:
Campaign has ended! We didn't quite reach our goal but this project will continue to happen. Donations are still being accepted and can be sent to Info@u1hproductions.com 

Thank you to everyone who gave us a start one this project :)

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

The 7 Deadly Sins series will consist of seven models each representing one of the 7 Deadly Sins: wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony. We will have various body painters that will each be designated one or more of the sins and will have open creativity to define their interpretation of that sin(s). My partner and I will be building a coffin designed not only for the series shoot but to take on art tours to be used as a photo booth for attendees to stand inside and get their photo taken.

The photo shoot will entail of the model climbing in the coffin and being shot from various angles. These photos will be done individually as well as composited into one larger photo with each coffin side by side.

Our hopes are to begin this project in early July 2013 and completed by May 2014. We will also be documenting this process and creating a Behind the Scenes video to hopefully be completed May 2014.

Funds will be used to pay body painters, models, make-up/hair artist, purchase supplies for painting, make-up, set design, renting a flash kit and any unexpected materials to complete project.

story:
The Infinite Portal For Sunshine

 

A multi-aspect campaign that raises funds for 3 purposes:

 

 

 

 

 

 

~ A Burning Man art installation officially confirmed as part of Fractal Planet 2013, entitled: “The SunShrine” Memorializing everything that Sunshine Daydreamer was all about...

 

 

 

 

 

~ A two day gathering taking place two weeks after burning man, at both of his stomping grounds, MI and CA, simultaneously, by means of live streaming, on video projection screens on the sites, and live on the internet, so that friends and pham who can't make it to burningman and or the other side of the country, can be together in his honor...


 

 

~ And finally as a charity for his amazing mother Nancy, who is recovering from 2 back surgeries, and about to head overseas for her next teaching journey to Turkey this August....

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Sunshine Daydreamer memorial fundraiser update #1:

 

Greetings friends and pham!

 

We wanted to give you all an update on the status of the project now that we are back from our 2 week journey at Electric Forest.

 

We are soo grateful for the recent outpouring of support and sharing all over the internets by such wonderful people... it means so much, please continue whenever you feel inspired to!

 

We have 2 points we wanted to address in this update:

 

1.) We know that some of you do not have access to a bank card, and we have devised a method for’ ya’ll to use cash, and have it end up showing up as a legitimate donation on the Indiegogo fundraising page.

 

.

 

2.) We wanted to make clear why our goal is what it is, and how the outlined budget adapts to the charity fund for Sunny’s Mother based on what we raise.



Our outlined budget does not reflect a certain amount that we are trying to raise for Nancy. Our intention is raise more than the goal, because if we do, Indiegogo only charges a 4% fee. If we do not reach the goal, they charge us 9% on whatever we raise.

 

We have planned for this possibility, by making our budget adaptable. The burning man memorial art installation can be scaled back to half the size, or scrapped altogether if the amount stays lower than say $5K for instance. We will still be able to throw the gathering, and give all of the remaining sum to Nancy.

 

However, we have our sights set high right now. With less than 40 days remaining, we would like to proceed with ordering a very small batch of test materials, and start getting our hands dirty building and perfecting a proof of concept test slice.

 

We would only need a couple hundred to start that crucial process, and we are almost there currently.




Nextly, to explain the cash donation method that we have come up with for those of you or your friends who don't have bank cards:

 

Any Bank of America branch in the country will allow a cash deposit into someone’s BoA checking account, provided you have that someone’s account number.

 

That someone will be Scotty, and then he will take that exact amount and donate it into the Indiegogo project as an official donation, which could include your name, or could remain anonymous.

 

If that sounds like it might work for you, please message either Scotty or Wolfgang on facebook.

 

facebook.com/scottsutt

facebook.com/okolleck

 

WE LOVE YOU

 


 

^^^ END OF UPDATE #1 ^^^

 

 

About Sunshine:

 

 

 

Any of us who had the pleasure of being around Sunny would agree that he was one of the most inspiring people that we had ever experienced. His light was soo positive and powerfully beautiful.

 

 

 

He was all about infinite possibilities and co-creating with others in manifesting dreams, no matter how big they might have been.

 

 

 

When sunlight is split by a prism, the rainbow that lies within it is revealed. He revealed his inner rainbows to everyone he came in touch with.

 

 

 

He was here to help save the world with his spirit, and that hasn't changed. he knows it better than we do, and the handful of times where he has appeared to us in our dream state, glowing as bright as ever, proves that point.

 

 

 

Description of The Burning Man Art installation Memorial:

 

 

 

We are creating a playful yet reflective space, that outwardly reflects sunshine to people headed in any direction, and reveals  everyone's inner rainbow infinity on the inside, by way of the principle of the infinite mirror effect, combined with a flowy sea of furry, dreamy LED rainbows that literally have no end.

 

 

 

We won’t be burning the structure, because its is designed to be infinite, and travel wherever it is called to. the next destination will be his simulcasted portal gathering event, which is outlined above, and will take place 2 weeks after burning man. if you can't be there in person, you can still be there in spirit, due to the "google hangouts on air" internet broadcast, which is one of the rewards offered for supporting this memorial fundraising campaign.

 

 

 

Another reward is knowing that you are supporting his amazing mother Nancy in a time of need.

 

 

 

And yet another reward for supporting this will be getting to see this amazingly playful yet infinitely reflective art piece come into manifestation, in honor of the spirit of Sunshine Daydreamer.

 

 

 

Early Draft rendering at the below, the big video is coming soon!

 

http://youtu.be/cIA5t6UFkr8

 

 

 

More Information on the 2 day Memorial Gathering is also coming soon, stay tuned for updates!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to afford an event pass, but do not want to miss it, feel free to write us, and include how you could volunteer, which could simply be sharing this campaign over social media, or working at the kitchen at the event, etc...

 

Cost Breakdown:

 

 

 

  • Optical-grade Mylar for glassless Mirrors = $2100

  • Framing Materials: = $1050

  • LEDs, Wiring Hardware, Controllers = $1400

  • Durable, comfy, riggable flooring Foam, floor Fur + hardware = $1100

  • Helium, and hardware for custom space baloons = $300

  • Solar free energy powering system = $1000

  • Truck Rental + Gas = $2000

3 Burning man tix for core building group = $1200

 

 

2-day Event Costs:

 

  • Video Tech crews + projectors and screens for event = $1500

  • event hospitality (food, beverage, etc.) = $500

 

 

 

=$12,150

 

 

 

CONTEXT OF CHARITY FUND:

 

Sunny was so into manifesting big ideas that could help free the world, he took a loan out on his mother's home (with her blessing) to invest in that ideal. Nancy is one of the most amazingly awesome widows that any of us has ever met - she's going to Turkey in August 2013 to teach children for crying out loud! This lady deserves a spaceship. We plan to get her one.

 

 

 

 

https://www.facebook.com/sunshine.daydreamer.3

Framing Materials: = $1050


LEDs, Wiring Hardware, Controllers = $1400


Durable, comfy, riggable flooring Foam, floor Fur + hardware = $1100


Helium, and hardware for custom space baloons = $300


Solar free energy powering system = $1000


Truck Rental + Gas = $2000


3 Burning man tix for core building group = $1200
 
 
2-day Event Costs:
 


Video Tech crews + projectors and screens for event = $1500


event hospitality (food, beverage, etc.) = $500


 
 
 
=$12,150
 
 
 
CONTEXT OF CHARITY FUND:
 
Sunny was so into manifesting big ideas that could help free the world, he took a loan out on his mother's home (with her blessing) to invest in that ideal. Nancy is one of the most amazingly awesome widows that any of us has ever met - she's going to Turkey in August 2013 to teach children for crying out loud! This lady deserves a spaceship. We plan to get her one.
 
 
 
 
https://www.facebook.com/sunshine.daydreamer.3

story:
My name is Hromovy (hrah-MOE-vee)

I will be having a solo show in Chicago, Illinois at the Leather Archives and Museum, June 13th 2014.


The Artist and Patron relationship has been a critical component of the creative process for hundreds of years in the history of art.  Patrons have provided the necessary financial support that has allowed artists to focus on creativity and freedom of expression while minimizing the distraction of outside influences.  Patrons have also helped create the public and private spaces to promote the Artist’s work so that others may benefit from their creativity as well. 

The Family Tree

The Family Tree will be a life sized installation piece created specifically for the exhibition.


Using parts of images taken over the course of a year I will create a collage that becomes a crucified body. Each image will be of a person that is part of the leather community.

I intend to shoot as many different representatives of our community as possible.


  As a marginalized community, I believe we are ignored or reviled. My portraiture has always been about bringing dignity to those who often can't find acceptance in the world we live in.

My studio, DivaFoto uses the tag line; "Glamour for the rest of us". This piece will bring us together as a whole. What better place to premier it than the Leather Archives and Museum.

 

Mutagenesis /mu·ta·gen·e·sis : The formation/development of a mutation... and my latest series of work


While some images are more obvious than others, my intent is to create art that provokes and intrigues.

Much of my past work is very literal. I have taken documentary style images on 35 mm and large format film and combined them digitally with the purpose to explore the relationship of elements.


When creating these images I had no clear idea of the results I would achieve; I let the images do the talking. The individual elements were chosen for their contrasting nature.

The images were not created with a specific intent but rather by listening to what the individual pieces said when contrasting elements were brought together. Some images were shot specifically for the "Mutagenisis" series and others are from my archives or other project series.

The introduction of electricity to the mix, in the form of a computer program, allowed me produce work that provides a fresh look at common objects.


These digital double exposures have created much interest in my work since my successful solo show in Kansas City, MO in 2012.

All images are done in limited signed and numbered editions: Mutagensis is limited to 10 of each image. Family Tree will be a one off. Only one ever produced.

I received my first camera at the age of 5, was trained as an apprentice lapidary and jeweler from age 7 and have rarely held a “real” job.

I have received numerous awards for my 3D media artworks in: glass, metal, jewelry, and mixed media.

Having made the decision to concentrate solely on Photography, in 2000, I have been awarded various honors including:

  • 3 images chosen as Kodak Image of the Day
  • A piece included in the Peabody/Essex museum (Salem, Mass) collection that details new trends in modern art.
  • I have shown in numerous juried exhibitions receiving awards in many of them.
  • I am the official photographer and documentarian for South Plains Leatherfest / International Master/slave weekend in Dallas, Texas.

What will your patronage support?

  1. $3950 is needed to produce the actual pieces to be installed. 
  2. $700 in shipping from San Antonio to Chicago
  3. $1400 in travel and related expenses to collect the images for The Family Tree
  4. $450 for promotional materials

 

Why doesn't my campaign ask for the full amount?

Of course I'm hoping for more donations than I'm asking. The percentage that is taken from the amount donated is higher if you don't meet your goal.  So setting a lower goal is a better financial decision.

The $4500 goal will make sure I can produce the actual art for the show. If I receive more than the goal that will cover more of the expenses I have estimated.  Should the funding exceed the estimated cost, I will be able to produce a larger installation and cover more of what I have already spent.

(As of the launch date, over $800)

Everyone is invited to the opening!

Updates will be posted here along with some of the new images as they are finished.

I understand the limitations of today's economy. If you could help by spreading the word of this project to your friends I would greatly appreciate your support in this way. Thank you for your interest in my work.

Update! Sept. 2nd

New work is progressing nicely.  Here is part of one of the new pieces. It's called

"the little green fairy".

story:
Thank you everyone!!!  Between the two campaigns we raised over $4,200 from over 50 donors!  And while we didn't reach our ultimate goal, we did make enough to fulfill all the perks with just a little extra for production items we really needed to start making this movie!  So we're on our way!

Thank you all so much for your support every single donation made a HUGE difference!

If you want to continue supporting our film, you can visit our website ZombieElves.com where you can still donate and receive some of the same awesome perks!

Also, be sure to "like" our Facebook Page.

These incredible hand-painted watercolors were originally created by Illustrator Nikki Rossignol as concept art for the independent feature film, "Zombie Elves".  

$10 gets you a Digital Download 8.5" x 11" version of the calendar that you can access and print on your home printer right now!  You'll also get FREE wallpaper images for Nov and Dec 2011 that you can use now as well!  We will also include this digital download with any printed calendar contributions.


Meet The Artist:

Nikki Rossignol is the talented artist behind our unique calendar.  She is incredibly talented at everything she challenges herself to accomplish.  She is a model, an actress, a trained dancer and a brilliant artist.


The Zombie Elves 2012 Wall Calendar

Each month features a whimsical depiction of the little Zombie Elves in mischevious situations. 

These glossy calendars make great Christmas gifts and will look great on any zombie lovers wall!  




The Deal

Our goal is to raise enough money to get 1,000 calendars printed.  So we only need 210 people to contribute $25 each to reach our of $5,250.00 for the printing costs.

There is a 3-4 week turnaround and Christmas is just around the corner so our goal is to have all the money raised no later than November 14, 2011 to have the calendars printed and shipped in time for Christmas.

This is the holiday season and the time of year that people are buying their 2012 calendars, so we need to get the ball rolling!

FREE 8.5" x 11" Digital Download Version - You can print today at home!

For any donation you will INSTANTLY receive a specially designed 14 MONTH digital version of the calendar that starts with this month, November 2011.  This is an instantly downloadable PDF file that can be printed on any home printer at 8.5" x 11" on any kind of paper.  This PDF version was designed specifically to printed month by month at home and is a different design from the 12" x 12" printed version.


*BONUS  Anyone who contributors will also receive a FREE November 2011 Wallpaper jpg file that you can instantly download to your desktop as soon as you donate!




All contributors who choose the printed versions will automatically receive the Digital Download versions for FREE!


Other Ways You Can Help

If Zombie Elves just aren't your thing, maybe you have a friend who loves zombies.  If you like the artwork, or just want to help support a cool art project, please forward this link to your friends. 


http://www.indiegogo.com/zombiecalendar


Thank you!!!

story:
Our Story

Hi, My name is Gretchen McLaren and I am a jeweler, blacksmith and yoga teacher from Raleigh, NC.  The plight of women and young girls in India is a story that deeply resonates with me. 

In one month's time, I will be moving to India for 6 months, volunteering with a group of orphanages in South India.  I will be setting up a studio at one of the orphanages, teaching the girls and village women how to make jewelry. Together we will design a line of jewelry that they will produce, and then I will bring the finished product back to the US to market, distribute and sell for them.  All the money from the sale of the line will go directly back to the women less material costs. 

My intention is to be of service to these women and girls and to create a sustainable, green business for them.  My work is completely volunteer based.  This $5,000 that I am asking is for travel and expenses to support me while I am working on this project for 6 months.  It is my hope that this campaign will exceed my wildest expectations and that I will also be able to buy additional tools and materials for the community.

We will start simple and small.  I will be taking one suitcase of tools and materials to set up the studio, but I am hoping that the project will grow in time and that the original studio will be better outfitted, and that we be able to replicate the project in 16 other orphanages in South India.


The Impact


I will be teaching these women a marketable skill, thereby giving them a means so that they can provide for themselves. The impact of the hope project on these girls and women is tremendous.  With the income they earn from the sale of the jewelry line, they will be able to pay for their own education, support their families and provide a dowry for themselves. 

It is my goal to simply change the course of just one life.  If I reach that goal then I will feel like this project has been successful.  

What We Need & What You Get

I was chosen by a non-profit organization to go on this trip and complete this project.  They are providing part of my airfare and room and board in the orphanage for 6 months.  There are expenses that are not being covered by this organization and that is why I am launching this campaign.  There will be no salary as this is completely volunteer.  I have given up my home, my studio and resigned from my jobs in order to go to do this.  To be clear, your contribution to this $5000 is allowing me to complete this journey.  A portion of this money will go towards purchasing a few extra tools and materials, and a laptop to teach, consult and start the business for this community.

Thank you gifts for contributing:

$25:  Mala Beads from India that have been blessed in the Holy Ganges personally by me 

$100:  A piece from the girls jewelry line.  This special thank you piece will be separate from the line, made by me, in India, inspired by working with the girls.

$500: An Indian vegetarian meal cooked by me. 

$1000:  A private yoga class taught by me.

All thank you gifts will be sent upon return from India.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please Please Please share this on Facebook, Twitter, Linked In, email, text or by word of mouth!

Even if you can't contribute financially, your support means so much to me by passing this campaign on to your community.  Thank you!

story:
Overview:

Hello All!! Thank you for stopping by my indiegogo page. This page was made to help me fund gallery showings of my new  painting series, where I recreate romance novel covers to provoke dialogue on modern culture.  My purpose for doing this is to present the figures in these narrative paintings as symbols of power, identity, gender, race, class, culture, and ethnicity.  This show will be my final showing  as a graduate student at The University of the Arts in Philadelphia, PA, and I also have another showing in Columbus, OH.

The reason for my indiegogo page is to help me procure supplies for creating, storing, and renting a van to drive work to the gallery sites. I am also need to obtain 10ft. rolls of Tyvek 10gx and 107"in., seamless background paper to create new paintings on. The bulk of funding for helping me utilize a studio facility to paint the large scale pieces, and store them. This show is very important, not only to me and my practice, but I think it will definitely be a stepping stone for my career, and will help me become the painter and professional I know I can be.

All contributions are an investment into this project. The hope is for these paintings to provoke new dialogues on our identities. It is my snapshot of the human condition. Sometimes we are more complex than what we project to world, and sometimes we are not, and that is the balance of us as a people. In the end, the paintings celebrate our differences, and push us to celebrate love, life, our realities, and strives to present our authentic selves.
 
REWARDS!!!
 
Five donation reward packages are up for grabs! $25 donation places you on the email mailing list for instant video updates, live streaming, and emails of progress during summer of painting! $50 gets you a custom Sketch Butler t-shirt designed specifically for the My Idyll painting series, and Hi-res digital copies of the painting series sent to your email!! $100 gets you a custom Sketch Butler hoodie designed specifically for the My Idyll painting series, and digital copies of the painting series!! $250 you receive a t-shirt and a autographed hardcover book of all paintings! And $500 you receive a book of paintings, and a custom painted 16x20 portrait (up to 2 people)!! And rewards #1-4! ALL IN LIMITED AMOUNTS!!
 
**Even if you have nothing to give I am still rewarding those willing to help me promote this page the most!! If you share this page with the most people you can (Sharing and tagging people), and get others to donate, I will send you FREE DIGITAL CARICATURES, OR HI RES SKETCH BUTLER ORIGINAL ART sent to your email!! So everyone wins here!!
 
I thank you all so much for stopping by, and thank you from the bottom of my heart for your donations and help to see this dream become a reality!! I don't take it for granted. THANK YOU, THANK YOU, THANK YOU!!
 
--David Sketch Butler
