story:
A central part of The Institute for Art and Olfaction’s programming mission lies in creating opportunity for innovative ideas and executions around scent. Launching in May 2013, our residency program will pair creative practitioners with fragrance professionals. Together, they will implement specific cross-genre creative projects that involve a strong olfactive element.
 
To help make this happen, we are creating an accessible space in downtown Los Angeles that provides support, experimentaton and access. This experimental laboratory will be supplied with scent-making supplies, a library and a classroom.
 
But, we need your help.

FIRST, A LITTLE ABOUT US.

We're launching The Institue for Art and Olfaction to help support independent work in perfumery. We want to highlight the innovation and artistry in perfumery, to instigate greater engagement with the art and science around scent, to juxtapose it with other creative practices, and to bring it into the bigger world. We will do this through a public education program, by building an archive of contemporary perfume releases, by creating an accessible laboratory for scent experimentation, and – most importantly – by inciting cross-genre collaboration between perfumers and folks on the cutting edge of other fields.

In connecting these different types of people with olfactory experts, and in encouraging them to experiment outside of their comfort zones, we hope to facilitate strange and beautiful new projects. With our help, an aerospace engineer might collaborate with a perfumer to create a scent for outer space, a designer might develop a typeface around the idea of ‘gourmand’, or a homeless teenager might work with a molecular biologist to re-create the scent of fear at midnight.
 
It's worth noting at this point that the IAO is a not-for-profit enterprise, fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, and wholly devoted to artistic experimentation and access.
 

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS, YOU ASK?

 We spent years trying to gain access to information and education about perfumery: It's pretty hard to come by, and tends to be rather exclusive. Populists at heart, we believe that perfumery is an art medium that deserves the attention of the greater public. So we've elected to provide the education and access ourselves.
 
Our background in fine art also gives us the motivation to apply the tinkering artist mentality to scent. Rather than focussing on 'pretty' sellable scents, we are hoping to stretch the conceptual potential for perfumery by opening it up to folks outside the field.
 
There are some incredible people working with perfume as an art form, but to our knowledge, we are the only space that allows this level of access to the practice. We're one of a kind!

THIS CAMPAIGN

BRASS TACKS: THE LABORATORY.

This campaign is about raising funds for a specific project: Launching an experimental perfume laboratory.

 We have access to a robust perfumers' organ (check!), we have our space nailed down (check!). What we are missing are very specific things:
  • Chairs for the educational space
  • Laboratory tables
  • Large blackboards for your ideas
  • Scent-making equipment (atomizers! beakers! pipettes! mouillettes!)
  • Two iBalance scales
  • A mixer
  • Scent vials
  • And bits and pieces such as lights, and a houseplant
A creative space, our lab nonetheless has very specific goals. We will implement a program of public courses and events starting in March 2013, and - through our collaborative residency program -  the lab will host two trans-media art projects in 2013. In fact, we already launched our special projects: A collaboration with perfumer Josh Meyer and filmmaker Mark Harris. Check it out here!
 
We are also hard at work creating community partnerships with underserved populations. Our hope is to introduce the art and science of perfumery to folks who would have little access to it. Our particular focus is on homeless teenagers.

If you are curious about what the heck an experimental collaborative perfume lab might look like, are interested in seeing experimentation in scent, or just want to promote access to education... Well those are three very good reasons to fund us.
 
In exchange, we'll keep you involved in the process, and make sure you reap the benefits of our work. At the very least, you can consider yourself our elite test audience for a potentially amazing process. But there are also opportunities to become more involved. In fact, if you have questions you can email us anytime at hello@artandolfaction.com.
 
BUT, WHAT'S THIS ABOUT BOOKS?
 
Part of our mission at IAO is to provide accessible education. The first step towards this is to build a lending library of scent-related books. We're starting small: We've asked our community on Facebook and our board of advisors to propose their suggestion of the essential books for scent education. We're hoping that you will help us purchase those books by, well, adopting them, one at a time.
 
We've added a new perk at $35: Adopt-a-book. When you kick in at this level you're not only allowing us to provide a well-curated selection of books to the folks coming through the IAO, you're also helping us build the infrastructure around the library.
 
When you adopt-a-book, we'll send you our wish list of recommended books, and you can choose the one you want to adopt. Or, suggest your own (scent-related, of course).
 
ARE THERE RISKS TO ALL THIS? YOU BETCHA.

We are fully confident that we will be running a very successful arts organization by the end of 2013. But, like with any non-profit, there is a risk of failure.
 
Luckily, the challenges that the IAO faces relate entirely to the level of elbow grease we put in, not to mention our capacity to formulate and implement oblique solutions. Since we have the space, it becomes a question then of sustaining the effort.
 
So, barring any natural disasters or acts of god, we have full confidence that we will be launching to the public, on schedule, by March 2013.

WANT TO HELP BUT DON'T HAVE ANY CASH TO SPARE?

We can use your support in other valuable ways!

  • Tweet about this project: Support the creation of an experimental perfume laboratory. @artandolfaction has an indie-go-go campaign: indiegogo.com/artandfolfaction
  • Facebook 'like' us: Our Facebook page is here
  • Email your friends about this campaign: The link to point them to is indiegogo.com/artandolfaction
  • Donate educational materials: Books, scent-making ingredients, office supplies, blackboard paint... We need it all. Email us directly at hello@artandolfaction.com

WHAT THE PRESS SAYS

Yeah, we're sort of proud, but we've received some good press already about the IAO.

  • Check out the LA Weekly article about the IAO: Here
  • Read an interview with founder Saskia Wilson-Brown for KCET: Here.
story_txt:
A central part of The Institute for Art and Olfaction’s programming mission lies in creating opportunity for innovative ideas and executions around scent. Launching in May 2013, our residency program will pair creative practitioners with fragrance professionals. Together, they will implement specific cross-genre creative projects that involve a strong olfactive element.
 
To help make this happen, we are creating an accessible space in downtown Los Angeles that provides support, experimentaton and access. This experimental laboratory will be supplied with scent-making supplies, a library and a classroom.
 
But, we need your help.
FIRST, A LITTLE ABOUT US.

We're launching The Institue for Art and Olfaction to help support independent work in perfumery. We want to highlight the innovation and artistry in perfumery, to instigate greater engagement with the art and science around scent, to juxtapose it with other creative practices, and to bring it into the bigger world. We will do this through a public education program, by building an archive of contemporary perfume releases, by creating an accessible laboratory for scent experimentation, and – most importantly – by inciting cross-genre collaboration between perfumers and folks on the cutting edge of other fields.
In connecting these different types of people with olfactory experts, and in encouraging them to experiment outside of their comfort zones, we hope to facilitate strange and beautiful new projects. With our help, an aerospace engineer might collaborate with a perfumer to create a scent for outer space, a designer might develop a typeface around the idea of ‘gourmand’, or a homeless teenager might work with a molecular biologist to re-create the scent of fear at midnight.
 
It's worth noting at this point that the IAO is a not-for-profit enterprise, fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, and wholly devoted to artistic experimentation and access.
 

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS, YOU ASK?

 We spent years trying to gain access to information and education about perfumery: It's pretty hard to come by, and tends to be rather exclusive. Populists at heart, we believe that perfumery is an art medium that deserves the attention of the greater public. So we've elected to provide the education and access ourselves.
 
Our background in fine art also gives us the motivation to apply the tinkering artist mentality to scent. Rather than focussing on 'pretty' sellable scents, we are hoping to stretch the conceptual potential for perfumery by opening it up to folks outside the field.
 
There are some incredible people working with perfume as an art form, but to our knowledge, we are the only space that allows this level of access to the practice. We're one of a kind!
THIS CAMPAIGN
BRASS TACKS: THE LABORATORY.This campaign is about raising funds for a specific project: Launching an experimental perfume laboratory.
 We have access to a robust perfumers' organ (check!), we have our space nailed down (check!). What we are missing are very specific things:


Chairs for the educational space
Laboratory tables
Large blackboards for your ideas
Scent-making equipment (atomizers! beakers! pipettes! mouillettes!)
Two iBalance scales
A mixer
Scent vials
And bits and pieces such as lights, and a houseplant



A creative space, our lab nonetheless has very specific goals. We will implement a program of public courses and events starting in March 2013, and - through our collaborative residency program -  the lab will host two trans-media art projects in 2013. In fact, we already launched our special projects: A collaboration with perfumer Josh Meyer and filmmaker Mark Harris. Check it out here!

 
We are also hard at work creating community partnerships with underserved populations. Our hope is to introduce the art and science of perfumery to folks who would have little access to it. Our particular focus is on homeless teenagers.

If you are curious about what the heck an experimental collaborative perfume lab might look like, are interested in seeing experimentation in scent, or just want to promote access to education... Well those are three very good reasons to fund us.
 
In exchange, we'll keep you involved in the process, and make sure you reap the benefits of our work. At the very least, you can consider yourself our elite test audience for a potentially amazing process. But there are also opportunities to become more involved. In fact, if you have questions you can email us anytime at hello@artandolfaction.com.

 
BUT, WHAT'S THIS ABOUT BOOKS?
 
Part of our mission at IAO is to provide accessible education. The first step towards this is to build a lending library of scent-related books. We're starting small: We've asked our community on Facebook and our board of advisors to propose their suggestion of the essential books for scent education. We're hoping that you will help us purchase those books by, well, adopting them, one at a time.
 
We've added a new perk at $35: Adopt-a-book. When you kick in at this level you're not only allowing us to provide a well-curated selection of books to the folks coming through the IAO, you're also helping us build the infrastructure around the library.
 
When you adopt-a-book, we'll send you our wish list of recommended books, and you can choose the one you want to adopt. Or, suggest your own (scent-related, of course).
 

ARE THERE RISKS TO ALL THIS? YOU BETCHA. We are fully confident that we will be running a very successful arts organization by the end of 2013. But, like with any non-profit, there is a risk of failure.
 
Luckily, the challenges that the IAO faces relate entirely to the level of elbow grease we put in, not to mention our capacity to formulate and implement oblique solutions. Since we have the space, it becomes a question then of sustaining the effort.
 
So, barring any natural disasters or acts of god, we have full confidence that we will be launching to the public, on schedule, by March 2013.
WANT TO HELP BUT DON'T HAVE ANY CASH TO SPARE?
We can use your support in other valuable ways!


Tweet about this project: Support the creation of an experimental perfume laboratory. @artandolfaction has an indie-go-go campaign: indiegogo.com/artandfolfaction

Facebook 'like' us: Our Facebook page is here


Email your friends about this campaign: The link to point them to is indiegogo.com/artandolfaction

Donate educational materials: Books, scent-making ingredients, office supplies, blackboard paint... We need it all. Email us directly at hello@artandolfaction.com

WHAT THE PRESS SAYS
Yeah, we're sort of proud, but we've received some good press already about the IAO.

Check out the LA Weekly article about the IAO: Here

Read an interview with founder Saskia Wilson-Brown for KCET: Here.

story:
Detail from "Thick & Full  Therapy", 2009 INTRODUCTION

Hello, I am Susan Smereka. Many of you know my work and have supported my artistic endeavors over the years. I am grateful for the community that has kept me going while I have created art while working full-time.

Now I am thrilled to have a new opportunity for uninterrupted time to focus on my art making in the community of New City Galerie in Burlington, Vermont. My residency begins May 1st  and will culminate with a show in November 2015. The group show will feature book arts and my new video installation.

I am seeking your help to make this possible.

I am hoping to raise $7,000 to take the time off from work and make the most of this expanse of time. The money will help to cover my living expenses as well as cost of art supplies. During the residency, I will create a body of new work described below. I will assist with the curating artists books for the culminating show. I also plan to organize and offer workshops on book arts.

BACKGROUND

My work with book arts and hair drawing began in 2008 during my art residency at the Helen Wurlitzer Foundation in Taos, New Mexico. There, I began gluing hair on to paper and then later into blank journals. The meditative, methodical, repetitive process helped with the physical problems I was having at the time. I used the hair that I collected from my brush and the shower.  During that residency I also created a few unique hand bound wordless books. I explored different ways ink was absorbed into paper and cloth. I, then, complied them into hand bound unique books. They are about texture and nuance.

In 2009, I received a grant from the Vermont Arts Council to take a letterpress class in New York. From there, I interned with Classic Letterpress in Oakland, CA (where it was located at the time). During this 7 month period, to deepen my practice, I served as a volunteer at the San Francisco Center For Book Arts. I tried my hand at altered books, book binding, cloth box building and letterpress books.

Video work has been an interest since 2005 when I worked in collaboration with Karen McGregor and Jane Horner on our collaborative video installation, Hidden Room. Since then I have experimented with the media and a handful of results have been posted my youtube channel.

Monoprinting has come to me through a grant I received to work at Two Rivers Printmaking Studio (TRPS) in White River Junction, Vermont. I have been printing since 2000 and have taught monoprinting workshops at both TRPS and at Burlington City Arts.

THE WORK

Six months will allow me the time and the freedom to explore book arts, video, hair drawing and monoprinting, I enjoy the complexity that comes with a multitude of materials and ideas. My goal during this residence is to discover, or let surface, the relationships between these media. My list of things I would like to work on during my residency looks like this;

  • compile 3 printed books from scanned drawings The drawings for these small (6" x 6") books originated from a year of Daily Drawings  (2008-2009). I will have them them mechanically printed and perfect bound (a glued binding).
  • create a new video inspired by ideas and concepts explored over the the last 4 years; for example one source are these photos I took of windows in San Francisco. I will be creating an object/surface for the video to be projected on.
  • create a book of drawings and excerpts from my aunt's letters who passed away a number of years ago. This is a continuation of the work that I did with "Repair".
  • create several large scale hair drawings (the hair work will also figure into the video).
  • work on large monoprints.
  • assist with the curration of the show.
  • offer and organize book arts workshops.

One of the things I find exciting about concentrated, focused time, in a lovely, new to me studio space is the gift of working through ideas and concepts more quickly. 

COMMUNITY AND CONNECTION 

It will be a inspiring opportunity to make more network with book artists in Burlington and throughout Vermont. I will continue to work in the Burlington City Arts printmaking studio to do the work on my monoprints. For my video work I will participate in Vermont Community Access Media's (VCAM) program which loans equipment and shares their expertise for airing on their TV channel (15).

I will be growing community through the culminating exhibit, workshops on book arts, TV and the gallery. The community building aspect adds to the ongoing work of artists that contribute to the vitality of Vermont.

PERKS

All the the perks are unique works of art (excluding the printed books). You can view some samples of the clothes pin drawings along with the installation "Repair"  I did in 2012. Images of the large, framed hair drawings can be seen here. Framed work includes these mixed media cloths pin drawings. I have both framed and unframed mixed media hair drawings.

                                                                                                        accordion hair book, 2009

                                                                                                               recycled journals, 2011

                                                                                      two unique hand bound books, 2010 

On the "Gallery" tab you will find images of work that fall into the perk for those of you that want to make a 'down payment'. (On the "gallery" tab there are also 2 videos of work I have done - one a video and one a documentation of a multimedia installation) For any of the perks, I would love for to you coming by my place to pick out exactly which piece you would like.

I will include a 'surprise' (another work of art) with each contribution. This additional perk is a way to say how much it means to me that you believe in the importance of art and community.

Even if you can’t help financially, you can still help by passing the campaign on to others that might. Please sign up for my blog or send me a reply with your email so that I can keep you abreast of events as they approach.  Another way to show your support is to come to one of the workshops that will occur during my residency. Keep in mind that the show in November will have a call for artists who have books and related book ideas to share. I'll keep you posted on the workshops and the call to artists. I look forward to working with you in whatever way is presented.

story:
Short Summary

We are the participating seniors of The Missouri State University 2015 BFA Actor Training Program Los Angeles Industry Showcase. 

Every spring, seniors in the BFA Acting and Musical Theatre programs at Missouri State University travel to Los Angeles California to participate in a capstone to their undergraduate training: The L.A. Showcase.

Our showcase is a one-hour performance that will include ten scenes featuring the twenty actors of this spring’s graduating class.


What We Need & What You Get

Traveling, eating, securing accommodations, and mailing hundreds of headshots and resumes to industry professionals racks up quite a bill.

Any financial assistance you can provide is greatly appreciated and will not go to waste.

Our goal is $4,000 and we only have sixty days.


The Impact

What’s the point?

The audience. Every year, Los Angeles Acting Industry professionals and Missouri State University alumni attend this showcase.


This is our first step into the professional acting industry. It's a chance to be considered for agency representation and network with professionals and alumni.

The week in Los Angeles also includes numerous professional development workshops.

The Showcase, our supplemental workshops, and alumni events all afford us the opportunity to enter this industry more equipped for success.


Risks & Challenges

Being a full time student with part time jobs with bills to pay, classes to attend, and futures to plan for makes financing a major trip the west coast rather daunting.
Not every student is financially equipped to raise and spend the money necessary, which may impact the actual participation. 
With your contribution, those fears are subsided. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If someone you know is featured in our campaign video, please share it now.

Facebook, Twitter, everywhere!

Please help spread the word about our fundraiser and stay tuned for updates as we move closer to the big day.


Facebook Page: Missouri State University 2015 L.A. Showcase

Twitter: @MSULAShowcase15

story:
The Bible Beautiful - The Book of Psalms 

This is Alabaster | Psalms-- Raw, honest poems from thousands of years ago telling the story of humans and the desire to know God, reimagined through striking visual imagery and thoughtful design. All 150 Psalms in one 232-page book. Continuing in our passion to explore the intersection of creativity, beauty and faith we’ve started designs on the text of Psalms and through Kickstarter aim to fund costs for the production and printing of these books. 

In April of 2017, Alabaster Co. completed its first project, Alabaster | The Gospels. Reimagining the Gospels was a project born out of a desire to engage readers with a fresh experience of the Bible. Psalms advances our vision of seeing the Bible, beautiful.

We can’t wait to share our visually-driven and design-oriented approach to this much loved book of the Bible with readers.

Why Psalms

Psalms is already a beautiful and creative work of art. This ancient and timeless book of poetry and songs highlights the full range of emotional and spiritual experiences we live through as humans.

In the book of Psalms we learn about mourning, grief, lament, love, joy, forgiveness and what it means to connect with God in the midst of our complex lives. It is a sprawling creative epic about our life with God, community and creation. Today, in our growing creative culture, we believe there's a deep need to experience God through the book of Psalms in a new and visual way.

As we thought about what book of the Bible to tackle next, Psalms felt like the obvious continuation in Alabaster's exploration of creativity, beauty and faith. We think most creatives would feel a kindred connection to the writers of Psalms. 

Walter Brueggemann describes Psalms as showing us the counter-world of abundance and truthfulness that comes from living with God. We think that is the ultimate purpose of art: to show us new worlds and imagine new realities of truth and abundance, worlds that we haven't yet dreamt. 

We're incredibly excited to offer our visual and creative approach to this book and see how it enhances the reading experience of Psalms in today’s culture.

Design Aspects

All 150 Psalms, in one 232 page book
100# cover paper (soft-touch aqueous coating)  
80# text paper (uncoated) 
232 pages 
7.5in x 9.5in 
Perfect-binding

 

Timeline

March: Full Production of Psalms 

April: Printing

May: Start Shipping


Translation

We're using the New Living Translation for this project. We wanted a modern English translation, without sacrificing the true meaning of the ancient text.

 

Rewards

Alabaster - The Book of Psalms. All 150 Psalms, in one 232 page book.

The Book of Psalms + One Book of the Gospel or The Gospels Set

Small Print Run. Psalms Hardcover Edition. Clothbound with foil stamping. Dust jacket.

story:
If you're not familiar with us, my name is Joeming Dunn, and I run Antarctic Press, a small, independent comic company started in 1984. I have personally collected comics of almost every type and genre since 1974, and I can say that during the past 30+ years, we have published some of the greatest and best independent comics out there. Our publishing history includes titles like Gold Digger and Ninja High School, and naturally, T-shirts are among the merchandise we've produced for them. Over the past several years, we have also released a number of great parody shirts. You may have seen some of them at a comic book or sci-fi convention.

Our aim is to expand our line of shirts and create them on a more regular basis. To this end, we hope to use the Kickstarter funds to help us achieve that goal. The shirts themselves are 100% cotton and will be offered in sizes ranging from Small to XXX-Large.

 

Our next Kickstarter T-Shirt is OP TATOOINE. Whether you're out bull's-eyeing womp rats in your T-16, picking up some power convertors at Tosche Station, running the rounds on the moisture farm, or just cruising around at double-sunset, listening to the Mos Eisley Brothers, this is the shirt to wear!  It's sure to fix your bad motivator and put you in the mood for heading out to the Dune Sea, joining a desperate Rebellion, or just enjoying a cold one at the cantina.  (Now serving Droids!)

 

 

Risks and challenges

There is always risk with any Kickstarter campaign, but over the past 5 years, we have produced a multitude of shirts without any problems. We have worked with a variety of different shirt printers over the years, and we will choose the one which we think will produce the highest-quality shirt in the least amount of time. We have had much experience in producing, packaging and sending out product like this in our 30 years in business, so we do not anticipate any difficulty in fulfilling this Kickstarter.
story_txt: If you're not familiar with us, my name is Joeming Dunn, and I run Antarctic Press, a small, independent comic company started in 1984. I have personally collected comics of almost every type and genre since 1974, and I can say that during the past 30+ years, we have published some of the greatest and best independent comics out there. Our publishing history includes titles like Gold Digger and Ninja High School, and naturally, T-shirts are among the merchandise we've produced for them. Over the past several years, we have also released a number of great parody shirts. You may have seen some of them at a comic book or sci-fi convention.Our aim is to expand our line of shirts and create them on a more regular basis. To this end, we hope to use the Kickstarter funds to help us achieve that goal. The shirts themselves are 100% cotton and will be offered in sizes ranging from Small to XXX-Large. Our next Kickstarter T-Shirt is OP TATOOINE. Whether you're out bull's-eyeing womp rats in your T-16, picking up some power convertors at Tosche Station, running the rounds on the moisture farm, or just cruising around at double-sunset, listening to the Mos Eisley Brothers, this is the shirt to wear!  It's sure to fix your bad motivator and put you in the mood for heading out to the Dune Sea, joining a desperate Rebellion, or just enjoying a cold one at the cantina.  (Now serving Droids!)  Risks and challengesThere is always risk with any Kickstarter campaign, but over the past 5 years, we have produced a multitude of shirts without any problems. We have worked with a variety of different shirt printers over the years, and we will choose the one which we think will produce the highest-quality shirt in the least amount of time. We have had much experience in producing, packaging and sending out product like this in our 30 years in business, so we do not anticipate any difficulty in fulfilling this Kickstarter.

story:
A Lil' About Me.

My name is Adelle Rae Taylor and I am an emerging Canadian artist, currently living in downtown Toronto.
I am a graduate of the Ontario College of Art & Design University, where I majored in painting and drawing. Since graduation, I've had many amazing opportunities to showcase my work throughout the G.T.A. and my hometown of Sarnia, Ontario. I see myself as a chameleon artist, working in many different mediums and seizing to come out of the same rabbit whole twice.
Recently, I applied to the Toronto Artist Project Art's Festival here in Toronto, and was humbly accepted for my 2014 Planet series. However, with my acceptance come's a large exhibitor fee to which I must provide before January. This fee will pay for my 5 x 10 booth at the festival. This festival will be one of the most crucial moments of my artistic career so far, and will give me the best exposure Toronto [ even Canada ] can offer. 

This is where I need you.

I couldn't think of a better way to come up with the exhibitor fee then doing what I do best - creating art for you. 
I am seeking to come up with $2000 to secure my spot in the fesitival, while also gathering funds for supplies and marketing materials!
That being said, your help will not go unappreciated!
I've come up with unique perks that you can chose from. From prints to original paintings, you will not leave empty handed! 

I'm an artist, this is what I do!


I have made countless commissioned piece for all types of people, company's and showcases. If you are a little nervous about contributing, please feel free to contact me personally to ask any questions you may have. 

About the Toronto Artist Project

The Toronto Artist Project is a 4 day arts festival at The Toronto Exhibition Centre. 250+ Artists are selected across Canada to showcase their work in the festival where they will have the opportunity to expose themselves and their work to potential buyers, art critics, gallery owners, etc.
The show will run Feb 19th - 22nd, 2015

Spread the word!

If you're unable to help [ no worries! ] just spread the word to people you think may be interested! 
Make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

I LOVE YOU ALL! 

Adelle Rae Taylor

story:
The Transformation Man is Born. 

The Man hatched out of his in container just in time for Dutch Decompression 2014.  He was conceived after the decomp meeting 8 weeks earlier.  His debut was a great success. 


But traveling is in his DNA.

He started his life in China as a small but feisty 10ft shipping container.. so he has seen the world and although he had unglamorous period as paint shack before his transformation he still longs for the open road.  And now he has even more to offer than his 15.89m3 storage capacity; he can transform, amaze people and throw big flames.


We want to help the Man

to strut his stuff near you.  But he is an expensive boy to transport so that is why we started this campaign. 

Our Goals

Our first goal is to bring it to AfrikaBurn. We will fill the Transformation Man with all kinds of goodies that African charities are in need of, like clothing, toys, sportsgear and teddybears and will donate that personally to local communities and charities, onze we are there (beginning of May). If we have any money left we will donate the extras to Pedals 4 Peace; a charity that collaborates with AfrikaBurn to donate used bikes to local kids that therefore are able to travel the long distances to school. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! 

Or if you have a truck which can transport the Man or even truck drivers licence could help us greatly. 

Also the Man would love to come a festival near you so if you are interested, please let one of the team know!

story:
Redact This! Artists Against Torture is a collection of artwork made in response to acts of torture at Abu Ghraib, Guantanamo Bay, and CIA Black Sites. Redact This! creator David Schwittek has designed this book as a tribute to those who continue to suffer from, and to fight against, acts of state sponsored torture.

David Schwittek is an artist, designer, filmmaker, and educator working in NYC. 

About the Project: In 2009 I was seized with an idea: to create an art historical volume that could serve as a response to the acts of torture committed as part of the “War On Terror”. My foremost goal was to address the over-saturated image culture that had arisen since the release of the May 2004 Taguba report, and the subsequent reportage by Sy Hersh and 60 Minutes. 

In these first glimpses of the extensive torture programs, we were confronted with the iconic images of torture orchestrated in the Abu Ghraib prison; images that went from shocking to blasé after a relatively small number of news cycles. Like the many thousands of images we see each day, the images found in the Taguba report had lost their potency with each casual viewing and were thus met with indifference by the majority of Americans. 

“Art does not have the power to bring about social or political change. But it does have the power to perpetuate the memory of an episode over time … Art serves as a testimony that endures over time, and in the collective memory.” – Fernando Botero

I designed Redact This! Artists Against Torture as a corrective for this indifference. By elevating the subject of torture to the realm of fine art, the reader is invited not to consume the images, but to contemplate them. They serve to “perpetuate the memory” of these acts so that the people of the world never halt their struggle to end torture. In each of the pieces found in this book, there is a richer meaning than the formal qualities or subject matter can convey; each stands on its own as a unique protest against the use of torture, anywhere, everywhere, for any reason, always.  

-David Schwittek, 2014

About the studio: If we are successful in our funding campaign, we will be working with animation studio and eBook developer FlickerLab LLC. FlickerLab is an animation and production studio in New York City that brings together an interdisciplinary team of storytellers, producers, technologists, composers and educators to create stories with the world’s leading brands, agencies, publishers and networks. They are pioneers in transforming complex ideas and story-worlds into effective and moving experiences that translate across today’s rapidly evolving, multi-screen media environment.

In addition to its more commercial work, FlickerLab is currently creating an animated breakdown for the ACLU on the modern surveillance state, as well as a series of animated videos explaining UN human rights structures with the UN Office of the Special Reporteur on Human Rights in Iran. In the past, FlickerLab has created a series of music videos for Kids for Global Peace. It also developed a citizen journalism and publishing platform for use with Peace and Reconciliation processes in Latin America. 

Finally, FlickerLab has worked on Michael Moore’s Bowling for Columbine, Fahrenheit 9/11, Sicko and Capitalism: A Love Story. 

About FlickerLab's Harold Moss: Harold is the founder and creative director of content, education and technology creation studio FlickerLab, who has spent his career fusing storytelling, technology and a passion for change-making media. Notably, he created the three-minute cartoon, A Brief History of the USA, in Michael Moore’s Academy Award winning, Bowling for Columbine (2003); was a producer of the 2008 Sundance Grand Jury Prize winning and Oscar nominated documentary, Trouble the Water; and has produced and directed over 100 interactive eBooks for Barnes & Noble, Penguin and others.

Harold has committed his life to changing the world one cartoon at a time. 

Who does the money go to...?: All funds received from this campaign will go directly to The Alliance For Global Justice,

a unified domestic and international movement of transformational grassroots organizations that promote a socially, ecologically and economically just world, and a registered 501.3(c). IndieGogo uses FirstGiving to process donations to the AFGJ, ensuring that the funds are distributed transparently. 

...and what are we going to do with it? Working with FlickerLab, we are going to develop this ebook so that it includes: 

• The Artwork: The book features over one hundred unique and original works by artists such as Fernando Botero, Jenny Holzer, Richard Serra, Dread Scott, Steven Powers, Daniel Heyman and many others, presented as a detail-rich gallery and e-experience. 

• Installations and performance: With a print publication, it’s difficult to successfully present installation and performance art, and nearly impossible remain true to the medium. With video, however, it’s a snap! This eBook will be able to include much of the excellent – though difficult to print – multimedia work that has been done on the subject of torture. Artists include Steve Powers, Coco Fusco, Jenny Holzer, Peggy Weil and many others.

• Interactive pieces: The money we raise from this campaign will allow us to create an interactive work of art, as well as informational pieces to be included in the book.

Assuming this project is funded sufficiently, we anticipate this ebook to be completed at the end of 2014, with fulfillment of ebook orders shortly thereafter.

We anticipate success in fulfillment of rewards and completion of the eBook. 

Members of our team have created successful crowdfunding projects which delivered all rewards in a timely fashion, so we have done due diligence in preparing Redact This! for launch.

story:
UPDATE (6/3/14): We've hit the goal!...You can STILL CONTRIBUTE, though, and get the 'perks' and help out this project...I'm also working on figuring out a second mural site in Ann Arbor and your contributions will help this too!!! More shortly...


SUMMARY

Why and Who

Simple project: turn a high-visibility, graffiti-patched wall into a beautiful mural. The site is the former Borders building at the high-traffic intersection of State and Liberty streets. This mural, which would actually deter further tagging and continue to enliven downtown, is a project of shur!, a series of activities organized by Omari about self empowerment, citizenship, leadership, and creativity. (Paint Day: Sunday, June 22, between 11am and 4pm.)

Mary Thiefels of Tree Town Murals will create the mural -- assisted on paint day by an army of deputy muralists (shur! alumni and current participants) -- utilizing a paint-by-number system to allow people of ANY skill level to participate. (www.treetownmurals.com)

Regarding his inspiration, mural graphic designer Danijel Matanic says: "'shur!' is a positive attitude that leads to opening new perspectives and perceptions of the world around us...life can be a dream come true." (www.danijelmatanic.com)

Omari Rush - Project Organizer

Omari Rush, who currently works for the Ann Arbor Art Center and previously worked for the University Musical Society (UMS), takes time outside of the office to regularly design empowering and engaging events for peers, such as shur! and the Fox Trot. Additionally, he has served other organizations in advisory roles, for instance, as Vice Chair of the governor-appointed State of Michigan Council for Arts and Cultural Affairs, as a member of the Kennedy Center Partners in Education National Advisory Committee, and as Chair of the Board of Directors for the Ann Arbor Public Schools Educational Foundation.



DOLLARS NEEDED

Project Costs

Artist fee, materials (including paint), equipment rentals (including scaffolding), insurance, and maintenance (one year).

Confirmed Contributions

Various generous individuals and organizations have already confirmed support of this project:

  • Ann Arbor Downtown Development Authority ("Leadership" supporter)
  • Barracuda Networks
  • Amanda and Bennett Borsuk
  • Mack Rush
  • Hughes Properties

What else we need

The total project cost is $3,800 and given the confirmed contributions, we just need $1,400 more to reach our funding goal!


YOUR QUESTIONS

How likely is this to happen?

- We are DETERMINED to make this happen! Based on the current support we have and the momentum towards achieving our goals, we are confident we will find a way to make this work. PAINT DAY is Sunday, June 22, between 11am and 4pm.

Do you have building owner approval?

- Yes, building developer Ron Hughes of Hughes Properties is in full support of the project and we're working with his colleagues Pat Fix and Sean Havera on logistics and execution.

Do you have city of Ann Arbor approval?

- Yes, in particular with the help of the Public Art Administrator (Aaron Seagraves), we've gotten green lights related to insurance, permits, and zoning from all relevant City of Ann Arbor offices.

What happens if it rains on paint day?

- Paint Day is Sunday, June 22 and our back-up plan is to do this mural on Sunday, June 29.

When will it be finished?

- This mural will be completed in one day...though muralist Mary Thiefels will do touch-up work after all of the volunteers have left.

Will vandalism/tagging ruin it?

- No! A special coating will be applied to the mural that allows any vandalism or tags of spray paint/permanent marker to be easily washed off.


THANKS SO MUCH for considering support of this project and for saying 'yes/shur!' to making Ann Arbor better. Feel free to share this with your friends, colleagues, and family too!

story:
This is a bit like a blog:  I've been adding progress photos as I've been drawing the artwork.  Scroll down to "Hello, I'm an illustrator" to get the gist of it

7/18  Finished!  Here's the final artwork:


Progress 7/12  Started in with the color yesterday, then woke up today at four in the morning and sort of obsessively had at it all day.  Here's where it is now


Progress 7/9 got a lot more detail work in:

Progress 7/8 I guess I'm about halfway through the black ink now:


Progress 7/7 It was hard to work on the big drawing over the Fourth of July, but I did draw in my sketchbook and finished this 5" by 7" image with the same pens and materials I hope to finish Scrutinizing Magnificence with:


Progress 7/3 Enjoying filling in details:


Progress 7/1 Getting into some of the detail work, late night doodleing-like session.  This is a lot of fun to do, just little detailed swirlies.  When it's done these will have overlays of grey and red inks, and a lot more shading:


Progress 6/29 I'm about a quarter of the way through the black ink:


Progress 6/28 finished the pencils!

Progress 6/27:  halfway through the pencils: you can see I re-drew the tiger


Hello, I’m an illustrator (mostly t-shirts) - oriented graphic designer in Alameda, CA. Check out my portfolio here: http://www.behance.net/tymeier . I recently got into creating these little designs in a sketchbook I carry around:


They’re a lot of fun to draw!

Recently someone commisioned me to create a larger drawing (18” by 24”) but can’t pay enough to make up for the hours that it’ll take to create it. But I really, really want to do the drawing, so this Indigogo project is my attempt to make the many hours I’ll have to put into the drawing worth it.

All we know about the artwork now is that it will begin with the sentiment expressed by this Henry Miller quote:

"The moment one gives close attention to any thing, it becomes a mysterious, awesome, indescribably magnificent world in itself." - Henry Miller.

From that wonderful sentiment it will become an intensely detailed stream of consciousness like many of the pen and ink artworks I’ve done in the past (check them out here: http://www.peaceprosperityhappiness.com/ ) only this time on brown artboard with black, red and white ink.

I’ll be posting progress here as I go.

Thanks!

-Ty

story:
The 1 minute synopsis: 

The Wolftever Creek Greenway is a beautiful 4+ miles strip that bonds families and neighbors of the Collegedale/Ooltewah area in Tennessee. It offers a lot of interesting features for trail users, including the Imagination Station Playground, a Nature Nook, a dog park and a picnic area. In addition, you'll find artistically shaped benches, old wagon wheels, bicycles and plows made into planters and plenty of bird feeders. It is my dream is to create 3 (three) murals that will continue to unify and inspire our citizens and visitors as well as to contribute in the embellishment of the greenway. 

**UPDATE: 

Great News!! On Tue, July 15th the Collegedale's Parks and Recreations Dept. accepted the mural proposal. Here are the next steps:

 1. Get approval from TDOT

2. Then the Parks and Recreations Dept will submit a recommendation to the city to approve the project.

 We still need your support in spreading the word, the more signatures the more attention this project will receive. 

-------------------------------

A little bit About me:

My name is Alex Loza and I'm a professional representational artist, portraitist, muralist and adjunct art professor at Lee University. In 2001 I obtained a BFA degree from the American Academy of Art in Chicago, IL. For the past 15 years I've been commissioned to paint numerous portraits for private art collectors throughout the United States, Canada and Latin America. During my stay in Chicago I've participated along other muralist in several projects around the city. Since 2012 I've been part of Mark Making art facilitator team. That year 20 local professional artists teamed up to mentored and worked along 20 Howard High School students in the 20/20 Vision Mural project located in the Riverfront Pkwy and 19th St. in Chattanooga. In 2013 I was one of the artists that volunteered in the recreation of Historic Engel Stadium outfield walls after the film "42". The Collegedale/Ooltewah area has been home for my family and I since 2010 and I'm counting with your approval and support to create this murals for our neighborhood.

---------------------------

The Project Proposal: 

FIRST MURAL: VETERANS MURAL 

The funds I'm raising is for a mural on this bridge. It measures close to 6'7" x 48' (around 336 feet square). This mural will be located under the Ooltewah-Ringgold Rd bridge that leads the way to Veteran's Park. In our city we love and admire our Vets for this reason I want this mural to be the first one be painted. Do you know a local war hero? Would you like him/her to be part of the mural? Make a donation of $550 and provide me with his/her name and contact information. It will be my honor to portray the brave men and women who served our nation in various wars.

 

What if the contributions exceeds? 

That would be the best news ever!! An additional $6,895 will help us paint a second mural in the bridge near the Imagination Station (photo bellow). The wall measures 7' x 118 feet (around 826 square feet). This mural will depict the everyday outdoor activities seen in our community i.e. families walking, children playing, cyclist, runners, etc.   

If the total contribution adds up to $21,725 we will be able to paint all three murals. The third mural will be painted under the bridge that supports the rail road tracks near the beautiful stream. The wall measures 16' x 67' (around 1,072 square feet). This mural will honor our city's history of Native Americans and their culture.    

 

\

Who are we partnering with?

The Neighborhood: After transferring the mural designs into each wall I'll enjoy having the community to volunteer their time to make this murals possible

Local Artists: I'll also extend the invitation to my local art students, my Lee University art students as well as local professional artists and art organizations to collaborate with the projects.

Local Businesses and Organizations: We are hoping for local businesses and organizations to contribute by donating materials needed for this project.

Collegedale Park and Rec. Dept: This project cannot be possible without the city's approval and support. During the past years Collegedale has invested in the continuous transformation of our neighborhood.  The murals will be an addition to what the city has already accomplish. 

Donations will purchase the following supplies:

  • primer

  • paints

  • projector

  • empty containers with lids

  • brushes in many sizes

  • rollers

  • roller pads

  • extension handles for your rollers

  • rags or paper towels

  • drop cloths

  • buckets

  • yardsticks

  • masking tape

  • painting palettes or trays for mixing colors

  • metal scrapers to clean dried paint off palettes

  • stirring sticks

  • brooms and shovels

  • eye protection (goggles)

  • ladders

  • scaffolding

  • paint spraying system

  • milk crates or other sturdy boxes to store paint cans

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise. 
  • Share campaign link in your social media platforms i.e. Facebook, Twitter, etc 
  • Contact local businesses and ask them to contribute to our project. 

As you can see I cannot do this alone. Your contribution will make a difference and will be greatly appreciated. Enjoy our awesome perks!! 

Again thank you so much for your support,

Alex Loza

story:
What a funny thing is it that people like to give and get a sack of breath as a present? Even funnier is that this sack of breath makes people happy. Balloons make people smile even when they don't feel like smiling. Balloons make people happy. Simple as that.

Our mission is to bring that happiness to you in a new way - with LED Balloons!

Together we can take this hapiness to the next level. Let's reinvent balloons by adding light! When you turn off the lights in the room or when the sun goes down in backyard flashing balloons look very appealing and pleasant, like fire flies in summer night, but much brighter and more impressive.

LED balloons are perfect for home or children parties. Also you can use them for advertising, decorating parties, shopping malls, households, weddings, concerts and more.

We present you LED Balloons, LED Balloon Lamps and Paper Lantern Lamps

LED Element and Lamp

LED Element and LED Lamp for large balloons and paper lanterns is an innovation in the decorating field. Our LED element and LED Lamp for balloons is changing the way how event organizers look at the medium and large size balloons. So we can say for sure, it is a new, fresh and modern idea for original lighting in your events. 

It consists of plastic cover, printed circuit board with manually soldered LEDs and batteries for LED Element and electric wire for LED Lamp. For now LED element and Lamp is handmade, it takes very accurate individual work and a lot of time. Every product is lathed, soldered, painted and put together by hands. 

LED Balloon

LED Balloon combines the highest quality simple latex balloon with a specially designed LED light element. The outcome is very effective - modern, different and fun lighting. We recommend to use them for decorating weddings, concerts, open-air parties and other events with a lot of people. Use LED Balloons on the surface of water like pool, lake or pond! Also an interesting material for art projects! For LED Balloons you can choose one of these colors - white, blue, red or green!

LED Balloon Lamp

This is an innovation in LED flashing balloon field. Use LED Balloon Lamps to brighten up your party, backyard, living room or any other place. Become creative - make a flashing balloon ceiling for your garden or make dreamy decorations in high ceiling rooms or halls, illuminate stairways and pathways for night events like music festivals or weddings. LED Balloon Lamps are very convenient - it works from regular power supply so you don't have to worry about changing batteries. Another extra - lights can be managed by remote control to choose the right color and right flashing rhythm that suits best for your event atmosphere.

Paper Lantern With LED Element

Paper Lanterns are the same white Chinese paper lanterns but advanced with our LED element. This is the most universal product from our product line because Paper Lanterns with LED Element are easy to install and are appropriate in any kind of environment - even in the thorny bushes at windy weather. Make a comfy atmosphere in your room or use Paper Lanterns as a light object in weddings, garden parties or lovely family dinners on terrace.

The Story

In the spring of 2013 we had one of our work parties and colleagues made LED balloons from LED light, batteries, duct tape and simple balloon. It looked so nice that we were interested in buying some more for the next spring party. Unfortunately, (or luckily for us) we found that there are no mid-sized LED balloons on the market. We prepared LED balloons for the planned event by ourselves. Event organizers were very interested and advised to produce them on larger scale. We got our first order and that is how we started.

Why We Need 17,000 Dollars?

Currently, our LED element is made manually, so it takes time and needs accurate individual work. Our desire is to invest in molded plate shape, which will make the production:

  • Faster 
  • Easier 
  • With Lower Costs 
  • With Higher Quality

As a result you will be able to purchase higher quality products and get the order in shorter amount of time. This is where we need your support to optimize the production process and spread the word about us all over the world!

We are very eager to develop our ideas and to grow as a technology company because we truly believe in our products!

What's Next?

Our company never stops developing new ideas and improving already existing products. Right now our production team is working on DMX Control (professional stage lighting control system) development for Balloon Lamps. The goal is to achieve easily controllable lights from professional light controller in massive events like pop concerts and music festivals. 

Also our ambition is to create controllable LED balloons up to 5 meters in diameter for professional usage like in massive events, construction, film industry etc. 

We intend to be the best LED Balloon manufacturer in Europe by providing our clients with the best quality LED Balloons, LED Balloon Lamps and Paper Lanterns with LED lights. We are a small company, so every client is special to us. With an individual approach we open up a new brighter world of event decorating for our clients!

Perks

Check out the perks we offer you for contributing:





Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth is the key for a successful crowd funding campaign. We need your help! Spread the word on Facebook! Pin it! Tweet! Together we can bring the happiness of modern and fun balloon lighting in everyone's event and brighten up the atmosphere not only with lights but also with smiles!

Questions?

If you have questions, we can answer them. If you have comments, we want to hear them. And if you just want to say hi, well, we’ll say hi right back. Write us an email at info@99ledballoons.com

story:
THANK YOU for taking the time to watch my video and check out my request for support!

"Residency opportunities exist to invite artists and all manner of creative people for a time and space away from their usual environment and obligations. They provide a time of reflection, research, presentation, and/or production. They also allow an individual to explore his/her practice within another community; meeting new people, using new materials, experiencing life in a new location. Art residencies emphasize the importance of meaningful and multi-layered cultural exchange and immersion into another culture."

I have recently been invited to an artist residency that is presented by the Art Department of Central Piedmont Community College in Charlotte, NC. It is an intensive week long exploration of the process of finding one's own creative voice in the visual arts. This course is held on the rolling hills of a farm in Virginia - in the middle of the Shenandoah Valley. 

I'm reaching out to get help in covering the expenses of this program, which include:
- A small Registration Fee (that covers art supplies and program expenses)
- Transportation to and from the Airy Knoll Farm in Virginia
- Room and Board 

 Instead of just asking for money, I want use this as an opportunity to share the process with those who are able to help me enjoy this experience. I am providing perks (listed below) to share something of value in exchange for your support. 

If you are not able to contribute financially, but would still like to support, please help me by sharing work from my artist page ( https://www.facebook.com/artofchdwck ) and/or my campaign posts on your pages via FB, Twitter, and Tumblr. Please remember, any type of support you give continues to be appreciated. THANK YOU - not just for what you do, but what you have already done!


GIFT INCENTIVES

$1 - All financial donors will receive a Thank you on FB/Twitter, via email, and will be         acknowledged on my personal website chdwck.com


$10 - 1 Handwritten "Thank You" postcard


$25 - 1 - Handwritten "Thank You" postcard

        3 - Signed 5"x7" Photo Prints (taken at The Farm)


$50 - 1 - Handwritten "Thank You" postcard

        3 - Signed 5"x7" Photo Prints 

        1 - 4"x4" Signed Original Collage or Mixed Media artwork


$100+ - 1 - Handwritten "Thank You" postcard

                3 - Signed 5"x7" Photo Prints

                1 - 8"x10" Collage or Mixed Media Piece

            Exclusive Art Offers and Discounts throughout the coming year

story:
E Komo Mai

Welcome to Paha'oha'o

pronounced - Pa-HA-oh-HA-oh

The Hawaiian translation of Paha'oha'o is transformation. Transform into something more beautiful or elevated.

In Hawaii, eruptions are viewed as beneficial, as acts of creation, and Hawaiians often see their lives mirrored in the level of volcanic activity.

On those islands, an eruption usually begins with lava gushing from a long crack in the earth. The hot, highly fluid material leaves a smooth, skin like texture along the eruptive fissure. Because the structure is reminiscent of a huge vagina, native Hawaiians traditionally regarded an eruption as the menstruation of the goddess Pele, with the red lava always flowing toward the sea, the same path taken in ancient times by women to cleanse themselves.                                    


What It Will Look Like

Paha'oha'o will be a 30' tall by 50' in diameter volcano with a 10' vertical drop slide. The inner structure will be composed of wood, and the exterior covered in layered burlap to mimic molten lava. The volcano will be illuminated by wall washer led lights, programmed to look like flowing lava. A hidden lava tube will lead you to a ladder, where you will begin a 22' climb to the top of the caldera and sacrifice yourself into mouth of the volcano. The only way down will be to take a leap of faith into the belly of the volcano via the "drop slide of transformation" which is at 22 foot high slide with a 10 foot vertical drop.

Inside the belly of the volcano will be an enclosed room. This will be a place of learning and sharing of the Hawaiian culture through hula dancing, hula pahu drums, story telling. Also inside will be an 8’ hula dancer making an offering to the Goddess Pele, sculpted by Marco Cochrane.  

And we can't forget the fire! During the week fire will shoot out the mouth of the volcano. On Thursday we will burn the whole thing to the ground for the ultimate cleansing.


The Inspiration

The inspiration behind the project comes from my own process of transformation.  As a result of the abuse that I experienced in my childhood,  I came to believe that I deserved or should expect and keep quiet about abusive relationships with the men in my life. Unfortunately, alcoholism is a common thread among them too. I have spent the last year healing myself and re-discovering my inner strength as a woman, mother, lover and friend. I have learned so much about myself through this period of reflection. This volcano is my way of saying good bye to the past and embracing my new beginning. Some may say that I'm like a Phoenix rising out of the ashes...but since I am Hawaiian, I will sacrifice myself to the volcano and come out cleansed and transformed, ready to create a new truth about myself.  We all have baggage from our past and my hope is to encourage people to let go of the pain and hurt in their past and transform their lives for the better.  

 

Please join us in support of all the women and men brave enough to rise above the abuse that so many of us have experienced in our lives, and to everyone that is ready to make a transformation.


The Crew

I spent the last year contributing to Truth is Beauty and the Bliss Dance Project. This work has been a huge positive force in my transformation. Their amazing crew, and the Heartfullness crew, are supporting my dreams by helping bring this project to the playa. 



We Need Your Support

We are raising funds to cover the costs of materials including of lumber, burlap, lighting, fire equipment, and propane, as well as transportation to the playa.  All the money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the materials needed to bring this project to life.  

Any additional funds raised will be used to add pyrotechnics to our crazy fire plan.


Awesome Perks! 

We have some great perks to get you excited about what you will get for your pledge and helping us reach our goal! We've highlighted a few below, full list is to the right.


Welding Lesson

Introductory welding lesson at our San Francisco studio. Try your hand at MIG welding and make a piece that will become part of Paha’oha’o.


Wood Pendant

Laser etched 3" wooden pendant. Ash on walnut finished hand stained with cinnamon and walnut stains and a clear wood finish to protect it.


Ahi o Pele
- Fire of Pele -

Fire guru Al Stahler's custom made Ahi o Pele, a personal flaming party popper. A spark and a pop that will delight fire enthusiasts, yet easy enough for a novice to operate. Check out a demonstration here.

Collapsable Cup

5oz stainless steel collapsable cup engraved with Paha'oha'o logo. Attach to your belt or bag so you always have a cup handy




Other Ways You Can Help

Help us spread the word and make some noise about our project.  We also are looking for in-kind donations of construction materials such as lumber, pallets, nails, lighting and of course help with the building process too.


Thanks for your support,

A hidden lava tube will lead you to a ladder, where you will begin a 22' climb to the top of the caldera and sacrifice yourself into mouth of the volcano. The only way down will be to take a leap of faith into the belly of the volcano via the "drop slide of transformation" which is at 22 foot high slide with a 10 foot vertical drop.Inside the belly of the volcano will be an enclosed room. This will be a place of learning and sharing of the Hawaiian culture through hula dancing, hula pahu drums, story telling. Also inside will be an 8’ hula dancer making an offering to the Goddess Pele, sculpted by Marco Cochrane.  And we can't forget the fire! During the week fire will shoot out the mouth of the volcano. On Thursday we will burn the whole thing to the ground for the ultimate cleansing.The Inspiration

The inspiration behind the project comes from my own process of transformation.  As a result of the abuse that I experienced in my childhood,  I came to believe that I deserved or should expect and keep quiet about abusive relationships with the men in my life. Unfortunately, alcoholism is a common thread among them too. I have spent the last year healing myself and re-discovering my inner strength as a woman, mother, lover and friend. I have learned so much about myself through this period of reflection. This volcano is my way of saying good bye to the past and embracing my new beginning. Some may say that I'm like a Phoenix rising out of the ashes...but since I am Hawaiian, I will sacrifice myself to the volcano and come out cleansed and transformed, ready to create a new truth about myself.  We all have baggage from our past and my hope is to encourage people to let go of the pain and hurt in their past and transform their lives for the better.    
Please join us in support of all the women and men brave enough to rise above the abuse that so many of us have experienced in our lives, and to everyone that is ready to make a transformation.The CrewI spent the last year contributing to Truth is Beauty and the Bliss Dance Project. This work has been a huge positive force in my transformation. Their amazing crew, and the Heartfullness crew, are supporting my dreams by helping bring this project to the playa. We Need Your SupportWe are raising funds to cover the costs of materials including of lumber, burlap, lighting, fire equipment, and propane, as well as transportation to the playa.  All the money raised will go directly towards the purchasing of the materials needed to bring this project to life.  Any additional funds raised will be used to add pyrotechnics to our crazy fire plan.Awesome Perks! We have some great perks to get you excited about what you will get for your pledge and helping us reach our goal! We've highlighted a few below, full list is to the right.

Welding Lesson
Introductory welding lesson at our San Francisco studio. Try your hand at MIG welding and make a piece that will become part of Paha’oha’o.









Wood Pendant


Laser etched 3" wooden pendant. Ash on walnut finished hand stained with cinnamon and walnut stains and a clear wood finish to protect it.










Ahi o Pele - Fire of Pele -
Fire guru Al Stahler's custom made Ahi o Pele, a personal flaming party popper. A spark and a pop that will delight fire enthusiasts, yet easy enough for a novice to operate. Check out a demonstration here.









Collapsable Cup
5oz stainless steel collapsable cup engraved with Paha'oha'o logo. Attach to your belt or bag so you always have a cup handy












Other Ways You Can HelpHelp us spread the word and make some noise about our project.  We also are looking for in-kind donations of construction materials such as lumber, pallets, nails, lighting and of course help with the building process too.Thanks for your support,

story:
We would like to raise your attention and get your help for our LaBa! Arts Festival that will take place on June 07/08, 2014 in Kampala, Uganda.
The Goethe-Zentrum Kampala/ Ugandan German Cultural Society (GZK/ UGCS), a non-profit local NGO based in Kampala, Uganda, in collarboration with a group of committed Ugandan artists and art enthusiasts will carry out the festival for the 8th time in a row. It has become an important event in the cultural calendar for the whole country and has even been mentioned in the Lonely Planet guide for Uganda!

The 8th edition of LaBa! Arts Festival comes with a fundamental change. This year the festival will show two sides of the Ugandan art scene and the capital Kampala acts as the stage. The City is Our Space - and artists and audience are called upon transforming the Kisementi Parking Lot in Kololo, and Kabega Road in Nsambya into spaces for art.

The differences between the rather upper-town commercial area of Kisementi and the more classic example of a typical neighbourhood with community-based projects of Nsambya will be taken up by two different approaches towards art and its interplay with the people.

Kisementi parking lot will be the first stop over for LaBa! trying to focus on the urban and contemporary art movements in Kampala. With the participation of the surrounding bars and restaurants and the new shopping mall artists will be working side by side in and on different spaces in the area, exhibiting their works in relationship to the city. In the middle of the parking lot will be a stage, giving space for the musical programme till latest midnight, which will then continue with DJs in the surrounding clubs. The exhibiting artists will be selected and curated (after call for application) in order to present artistic works of high quality and relevance to the city landscape.

The second day will be a Street Festival at Nsambya which will focus on the community and its environment. Through interactive projects artists will involve the community in different performances and art projects, like dance workshops, street theatre, mural paintings, installations, concerts and more. The street will be turned into a lively art space enjoyable for everyone hopefully carrying the traces by the beautification of the area. The Street Festival is dedicated to community and social art projects and the participation by the community of Nsambya.

The "LaBa! Arts Festival 2014 - The City is our Space" will take place on 07th/08th June 2014.

For more information, please visit our blog and like our facebook page:

http://labaartsfestival.wordpress.com/

www.facebook.com/LaBaArtsFestival

story:
Wouldn't it be great to have a fun radio station in Portland that plays a variety of great music morning, noon and night with no commercials?  In 2015, three companies own over 75% of Portland's radio dial. We want you to join our team of media rebels. Help us further liberate local airwaves from commercial control. Just like you can't have too many local coffee shops or startup restaurants, you can not have too many local commercial-free radio stations.

Freeform, or freeform radio, is a radio station programming format in which the DJ is given total control over what music to play, regardless of music genre or commercial interests. Freeform radio stands in contrast to most commercial radio stations, where DJs have little or no influence over programming structure or playlists. In the United States, freeform DJs are still bound by Federal Communications Commission regulations.

Freeform Portland (KFFP) has a permit from the FCC to utilize a non-commercial low-power FM (LPFM) radio channel in Portland. KFFP is being created by a group of volunteers who are waaaaaay-into freeform stations like WFMU, KXLU, KALX, & KFJC, and have tons of prior college and community radio experience. Our volunteers work directly with All Classical, KBOO, KMHD, XRAY.fm, House of Sound, Portland Radio Project, Wild Planet Radio and Vancouver Radio Project. We've also got radio family at KPSU, KRRC and Mt Hood Community College. We love radio. We love Portland. We're all working on the same team against the crappy corporate radio monopoly.  Won't you join us?

The pressures of fundraising large amounts of money puts huge limitations on programming experimentation, so Freeform Portland aims to sustain a minimal budget that covers basic overhead, this way our DJs can focus on making great radio for everyone. We are all about art and experimentation. We encourage our DJs to dig deep into historical musics, collector gems, new sounds, local demo tapes, outsider music and sonic wanderings. Programming will be curated to appeal to both the occasional listener, as well as the most discriminating record collector.


Music & freeform radio have the power to bring together communities and create human connection that is becoming increasingly valuable in our digital age.  In this spirit, we'll be begin broadcasting DJs live from The Tannery and The Liquor Store this Summer.  In addition, we'll start hosting monthly musicology classes where experts share their knowledge of recorded sounds of the past 100 years and give students radio broadcast training. Freeform Portland programming will come organically from our volunteers and underground media - not from nationally-syndicated public radio content. We're searching for our first broadcast studio space now and plan to begin streaming a test signal later this Summer. If you make a donation today, you'll be one of the first to hear it.

Even the bare-bones equipment we need to broadcast on FM (and host dozens of weekly DJs) exceeds our $7500 Indiegogo goal, but we know we are going to have to keep fundraising for the rest of 2015 to get our little volunteer station on the air in 2016. Let's do it together! Freeform Portland is radio for the people, by the people. Yep, we are a not-for-profit, volunteer-powered, 501(c)3 tax-deductable organization (a special thanks to Media Alliance for being our fiscal sponsor while our application is processed!). You can support this creative radio movement today by helping us pull together the legally-mandated equipment we need to put our radio on the air for the community and give dozens of DJs the tools they need to make great radio for you. Your donation will go directly towards these necessary expenses:

Transmitter $2,200

Mast $1,000

FCC Emergency Alert System $2,200

Coaxial Cables $300

Turntables (used) $800

CD/Tape Player (used) $400

Mixing Console (used) $2,000

Computers  $1,200

First & Last Month's Rent (studio) $1200

___________________________________________

We can really use your help today. Grab a tee-shirt and spread the word.  

Together, let's create something fun for Portland and the world.

More questions? Check our FAQ

story:
My name is Prinjastin Sykes, I grew up  with a poor mom. My mom was mentally disabled and she always tried to commit suicide. My mom would get a welfare check every month and we could only afford to stay in a motel. So to make money to put food on the table I had to go out and sell my mothers poetry on the street for a while with myself then my little brother followed suit. after a while I got clever and I figured I could make more money performing the poetry. but still on a good day I would only come home with a few dollars. One night my mother didn't come back from a long walk when she was feeling suicidal, so me and my brother panicked  and called the police. They put my mother in the back of the car and  took her to the hospital. I felt guilty and reflected on my life that was definatly not a normal teenage life, and I wanted to kill myself. I ended up in a residential treatment facility where I found my passion "poetry". Now I want to create art from ashes with the life I had and return hip hop to its original form of story telling,  to start I'm creating an album of rap and poetry. I encourage many youth to tell there story. Not a lot of youth are as comfortable to the world as they should be to express themselves. I believe it is because they do not have role models other than rappers who have forgot the true meaning of hip hop. You will help me achieve a powerful transformation in this world.
What I need and what you get
I need $1500 to get studio time and to make my cd. 
I do make poems for businesses. I also make personal poems for others. I perform poetry and I can give you a shout out in a video.
If I do not reach my goal, your money will go to Art From Ashes, a non profit organization that empowers struggling youth by providing creative programs that facilitate health and hope trough  expression, connection, and transformation through spoken word poetry.
Risk and Challenges 
Youth will not look up to you if you have not achieved something great and if you are not admired by a group of people. There is more to my mission than money, I have to be bigger than life for youth to look up to me. 
I also have to sell my cd, and people will not buy a cd from a nobody. 
I encourage you to give a shout out to my campaign if you can not help with money. I also encourage you to email me if you have an opportunity for me to perform at prinjastin@gmail.com

story:
I'm a 28 (29 on 7/26) year old mother of 4 and survivor of 8 years of abuse. I have a 9 year old that suffers from ADHD, ODD, PTSD & mild autism, along with twins that are 6 and a 5 month old baby.
I work full time, and my husband worked part time and stays with the kids while I work, until our car broke down on Saturday, July 14th. He has another job lined up already, thank God.
 
My oldest son is in serious need of having me there for him more, and so are my other children, since my oldest has started acting out violently and dangerously. I also need to be home more so that he can recieve intensive in-home services.
 
I recently started making cloth pocket diapers for my daughter, and paracord survivial bracelets for my boys, and I've had a ton of interest! I set up a facebook page and an etsy page for my diapers, and I sell the bracelets at the store where I work.
 
 

 

Basically, we are a month behind on everything, which means things are about the start being shut off (electric, water, etc) and our landlord has started the eviction process. (We're actually only due to the landlord for $250 plus the late fee of $75, and the $80 court costs for this month, because they give their tenants until the 12th of the month to pay in full before they file with the court)

We still have 2 payments left on our car, which is in need of repair. It only runs for a few minutes before it stalls out.


I'm getting a lot of orders for my diapers, and my bracelets are flying off the rack at work, but I'm not making a lot of profit because I have to buy my supples as I get orders, and I have to use the sewing machine at work on my breaks because I don't have my own.

This money would do the following:

  1. Catch us up on our bills plus get us a month ahead.
  2. Allow me to buy the supplies I need to make my diapers at home.
  3. Pay our car off and get it repaired.
  4. Because of these things, allow me to be home with my children more. Each bracelet I sell is an hour I can spend at home instead of work, each diaper is two hours!

As perks, I'll be offering the diapers and bracelets that I make. Please take into consideration that I'm currently working extra hours at my full time job because we need the money, but I will get things sent to people as quickly as I'm able!

 

 

I have worked full time since I was 15 years old. I have had to start completely over with my kids after getting away from my ex. Close to 3 years ago, we were in a domestic violence shelter and now we have a home, the kids are in a great school, I've married a wonderful man and added a (surprise) little sister to the family. If our car doesn't get repaired, my husband won't be able to start the new job, I won't have a way to keep up with my son's frequest treatments and appoinments. I'm having to choose between keeping a roof over our heads or doing my best for my children, and it breaks my heart every day..

 

 

Every little bit helps..

Pray for us, share our project, anything makes a difference!

 

Thank you!
