story:
I want a new tattoo for my birthday (August 27th) but every time I say I want a new tattoo something horrible happens and whatever money I had set aside gets spent. One time we ran over our digital camera during a trip and had to replace it at some over-priced crap store in the middle of the Utah desert. Another time I ate a curb in a snow storm and had to replace a rim on my truck. The list goes on, people; and it only gets sadder and more pathetic. We are talking broken A/C kind of misery here. 

You see, tattoos aren't cheap. They usually run about $100 an hour and the design I want will be around a 3 hour piece, possibly broken into two sessions of 1.25 - 1.5 hours. Normally I'd only post this at $300 to cover it, but the minimum is $500 and they take 9% anyway so what the hell? Any amount raised over the actual cost of the tattoo will be donated to a charity that supports the victims of the Aurora Shooting. 

You might be thinking "why not live the American dream and charge that bad boy?" I'll tell you why not: tattoo artists only take cash. Not very trusting souls, are they? I know, I know. If I can't raise enough for the whole tattoo, the money will get added to the tiny bit I've been able to set aside and I'll get whatever work I can done. It might not be the whole piece but it will be something!

About the artist: I know this guy named Kevin. He and a buddy own Inksmith Tattoo in Louisville, CO and he's going to do the work. I've known Kevin for a good long while and he's simply amazing. 

The only thing of actual value I can offer in this is airtime on the internet (now valued at pretty much nothing!) and my gratitude and friendship. As far as internet cred I host a podcast called Andy's Movie Minute and I used to co-host a show called Wombatcast (not actually about wombats). No matter what, this will get all kinds of blogged about on my site and anyone who donates enough will get a shout out and might even get to come on the show - if I can swing it, the show will be with other podcasters (assuming I want to share my massive internet fame, that is) and might be a "jam session" where we riff on whatever you want. Maybe you are an aspiring writer and want to talk about your writing, or maybe you are an artist and want to pitch an art show, or maybe you are just a geek that wants to jam out with a few other geeks. Whatever. I'm easy. 

Thanks for reading all this and here's to shameless self-interest!

If I can't raise enough for the whole tattoo, the money will get added to the tiny bit I've been able to set aside and I'll get whatever work I can done. It might not be the whole piece but it will be something!
About the artist: I know this guy named Kevin. He and a buddy own Inksmith Tattoo in Louisville, CO and he's going to do the work. I've known Kevin for a good long while and he's simply amazing. 
The only thing of actual value I can offer in this is airtime on the internet (now valued at pretty much nothing!) and my gratitude and friendship. As far as internet cred I host a podcast called Andy's Movie Minute and I used to co-host a show called Wombatcast (not actually about wombats). No matter what, this will get all kinds of blogged about on my site and anyone who donates enough will get a shout out and might even get to come on the show - if I can swing it, the show will be with other podcasters (assuming I want to share my massive internet fame, that is) and might be a "jam session" where we riff on whatever you want. Maybe you are an aspiring writer and want to talk about your writing, or maybe you are an artist and want to pitch an art show, or maybe you are just a geek that wants to jam out with a few other geeks. Whatever. I'm easy. 
Thanks for reading all this and here's to shameless self-interest!

story:
Yay!! We're across the goal line for our IndieGoGo campaign. We're so close...but not quite to the ultimate end yet.

As of noon, April 5 ~ We've raised 90% of our total funds needed. We need to raise $300 more to be able to make this beautiful creation a reality! ~ Any amount helps & we are grateful for your support!

 

What is That Which Is Most Beautiful?

                  (referred to with affection as "TWIMBY")

This interactive art installation is designed to allow participants to fully immerse in a beautiful and moving experience of color, music, and inspirational words.  As visitors travel through the labyrinth, they will read beautiful, powerful words of wisdom written upon the walls – pearls which have been shared with us by some of the world’s respected indigenous leaders, healers and wisdom keepers. Those who are walking within the labyrinth will also hear blessings, songs, chants and drumming from many of these wise people. All of these recordings were given to the Ringing Rocks Foundation to be shared with the people of the world.

To see photos and a short video of the work being done, please visit: http://gallery.me.com/eschafer#100213&view=grid&bgcolor=black&sel=10

story:
WHAT IS 36.5?

36.5 / a durational performance with the sea is a global series: New York-based artist Sarah Cameron Sunde stands in a tidal bay in an urban environment for a full tidal cycle, approximately 12-13 hours, as the water engulfs her body and then recedes; the public is invited to take part as spectator, participant, informed citizen and creative thinker. This time-based art project acknowledges the permanently temporary nature of things and considers our relationship to water within contemporary urban environments, as individuals and as a civilization.

PROJECT HISTORY

The project began in August 2013 as a response to Hurricane Sandy’s impact on New York City. Sunde was working in Maine, thinking about time in relationship to her body and the parallels between an artist trying to survive and a city facing sea-level rise. She was struck by the visual change of environment with Maine’s tidal shift; it seemed like a perfect metaphor. Exactly six months later, she executed a research version in Mexico and discovered that the public needed to play a key role. Ongoing conversations with artists, environmentalists, water management experts, and strangers led to the realization that an urban environment was key. Exactly one year from the initial experiment, Sunde performed the third pilot version in Aquatic Park in San Francisco, a very public location where approximately 1500 people encountered the work.

UPCOMING SITES

36.5 officially launches on a global scale this summer in the Netherlands, thanks to local collaborations with artists, curators, sustainability experts, scientists, policy makers and more. Sunde will perform as part of a residency with Satellietgroep at the Zandmotor in The Hague on August 10, 2015. It will be filmed from four different perspectives and then projected on iconic buildings in Amsterdam August 18-23 during SAIL (Quinquennial Festival where tall ships enter Amsterdam harbor, 1.5 million visitors).

Over the next five years, the project will build off the working model created for the Netherlands while responding specifically to the needs and environment of future urban settings. Bangladesh is scheduled for 2016 and Sunde will execute one performance a year on each livable continent. The final piece in NYC on August 15, 2020 will be a truly global one, with people standing in water worldwide, and layered contributions from all previous sites creating a scope and reach well beyond one place.


36.5 is designed to grow and evolve in response to each community and specific location. The subject is relevant to us all, and the project provides a framework for deep exchanges with local artists and organizations, as well as audiences who encounter and contribute to the work.

At this moment, our goal is specifically to raise funds for the Netherlands iteration. Your donation supports artistic and production costs, enabling us to reach the widest audience possible, both locally in The Hague and Amsterdam, and globally via livestream.

UPCOMING DATES

  • August 10, 2015: performance in The Hague

  • August 18-23, 2015: footage exhibited during SAIL Amsterdam


  • September 21-October 21, 2015: footage exhibited in NYC with Creative Climate Awards


  • August 2016: Bangladesh iteration

PRESS
Check out press from The Brooklyn Rail, The Chronicle, SF Guardian and Howlround.

And be sure to follow Sarah's blog and like (and follow) us on Facebook!

story:
The History of Sugar Hill

Chris Walker has traveled all over while working as an artist. Now, he has the opportunity to create a piece of art, just miles from his home! The History of Sugar Hill mural that Walker has drafted showcases a transition of the present into the past of the sweet city's rich history. 

This mural is a great opportunity for the city to embrace the arts in the downtown area. The city currently has one mural on the opposite side of the building that was completed earlier this year. A second mural showcasing the story of the city's history will only add to the spirit of the growing downtown.

 

Where?

This mural will go on multiple sides of Sugar Hill's former city hall building located on West Broad Street. This building now functions as the Suite Spot, a business incubator in the heart of downtown Sugar Hill. 

This is how the building looks now: 

 

This is a general mock up of how the building will look, when the mural is complete: 

 

 

Support the Arts

This mural has a great deal of community support, but in order to fully fund the projects, we are looking to raise $20,000 to offset the cost of the mural. The Sugar Hill Downtown Development Authority will match up to $10,000 of donations! When you donate, you are supporting arts throughout a city, a local artist's work, and the public display of history in the heart of Sugar Hill's downtown. Any donations past the needed amount will be put towards the fund for future art initiatives in the city! 

We have several contribution level tiers that we are offering and each comes with a different token of our appreciation, depending on your level of donation. We are extremely grateful for any level of donation. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help! Please share our campaign, like the city and artist's social media pages, and look for press about the mural process as we move forward. We will have a few other opportunities for support, so please keep an eye out, throughout the city!

 

Offline Donations

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

**Please note that while cash and in person donations will not be reflected on this website's tracker, we will definitely be updating the "updates" section of this page with any cash donations and on the mural website, when that goes live. For live tracking, check out the fundraising thermometer outside of the Suite Spot in downtown Sugar Hill!

story:
Bref résumé

L’artiste Marie-Line Leblanc publie son tout premier livre d’art en collaboration avec la designer Elise Eskanazi. Il s'agit d'une œuvre qui adopte la forme d’un livre.

Pourquoi un livre?

Le livre d’artiste est un médium d'expression multidisciplinaire à part entière. C’est un lieu d’art total qui permet de construire des relations entre des séquences d'images, des photographies et des mots, en plus de procurer des sensations tactiles et un effet cinématique.

Au-délà du livre

Le livre intitulé FIXITY AND FLOW est constitué de deux cahiers d’exploration reliés par une affiche qui évoque la carte topographique dépliable. Les cahiers illustrent l’étude effectuée par Marie-Line durant sa résidence à Texel, aux Pays-Bas en 2015. Ses pensées, ses songes, ses déplacements, de même que les images et les témoignages collectés y sont recensés et mis en page. La lecture culmine à l’affiche où l’on peut visionner le MUR, œuvre issue et présentée à la fin de l'événement Dichter Bij Zee. Le style de l’ensemble fait écho aux cahiers FIELD NOTES et constitue un objet délicat, précieux et unique.

FIXITY AND FLOW est prêt à partir en impression!

Participez à sa mise en œuvre! Nous avons besoin de 4000$ pour faire imprimer / relier / assembler à la main les 100 exemplaires de ce livre conceptuel. Pour y arriver, nous vous invitons à l’acheter en pré-vente, ou à contribuer au projet de diverses façons grâces aux différentes offres listées ci-bas!

 

 

Nos besoins de financement 

Notre objectif est fixé à 4000$ en 30 jours. Ce montant permettra de couvrir l’ensemble des frais d’impression (réalisée chez Quadriscan, firme d'impression montréalaise reconnue pour la qualité de son travail et son accompagnement des artistes), de même que le cachet de la designer.

Si, par pur bonheur, nous amassons des fonds supplémentaires, ils contribueront à la poursuite de notre démarche créative. Nous comptons donner une suite à ce projet à partir d’une résidence de recherche qui sera effectuée par Marie-Line Leblanc à Kangaroo Island, en Australie, en juillet 2017.

Ce que vous recevrez, selon votre contribution

 

L’impact

Grâce à votre contribution, nous pourrons lancer l’impression d’un ouvrage culturel québécois de qualité. En contrepartie, vous pourrez réserver en primeur l’une des 100 copies du livre d’artiste FIXITY AND FLOW, numérotée et signée par l'artiste.

Votre contribution est un investissement à long terme envers une artiste sérieuse et le milieu culturel qui a besoin d’un public fidèle à ses créateurs.

 

D’autres façons d’aider

Toute forme de contribution est appréciée. Vous pouvez passer le mot et de faire de la publicité autour de notre projet grâce aux outils de partage Indiegogo !

story:
Clear Purpose Glass: beautiful art glass, worthwhile causes

Hello, Indiegogo fans! I'm Amy and I make fused art glass, with emphasis on the colorful and sparkly. Examples include dishes and vases, suncatchers and ornaments, coasters, night lights, garden stakes, and even wind chimes.


A few examples of my glass

It's a hobby I really love, but it leaves me with a lot of art glass I don't know what to do with. I already have a full-time job, so trying to make a living selling it isn't my best option. But I think that if I did sell it I could generate enough income to make a difference to someone else.

So I have founded Clear Purpose Glass. The purpose of Clear Purpose Glass is to sell art glass to generate money for worthwhile nonprofits.

How it works

Let's say you visit my booth at an art show  and make a $10 purchase. $1 of that amount goes to the nonprofit, or even more later after I've recouped some of my startup costs. The rest goes to me to pay for the raw materials and expendables. You get not only the glass at a fair price, but the satisfaction of knowing that you did a good thing for someone else. I get to keep my day job, and also my fun hobby. The nonprofit organization gets a donation. And everyone's happy.

What is needed

The one piece that's missing, that I can't cover in this funding model, is a part of the startup cost. I've already pieced together a little minimalist studio in my basement. But there are a couple of big expenses that have presented a real challenge, and they are the most basic expenses of all -- a kiln so I can fire the glass, and an art show tent and some tables so I can sell the glass.

I have started out using a rented kiln at an art school. I have to drive an hour to get there, and the glass that I had carefully cut and glued will often fall apart in the car. And the rental fees are prohibitive -- $40 per firing. Renting kiln space has enabled me to learn the basics of glass making, but it's certainly not a sustainable business model. A kiln at home is crucial.


Some of my glass loaded into a rented kiln

Once I make the glass, I have to sell it. Most art shows require a tent and they all require tables. If I have those two things, I finish putting together all the booth furnishings myself with a little imagination and elbow grease, and I'm in business!

How much is needed?

Here is the cost breakdown:

  • $2,800 kiln (Paragon clamshell kiln with shipping)
  • $350 tent (including transport case and sidewalls -- these events are “rain or shine!”)
  • $250 tables (five 2'x4' tables to accommodate any art show layout)
If I receive more than $3,400, I will be able to escalate my expansion to online selling, and generate donations  year ‘round. Very exciting!

Easy ways to help

If you donate to this campaign, I’ll thank you with some of my hand crafted art glass. See the sidebar on this page for all the colorful and sparkly options.

If you are short on funds but big on heart, you can still help! Just use the Indiegogo share tools to help me get the word out. Thank you for your kindness.

story: Thank you to everyone who supported this campaign since we started it in March. So far - we have the images printed and ready for framing for the Exhibition Opening on July 1st at the Centre for Democracy. We think its important for our young Norfolk Island photographer, Hari Frohling to be present at his first exhibition opening. Please help us get him here!

story:
With backgrounds in both visual art and English literature, one of the concepts that bridges our two perspectives is the belief that criticism and theory are underrepresented in our fields. Opportunities for artists and writers often take the form of calls for creative works such as short stories, poetry, or painting. We want to provide a forum where thinkers and makers can explore critical discourse in an accessible manner. We want to use books to share this work with the world in a way that allows it to be collected, lent, reread, loved, and passed down. The raw, analog quality of a handmade book appeals to artists, collectors, and readers alike and imbues a text with a care and permanence that web-based outlets like blogs and online magazines don't achieve.

We spent most of the summer traveling in Europe and forging connections with a large number of art galleries. One of the amazing things that stood out about European art spaces was that every gallery had a bookstore section, and they were taken very seriously. We want writers from Wichita and surrounding areas to have a place in this culture, to share ideas with the world, and to close the gap between midwestern “flyover” country and a worldwide conversation. One of the great things about local art space Harvester Arts is the practice of bringing art to Wichita from all over the country; in a way this project is an effort to establish the reverse direction, providing an outlet for Kansas voices to reach the art communities of the rest of the world.

We are currently seeking funding to pay for printing and shipping. We plan to find inexpensive analog publishing methods, potentially buying a used Xerox machine or similar, and assemble each edition by hand in our living room. Our budget will determine the reach of each publication, with the potential for copies to be available in gallery bookstores in France, Germany, Italy, and Romania. With some success we hope to expand the project to include multilingual editions, and we will pay for translation services when possible.

Our first edition will be invitational, and with enough interest we could move to an open-call format.

story:
Begelbyte

For almost a decade, I have lived in a mecca of passion, originality, and inspiration: New York City.  Time and time again, I find myself having intimate conversations with artists who are laying their livelihoods on the line in the pursuit of making something meaningful. These people want to make art that tells a story, and I want to tell their stories.  I want Begelbyte to be an online media platform that highlights emerging artists and their work. I want Begelbyte to be a place followers can visit to see what is transpiring in the cultural playground that is New York City. Most importantly,  I want Begelbyte to become a resourceful network for artists to find each other. As a NYU Tisch trained actress, theater educator at Manhattan's Atlantic Theater Company, and every day NYC art scene hustler,  I have been profoundly inspired by the passion of those around me. I want to share their pursuit of passion with you.

This project is important to me because I want to show that art is an equalizer. By that, I mean that art makes everyone that pursues creating it or views and interprets it valuable.   Moreover, this project is important to me because I have bet a lot (pretty much all) of my livelihood on telling stories. As an actress, writer, and teacher, I believe from my core that the most successful people on this planet (no matter how you measure success) are who they are because they never stop telling stories. Whether it be about what they love, what they hate, or what they worship, stories are how they express their deepest desires. Help me build a platform that curates those stories and exposes those desires.

I am looking to raise $10,000 to build this platform. 

Where the funds go:

  • Web design fees 
  • Filming and editing fees 
  • Photography fees
  • Day of production costs (transportation, food, props, incidentals)
  • Site advertisement 
In the near future (a couple of projects are already in the works), I aim to pair Begelbyte with artists who are looking to shoot fresh content for their existing or start-up brands in new and exciting ways. In the digital age, everyone can use a brief video, be it two minutes or ten minutes, explaining who they are or what they do or that perhaps details a specific new project. We will create scripted shorts, video campaigns, interactive sketches, visual tutorials, or any sort of virtual content that a modern creative could need. Along with selling advertisement space, this is the way that the site will be able to produce income. A team or product will come to me, ask for a piece that features their work, and my team will execute a video that promotes their passion project. But before I can monetize my producing videos for artists and highlight more emerging talents, I need to have a few more examples of what I can achieve. On a nominal  budget, my team and I have managed to shoot our first five pieces.  Those pieces are shown in the above video. We have the heart and the chutspa, now we're just looking for a little $ help. 
Any contribution is greatly appreciated. Thank you for your support!
Sincerely, 
Rachel Begelman

story:
Our Story

Thank you for taking the time to look at this. My name is Kurt and I'm a 26 year old from North Dakota who has fallen in love with tattoos. My last one was over two years ago, but since then I have been wanting to get another done. The problem has been that I did not want just anything to be put permanently onto my body. During the entire time I searched for ideas that had meaning to me, I was busy saving money for the day when I would finally figure out what I wanted. Unfortunately, with my concept in mind, events have transpired such that I find myself woefully short of money.


In the last year, I have racked up bills due to eye surgery and ER visits. All told, I have accrued $4,000 worth of medical bills, wiping out all the money I had saved for the tattoo to try and pay those down. I was told by a friend that there are generous souls on the internet willing to donate to a cause; so, I have come to plead my case and ask for help.


The tattoo concept is a half-sleeve tattoo covering my left arm, beginning at the elbow and covering the upper arm and spilling over onto the shoulder. The centerpiece of the tattoo is being worked on by an artist currently, and the concept design is an ouroboros (signifying the circle/cycle of life, balance, and the world) enclosing a triskelion (signifying perpetual motion/progress and the symbolic representation of past/present/future). Surrounding this central symbol will be an abstract design signifying the chaos of the sky/heavens.


What We Need & What You Get

This is a major project and will require quite a bit of money to complete. All of the funds will be going towards paying the tattoo artist who is actually putting the ink on my skin. If I have extra money following the completion of the tattoo, I will spend that extra money on a nice gift for the design/concept artist. She is a terrific person, and I'm hoping to be able to do something for her!

If I am unable to hit the target goal, then I will be using what donations I get to start the tattoo. The central piece of ouroboros and triskelion will be the first item to be done and can stand on its own, but would look better in the full concept. Whatever funds are left over after that initial design is completed will be used to start additional sections of the tattoo. This will be a project that I plan on completing over time until I am satisfied with the end result and as such I plan on completing it, just with donations that completion will come a whole lot faster than potentially needing to work on it over a decade!

All donations will help me complete a dream of mine, but I am not going to simply ask for donations without offering anything back to the community! My plan is to chronicle the tattooing process through pictures and in a written journal. Donators will be able to follow the progress of the tattoo over time and watch as the concept artist completes the design, and then be able to see that design go from concept to actual ink on my skin.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help me get the word out to others! If all you do is simply forward my page on to others that you know, then that is more than enough to help me out. I appreciate help in all forms and understand that donating for this cause isn't for everyone to do, but please help me by reposting the link to this or by suggesting the page to others that might be interested in my cause!

Thank you!

story:
What’s Happening at The Hatchery?

 

Ruin, regret, nostalgia: artists love this stuff. For The Hatchery: East of Fresno, forty contemporary artists from Europe, the US, and California will make work in direct (or oblique) dialogue with the unique layered past found in the ruins of two failed intentional communities. It will be a temporary artists’ occupation of the property—you could say that a purposeful art community is being formed. Like a colony of ants, we as artists and curators are working together to transform this place, and now we are asking you to work with us!

 

The compound is located east of Fresno, in the rural backwater of Badger, California. It stands in stark contrast with its setting, the foothills of the spectacular Sierra Nevada mountains. The West Coast and East Coast curators hope that by pointing the way “east of Fresno” it can again become a significant site of experience. Perhaps something truly marvelous is “that way.”



East of Fresno is the second exhibition in the ongoing creative use of this property in its present, dilapidated state. Last year’s show, The Hatchery: Free Range, was the cooperative effort of twelve California artists with a vision for the site as an arts venue.


 

We think it’s all pretty cool, but don’t take our word for it—come to Badger and find out for yourself! The Hatchery: East of Fresno will culminate in a free, two-day art and performance event on

September 24 and 25, 2011.

 

The Hatchery: East of Fresno Artists and Curators

Curators:

  Bill Doherty (New York City)

  Anné M. Klint (Oakland)

  Bachrun LoMele (Pinehurst, CA)

  Tom McGlynn (New York City)

 

Artists: 

  Sally Apfelbaum (New York City)

  Dori Atlantis (Los Angeles)

  Kevin Bowman (Visalia, CA)

  Lexygius Calip (Oakland/Philippines)

  Robin Lee Crutchfield (New York City)

  Carlos de Villasante (Petaluma, CA)

  Anna Dembska (Camden, ME)

  Elizabeth Dorbad (Oakland)

  Arthur Dyson (Fresno)

  Glenn Garver (New York City)

  Chris Glenn (Badger, CA)

  Andrea Hawks (Camden, ME)

  Buck Henri (New York City)

  Wendy Hirschberg (New York City)

  Matthew Hopson-Walker (Fresno)

  Jelle Kampen (The Netherlands)

  Eric Knoote (The Netherlands)

  Adam Longatti (Fresno)

  Ron Longsdorf (Kutztown, PA)

  Petra Mattheis (Germany)

  Robert Mertens (Badger, CA)

  Laura Napier (New York City)

  Tressa Pack (Oakland)

  Rick Preston (Miramonte, CA)

  Amie T. Rangel (Visalia, CA)

  Matthew Rangel (Visalia, CA)

  Stefan Riebel (Germany)

  Sheila Ross (Canada)

  David Sanchez Burr (Las Vegas)

  Nicole Shaffer (Oakland)

  Walter Sipser (New York City)

  James Stark (Sultana, CA)

  Eric Strasberg (New York City)

  Laura Ten Eyck (Canada)

  Bruce Tomb (San Francisco)

  Rob van der Schoor (The Netherlands)

  Rachel Van Pelt (Syracuse, NY)

  Tenesh Webber (New York City)

  Aaron Williams (New York City)

  Jane Ziegler (Miramonte, CA)

 


History of the Site: Intentional Communities in Badger

 

Built by Synanon as a drug rehabilitation center and now largely a ruin, the Hatchery is located in Badger, California near Sequoia Kings Canyon National Park. Its current moniker comes from the Synanon practice of raising children communally in what was dubbed the “Hatchery.” Synanon, although progressive in its time for its culture of racial integration and its drug treatment technique, fell into disrepute as its founder became delusional and authoritarian.

 

The property was subsequently re-purposed as a Muslim religious community and boarding school for children from Oakland’s violent streets, but was abandoned after 9/11 amid accusations of fraud.


 

Why support an artists’ temporary occupation at the Hatchery?

 

The Hatchery site has been a veritable ghost town since it was last abandoned in 2001, and visiting it has become a fascinating experience. Ten years of human neglect have encouraged nesting birds, mushrooms and moss, and cattle seeking shade, overtaking structures intended for people. Human histories are physically layered throughout the space—schoolbooks, homework, lesson plans on walls, the remains of a recording studio and a commercial kitchen, carefully chosen design. It is an archeological dig, but the ruins are of our own time. You get a clear sense that things didn’t work out: what happened here? what went wrong?

 

For artists, the Hatchery is a venue unlike any other—ruined, huge, open for so many interpretations, no rules, no restrictions—to explore, exhibit in, and interact with. The social, physical, and natural layers become lenses through which art is made. The artists of East of Fresno are invited to confront and elucidate the lingering questions, and possibly invoke new ones. Provocative, disturbing, and eye-opening, it’s a sensory and pyschic adventure for artist and viewer alike.

 

 

The Impact

 

Thanks to visionary artists and supporters, The Hatchery Art Spaces as a new contemporary arts venue is gaining a foothold in underserved rural Central California, whose demographics are akin to Appalachia or the Deep South.

 

It also has the potential to attract urban arts audiences of Los Angeles and the Bay Area and beyond. Attendees at last year’s Free Range exhibition included young artists from Los Angeles, arts supporters from San Joaquin Valley cities including Visalia and Fresno, former Synanon participants, and mountain locals, including cowboys and National Park employees.

 

The impact on you? By supporting and following this project, you have an opportunity to engage with us in this conversation about these ruins, what happened here, and why. Come to the show for the full effect, but even if you can’t make it, you can view the work online and stay in touch with us for information on the 2011 event.

 


What We Need

 

Supporters like you can help us pay for the myriad expenses related to the unique challenges of our remote location:

  • housing and food for artists as they make their work
  • site preparation and clean up of cow poop, rat poop, and assorted detritus
  • scaffolding for clean up and art installation
  • generators and extension cords
  • transportation to and from airports and hardware stores (it’s at least 70 miles round trip to town)
  • materials needed in addition to those found on site
  • postcards, posters, and road signs to help people find the place.

 

We also need you to help us expand awareness of this unusual venue throughout the region, and place it into the larger landscape of the local, national, and international imagination of creative communities past and present.

 

What You Get

 

In the spirit of ants, who work together to build, eat, and keep things tidy, Hatchery artists are bringing the building back to life. You can help! Make a donation—starting at $5— and your name will appear on an “ant trail” of donors, volunteers, and artists on a Hatchery wall. Not only that, you will receive automatic updates on the project as we march towards our goal. Looping around the baseboards and up around the door frames, this ant trail can grow and grow…

 

Our great Perks include:

  • your name inscribed on an "ant trail" on Hatchery walls
  • t-shirts (made onsite the day of the show by the Fresno State and College of the Sequoias Print Clubs)
  • artist-designed temporary tattoos and bookmarks
  • signed prints by Hatchery artists
  • a weekend-long art retreat of your own!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

  • transport artists to and from airports
  • make runs to hardware stores
  • food shopping, prep, and cleanup
  • distribute publicity materials
  • help set up the site and clean up afterwards
  • donate/lend materials, equipment??
  • cooking for artists and/or volunteers

 

 

Now What?


  • make a donation (thank you!!)
  • help us spread the word on your social networks online and in life
  • check up on us as we get the building ready and as artists start making work
  • come to the show—Saturday, September 24 (12-8pm) and Sunday, September 25 (12-5pm), Badger, California. See you there!

story:
The Temple of Transition

Now that we are back from playa, with our warehouse nearly cleaned and our tools all boxed for next year, your Temple crew has one last job to do before we can finally decompress. With the default world now truly closing in around us, and with its realities poking through the afterglow of the Temple experience, we now need to close our books and settle the many outstanding bills that still remain. Creating the Temple of Transition was not an easy task, and we decided to focus on the Temple and its effect rather than worry about money: but now, we are staring into a gaping hole.


We hope you enjoyed your Temple - and we have been humbled, awed, and delighted by the overwhelmingly positive response the entire community had to this enormous labor of love. But now that we've finally received every remaining bill & invoice, we are around $40000 short: a terrifying amount for a crew that maxed their cards months ago.


This was an enormous project and all the components really began to add up. We know that we have asked for your support all summer long, and so appreciate your help in meeting all of our previous campaign goals. This is the last one.


We don't think it's fair for us to ask the community for the entire amount, so we're asking for half of what we owe, $20000, in this campaign. We literally have no money left, and so we can't afford to offer any schwag - rather, all we have to offer is our gratitude. We know that the ENTIRE Burning Man community made it out to this year's Temple, so if half of the community thinks the Temple experience was worth a single dollar, we'd nearly be home free. No matter how much or how little you can give, please do consider helping this one last time - we've given everything we could, and have nothing left to give ourselves, but it was worth it!



We want to share some wonderful stories that have come from fellow burners about what the Temple meant for them. We are overwhelmed with the emotions and feedback from so many, and the afterglow has us in awe. We hope that you will join in with your story of how the Temple has affected you. Please share your impressions and adventures. Did you get married there? Enjoy the sunrise? Bump into a long lost friend? Dance to the Gameletron? Say goodbye to a loved one passed? Breath in the Earth Harp? We would love to hear from you.


Is this you?


"The temple was the center of my entire burn and moved me profoundly in a way I cannot explain in words."


"Where people who once wore their eyes closed can blink and discover the great diversity and spectacular richness of culture and beauty in the world."


"an opportunity to grieve fully and find a sense of closure that no other practice or custom surrounding death does."


"What a feeling-I was totally blown away! Then the silence with the burn. Thank you again for enabling us to be part of this"

"A concept descending out of the higher consciousness into the physical world to become a piece of art." 

"...every night, without fail, I've gone back to the temple in my dreams...And every time i wake up I remember that the reality of what happened was no match for the copies of my mind. I feel so privileged to have been and to forever be a part of this group of people."


"Thank you, Temple crew. I had the time of my life. Friends and memories were made that will continue to make me smile for a long time to come. I am humbled by the experience and the gratitude expressed by all who stood in the temple's presence."
story_txt:
The Temple of Transition
Now that we are back from playa, with our warehouse nearly cleaned and our tools all boxed for next year, your Temple crew has one last job to do before we can finally decompress. With the default world now truly closing in around us, and with its realities poking through the afterglow of the Temple experience, we now need to close our books and settle the many outstanding bills that still remain. Creating the Temple of Transition was not an easy task, and we decided to focus on the Temple and its effect rather than worry about money: but now, we are staring into a gaping hole.

We hope you enjoyed your Temple - and we have been humbled, awed, and delighted by the overwhelmingly positive response the entire community had to this enormous labor of love. But now that we've finally received every remaining bill & invoice, we are around $40000 short: a terrifying amount for a crew that maxed their cards months ago. 

This was an enormous project and all the components 
really began to add up. We know that we have asked for your support all 
summer long, and so appreciate your help in meeting all of our previous 
campaign goals. This is the last one. 

We don't think it's fair for us to ask the community for the entire amount, so we're asking for half of what we owe, $20000, in this campaign. We literally have no money left, and so we can't afford to offer any schwag - rather, all we have to offer is our gratitude. We know that the ENTIRE Burning Man community made it out to this year's Temple, so if half of the community thinks the Temple experience was worth a single dollar, we'd nearly be home free. No matter how much or how little you can give, please do consider helping this one last time - we've given everything we could, and have nothing left to give ourselves, but it was worth it!


We want to share some wonderful stories that have come from fellow burners about what the Temple meant for them. We are overwhelmed with the emotions and feedback from so many, and the afterglow has us in awe. We hope that you will join in with your story of how the Temple has affected you. Please share your impressions and adventures. Did you get married there? Enjoy the sunrise? Bump into a long lost friend? Dance to the Gameletron? Say goodbye to a loved one passed? Breath in the Earth Harp? We would love to hear from you.


Is this you?



"The temple was the center of my entire burn and moved me profoundly in a way I cannot explain in words."

"Where
 people who once wore their eyes closed can blink and discover the great
 diversity and spectacular richness of culture and beauty in the world."

"an opportunity to grieve fully and find a sense of closure that no other practice or custom surrounding death does."


"What a feeling-I was totally blown away! Then the silence with the burn. Thank you again for enabling us to be part of this"
"A concept descending out of the higher consciousness into the physical world to become a piece of art." 


"...every night, without fail, I've gone back to the temple in my dreams...And every time i wake up I remember that the reality of what happened was no match for the copies of my mind. I feel so privileged to have been and to forever be a part of this group of people."




"Thank you, Temple crew. I had the time of my life. Friends and memories were made that will continue to make me smile for a long time to come. I am humbled by the experience and the gratitude expressed by all who stood in the temple's presence."

story:
Quemaduras del Sol ("sunburn"), a golden sun effigy, is San Diego's regional community art project for the Burning Man 2011 'Rites of Passage' CORE Project. Launched in April of this year, the all volunteer team has been hard at work building the project.


Our Story


We are a team of 15-20 local volunteers building a 20' tall sun effigy and community arts project to represent the San Diego region at Burning Man 2011. Quemaduras del Sol represents the sun and beaches of the southwest coast, will be a climbable art installation, and features a center viewing platform between the dual sun faces on each side.


Quemaduras del Sol brings part of San Diego to the citizens of BRC, shimmering day and night over a soft audio background of ocean surf recorded at the many beaches in San Diego. The effigy base is inscribed with messages from the local burner community for the larger community in Black Rock City.


San Diego is bringing Quemaduras del Sol to the playa in 2011 to join many Regionals in the very special CORE project, the Circle of Regional Effigies. This sun will burn for all on playa as part of the great circle of fire on Thursday night during the event.

 

The Impact


Due to our location, San Diego is typically unable to incorporate the burning of a large effigy in our regional burns because doing so is a wildfire hazard and our region is usually under an open fire ban. Wildfires have historically caused massive destruction to the San Diego area, so the CORE project is a unique opportunity to create large scale fire art.


This project has brought together segments of the community by incorporating their talents in various roles which have brought the San Diego CORE project to fruition. This project was designed by a second year burner, and has been built by veteran burners and many first timers. People who might not have met otherwise came together on Sundays to bring this piece to the Playa.

 

What We Need


Simply put: transportation & gas money!! We all know at nearly $4/gallon + per mile charges on a rental truck traveling 1306 miles that getting Quemaduras del Sol to the playa is not going to be an inexpensive feat! So once again, we're calling on our community, friends and fellow art-enthusiasts to help us with the next leg of this race, affectionately titled, "San Diego to BRC or Bust!" Every little bit helps so please donate whatever you can!


Contribution Breakdown:

  • IndieGoGo Fees: 4% if we make our goal or 9% if we don't goes to IndieGoGo for their awesome help making this website possible! 
  • 3% - Credit Card Processing Fees because frankly Visa, MC and all the rest want their share too!
  • The other 88-93% will go towards our travel budget to pay for
    • Truck Rental Fee
    • Mileage Charges
    • Fuel


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word!! Share our links on your social networking feeds, tell your friends or tell a stranger--anything to help us garner support is highly encouraged and appreciated!
  • On Playa Volunteers are needed to staff our three awesome crews! Check out www.coresandiego.org/on-playa-volunteers.html for more details

story:
Our Story

LOOPOOL (aka Jean-Paul Garnier) is a sound artist based in Los Angeles and has been active since 1998.  While his focus is on experimental music, astronomy is a huge inspiration and he feels that the destiny of human beings lies in space.  LOOPOOL's picture was flown on the Space Shuttle Mission STS-134 as part of the Face in Space public outreach program and he has contributed to the Space Rocks program, both run by NASA.  LOOPOOL is also a member of the National Space Society and a supporter of the Mars Society.


The Impact

Naming a Star is completely a subject of vanity and holds no consequence in the scientific community. The company that does this (starregistry.com) is not recognized by the International Astronomical Union which is in charge of naming astronomical objects.  The reason for doing this project is to raise awareness about astronomy.  It is anticipated that the goal will not be met and that is great because if it is not then the money will be donated to SETI (search for extraterrestrial intelligence).


What We Need & What You Get

The deluxe package for naming a Star after LOOPOOL would cost about $550 (although it would only be lip service).  The main reason for this is to either have a Star falsely named after LOOPOOL or more reasonably to raise money for the SETI program.  Since there are Billions of Stars it is highly likely that we are not alone in the Universe, we should try and find our fellow beings of intelligence and communicate with them!  Everyone that donates will receive LOOPOOL merchandise as a reward!

Other Ways You Can Help

More important than this fundraiser you can get involved with SETI through a program released to the public called seti@home.  With this program you can donate your computer's unused processing power to sift through radio signals detected by the SETI program and possibly find an alien signal!  Hook up to it here: http://setiathome.berkeley.edu/

story:
My Story
I’m a clay artist living in Weaverville, NC.  I renovated a garage and turned it into a studio to fulfill my dream of continuing my career as a ceramics artist, and to create a teaching environment where people of all interests and backgrounds could come and tap into their creative talents using clay as their medium.   I lived in Japan for 15 years where I studied and worked as a clay artist, doing wood fired ceramics.  Check out my website to see some of that work.  I decided to take my skills and experience back to the U.S. and share them with people interested in realizing their own creative abilities.  That’s where the idea of Red Door Arts came.   After my parents passed away, I was left with a small amount of money to purchase a venue where I could continue my ceramics work while creating an environment to teach in.    I renovated the studio, but ran out of funds.  The missing link in fulfilling this dream, is the kiln.  I have a studio full of unfired ware, and a beautiful space to teach in.  Now I need a kiln - a special type of kiln to enable me to load large, heavy pieces into.  It's called a (Tom Turner) car kiln.  The door and floor of the kiln are built on wheels and set on tracks to roll in and out of the kiln.

Why Komainu (Lion Dogs)?
During my years living in Japan, and traveling throughout Asia, I discovered a fascination with komainu (lion dogs), and would travel to different areas seeking out these stylized creatures sitting atop stone columns and in entrance ways guarding shrines and other holy places.  They represent strength, fierceness, loyalty, and an unwavering sense of a higher truth.  Standing in front of them always gave me a feeling of strength and peace.  I hope to pass that feeling on to others by creating these pieces to sit outside one’s home, in entrance ways, or anywhere you'd want to feel a sense of protection.
The pieces I've made so far, are just the beginning.  I have lots more to explore with these forms, and their symbolism.  I'm excited to continue on this path.  The more I have the opportunity to delve into my own clay work, the more I have to offer to others wanting to explore their own creative skills.

The Impact
I live in a culturally rich area of Western North Carolina.  It's a mecca for artists of all types.  I'm often asked to teach art classes by the local community.  Weaverville is just 10 minutes north of Asheville, yet there's no venue for teaching art to the public.  My desire is to take those 15 years of living and learning in Japan, and create a community of creative people to share my experiences and know-how with.  The tougher the times, the more need for wholesome, supportive community.  Red Door Arts would be that venue. 

Where Your Money Will Go
Building a kiln is a costly project, but without the kiln, my clay pieces cannot be completed, and teaching at my studio would be difficult.  The supplies needed to complete the kiln are insulating firebrick, angle iron for the kiln frame and tracks, the interior shelves and stilts for stacking the ware, piping for propane, kiln burners, chimney block and flue, construction of small supporting tables on wheels to move clay work from the studio to the kiln, as well as labor.  All of this comes to a minimum of $12,000.  This would allow me, not only to fire the lion dogs I have already made, but to continue to explore these forms by making more.  It would also allow me to start teaching ceramics classes at Red Door Arts because I will finally be able to fire clay work done by students. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Times are tough for all of us, and any amount given would be received with tremendous gratitude.  If successfully funded, I'll hit the ground running and keep you posted throughout the process. Any funds received will go toward building this kiln - no matter how long it takes!   Please pass this word on to your friends and family.  Any ounce of support will be received with a ton of gratitude!  Thank you!

story:
Our Ladies of South 4th Street is a company.

But we don't sell anything. We do, however, make art. And we show it to you for free. See our website for the full details of our manifesto, but here it will suffice to say that we sponsor all charitable artists to share their work in a community unafraid of reverence. And that sponsorship takes some funding.

Because there's more to Our Ladies than the free performances that we host to sway your spirits. As our scrappy company tries to make a splash in the Brooklyn arts scene, we need some starting capital to invest in chairs, microphones, a projector for film screenings, promotional materials like stickers and postcards, lighting...

And you can help us make that happen. 


The Impact

By providing funds for production equipment and events, we can give our artists--who are performing for free and from the heart--the basic tools to bring their vision to you. Photographers want to show you their work on real photo paper, actors want a microphone to make even their whispers heard in the very back of the room, and all artists want word of their work to reach new audiences. To all those ends, your contribution makes a HUGE difference.


What We Need & What You Get

We've set the budget for the fall season at $1,000--which works out to about $330 per month. So far we've been able to get everything we need, but for November and December we need:


-a projector and screen for a film screening

-more lumber for building a custom sheet-screen

-250 more promotional stickers and postcards with our new website

-a set of picture frames for playbills and signed photographs of all our featured artists

-more mounting materials for our installation artists


As for what you get--well, you get an amazing lineup of free local performances with free drinks and lots of love. Pretty good deal, huh?


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page and our website with anyone and everyone! Our Ladies shows work out of the Matron-Saints' apartment because we like to blend art and life, home and performance--but an intimate community can still hold a heck of a lot of members. So spread the word! We thank you heartily for it, from the bottom of our bottomless lady hearts.


Much love,


Sophia Treanor and Rachel Broderick

The Matron-Saints

Our Ladies of South 4th Street

story:
Short Summary

Hello!

My name is Jennifer Martins, I'm 25 years old and I live in poor community in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.
I'm an artist and I Study in a Public University to become an art teacher.
I want to go to Argentina to improve my study and my work as an artist, also.

In Brazil, we have two types of universities:

Private universities: We have to pay to study, but they're too expensive, usually.
Public universities: We don't have to pay, but it's very hard to get a vancancy.

After 5 long years of too much effort and study, I finaly got my vacancy to a Public University (UEMG).
Throughout all this time, I dreamed with this oportunity to study in Argentina, however I couldn't get any financial support from my unniversity to go there.
I tried to work to get the necessary money, but I had a health problem, which broke me up.

After many attempts, I got this year a vacancy in a University of Buenos Aires and I'm going to start on April.
A friend of mine who lives in Buenos Aires gave me the airline ticket to go there. However, I don't have money to live there.
That's why I'm here, asking for your help to go on with this life project.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I estimated 3,000 to start living there. This money is going to pay my rent, food, transportation and any study costs.

Helping me, you can get acess to my personal blog, special thanks there, exclusives draws, photos  and painting made by me!

 

The Impact

Despite the physical and financial difficulties, I kept my dream to live of my art. I want to come back to Brazil as an art teacher and start another projects.
I know that I have a different sight, wich can cause impact in the reality of people's life, by my photographs, paintings and draws.
In my actual reality, I can't make this difference in people's life with my creations inside my drawer.
Many things made me want to give up my dream. Anyway, I'm getting closer day by day.
Without your help, I can't live in Argentina.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help with money, that's ok. You can help sharing my page to all your friends who likes arts or helps people. 

 

Share my page www.indiegogo.com/goinginside

Jennifer Martins.

story:
So there were these artists that liked dogs and they liked video games, and comic books, and animes, and mangas, and role play. These artists wanted a way to raise funds for the local animal shelter, The Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland.

The Dorky Dogs Calendar is  going to be a compilation of 12 nerdy canine images in traditional medias created by 6 artists that is ALSO useful for writing down vet appointments and your mother's birthday. We're the helpful sort. 

The point of this campaign is to raise enough funds to print the calenders and pay the artists for their work. We will be selling the calendars online as well as at local comic book shops, doggy daycares, and grooming shops. We already have a growing list of local business owners that have expressed interest in carrying our local-grown product. :) If it goes well enough we would like to do a calendar project every year, but one step at a time!

Any funds over our $3000 goal will go towards printing extra calenders if there is a demand, if not we will donate extra funds to the Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland.

How we will spend our funds


Everything up to $2000 goes towards printing and S&H of the calendars

Anything after $2000 up to $3200 will go towards the artists to thank them for their work.

Anything over $3000 will go to ARL.

*-  $20 of all calendar sales (both in store, online, and through our incentives here) goes directly to the Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland - *



The Artists

Stacey (Skardash) Kardash:

Stacey is an official sketch card artist for Rittenhouse Archives (Marvel Comics), Cryptozoic Entertainment (DC, Archer), Perna Studios and Versicolor Productions. Stacey has a chihuahua (Mini) and an Italian Grey Hound/ Whippet mix (Rocky).  https://www.facebook.com/skardashart

Melanie (Meltingdoll) Tingdahl:

Mel has done artwork for the covers of the My Little Pony comic as well as the Adventure Time comic, and is known to do artwork for comic shop displays.  She specializes in crayon artwork and watercolor and would one day love to adopt a corgi or Australian Shepard.   https://www.facebook.com/melanietingdahl

Liz (Lizspit) Jackson:

Liz does cover art for the novels of T.R. Blasingame as well as independent commissions and the retired web-comic 'Ratutorials'.  She owns a rescued Border Collie mix (Zabu) and an old orange barn cat (Scott).  https://www.facebook.com/LizSpit

Amanda (Archimer) Anderson

Archimer is a Graphic and Web Designer, she coordinates the Artists' Alley for PortConMaine and appears in costume at various events with the Wampa chapter of the Mandalorian Mercs.  Archimer has a black and white cat named WAFFLES!  http://www.pleadingbrilliance.com

Decland McCarthy

Declan is a college student, has self-published three mini comics, and ran a semi-weekly comic on his tumblr account.  http://cheerupbrigade.tumblr.com/

Meagaon Gibson

Meagan is also a college student and an illustrator specializing in ADORABLE! http://www.heyagainmeagan.tumblr.com/


Elizabeth (Betsy) cole

Betsy is an independent, freelance character designer and animation artist residing in Topsham, Maine. She is aiming for a studio job in teh future, but fo rnow she is content working as a fulltime toon-animal factory. Betsy lives with a Pembroke Welsh Corgi named Jasmine, Mister kitty, and a goldfish named Markl.  http://idreamin2d.blogspot.com


The Art So Far!

These are the pictures that have been completed so far!

Akira Tetsuwoof - Declan

Avatar the Last Arf Bender - Mel

The Arfvengers - Stacey

Game of Bones, Ned Bark - Liz

Super Barky All Pups - Meagan

Mass Effect Shepherds - Mel

Megaman Boston Terrier - Liz

PawTrek - Liz

Pawwars, Ewok Pomeranians - Amanda


Art To Come

We Still have a few images left to produce!  Here is what we are thinking:

Amanda - Zelda

Mel - Harry Potter

Betsy - World of Warcraft



Keep watching our campaign! We will upload new pictures as they are created!


----------
story_txt:
So there were these artists that liked dogs and they liked video 
games, and comic books, and animes, and mangas, and role play. These artists wanted a way to raise funds for the local animal shelter, The Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland. 
The Dorky 
Dogs Calendar is  going to be a compilation of 12 nerdy 
canine images in traditional medias created by 6 artists that is ALSO 
useful for writing down vet appointments and your mother's birthday. 
We're the helpful sort. 
The point of this campaign is to raise
 enough funds to print the calenders and pay the artists for their work. We
 will be selling the calendars online as well as at local comic book 
shops, doggy daycares, and grooming shops. We already have a growing 
list of local business owners that have expressed interest in carrying 
our local-grown product. :) If it goes well enough we would like to do a
 calendar project every year, but one step at a time! 
Any funds over our $3000 goal will go towards printing extra calenders if there is a demand, if not we will donate extra funds to the Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland. 
How we will spend our funds

Everything up to $2000 goes towards printing and S&H of the calendars 
Anything after $2000 up to $3200 will go towards the artists to thank them for their work.
Anything over $3000 will go to ARL. 
*-  $20 of all calendar sales (both in store, online, and through our incentives here) goes directly to the Animal Refuge League of Greater Portland - *
